PretrialNotes: 23/6/1658 investigated by the presbytery. Accusations stemmed from confessions by Margaret Duchill and Margaret Talzeor. Paton denied all the charges. She was confronted by Talzeor and Remy. On 19/7/1658 the JPs investigated allegations of extrajudicial torture and burning with hot stones.  They did not do anything.
TrialNotes: Assize ordered to go to Edinburgh for 3/8/1658 for trial of Alloway/Alloa witches, (I don't think the trial happened there?)

Notes: I think she may have lived at Leith at some point.
DevilNotes: Did not confess to any features of demonic pact to the presbytery but they implied it.  She later did confess to a demonic pact.  She was heard yelling to Satan to get out of her bed.
MeetingNotes: The Devil went home with her in a great storm
FolkNotes: Confessed some story about having a moldiewort that she kept at home ?familiar but unlikely.  A woman saw a woman walking home from where they collected mussels, looked back and saw only a sow, and 'in the twinkling of an eye' she saw no sow but Jonet Black.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Accused of damaging the boat at Black grange while in the shape of a corbie.

Notes: I think she may have lived at Leith at some point.

PretrialNotes: Questioned by presbytery as part of a bigger group. Confronted Bessie Paton who she said took her to meetings.

Notes: Claimed to have been in devil's service for 3 years, 25+3=28.
Charnotes: Denounced by Margaret Duchall and confessed to demonic pact.
DevilNotes: Confessed the devil's name was Johne. At one meeting there was a gentlewoman whose name she did not know. The woman had a black pot and wore a green waistcoat with grey tails. In second confession described touching her head and foot
MeetingNotes: She described many meetings with various combinations of other people. Also said that they spoke in another language.  Had a meeting in a brewhouse
FolkNotes: Claimed that Jonet Great, who was dead, came out with herself and others to a man's house, where they stole bread
DiseaseNotes: Claimed that the other woman had told her about malefice (death of animals and children) but did not confess to any herself the first time. Later she claimed that they had destroyed a child and animals.
CaseNotes: K. Remy, B. Paton, and M. Tailior were extrajudicially tortured and burnt with hot stones by four local men.  The JPs questioned them, and confronted them with the three witchcraft suspects.  No further action was taken.

Notes: Claimed to have been in devil's service for 3 years, 25+3=28.
Charnotes: Denounced by Margaret Duchall and confessed to demonic pact.
DevilNotes: Confessed the devil's name was Johne. At one meeting there was a gentlewoman whose name she did not know. The woman had a black pot and wore a green waistcoat with grey tails. In second confession described touching her head and foot
MeetingNotes: She described many meetings with various combinations of other people. Also said that they spoke in another language.  Had a meeting in a brewhouse
FolkNotes: Claimed that Jonet Great, who was dead, came out with herself and others to a man's house, where they stole bread
DiseaseNotes: Claimed that the other woman had told her about malefice (death of animals and children) but did not confess to any herself the first time. Later she claimed that they had destroyed a child and animals.
CaseNotes: K. Remy, B. Paton, and M. Tailior were extrajudicially tortured and burnt with hot stones by four local men.  The JPs questioned them, and confronted them with the three witchcraft suspects.  No further action was taken.
PretrialNotes: Questioned by the presbytery and elders. Confessed to several points of witchcraft and named several others. Later claimed that James Lindsay told her to name others so she would live. Claimed she was tortured with hot stones. On 19/7/1658 the JPs investigated allegations of extrajudicial torture and burning with hot stones.  They did nothing.
TrialNotes: Assize ordered to go to Edinburgh for 3/8/1658 for trial of Alloway/Alloa witches, (I don't think the trial happened there?)  Statements taken before the presbytery on 22/7/1658.  Listed on a high court index for 3/9/1658.  Not sure where she was tried.

Notes: Is also listed as Elspeth Black and Elspet Blak.  She was able to sign her name on a supplication to 'the commissioners of justice' protesting her guilty verdict, probably at least middling status.
CaseNotes: She was tried twice (with two others).  In her first trial on 23/3/1659 in the circuit court she was found guilty and ordered to be transported.  Until that could be arranged she was to be held in Stirling prison.  Apparently after two years of imprisonment they petitioned privy council, who ordered another trial due to irregularities in the first one.  The second trial was a local one, we don't know the outcome.

PretrialNotes: JPs to put her to liberty on 8/1/1659 until she stood trial.  One witness testified that a misfortune was probably not due to witchraft.
TrialNotes:
Assize ordered to go to Edinburgh for 3/8/1658 for trial of Alloway/Alloa witches, (I don't think the trial happened there?).

On 22/3/1659 Katherine and Elizabeth Black wrote a supplication to the justice commissioners asking for a postponement of sentencing and for the jury to be recalled and  instructed at law.  

Pleaded not guilty

I think it is the North circuit even though it is bound in with South and West circuit secion.  She pleaded not guilty.  Later docs show that there were irregularities and another trial was ordered to be held.
PostTrialNotes: She was ordered to be held in Stirling tolbooth until arrangements could be made for her banishment.  She was banished from the nations of England, Scotland, and Ireland - essentially she was ordered to be transported.  She gave her mark (signature) stating that once transported she wouldn't return.  She appears to have been held with 2 others till 1661

DevilNotes: Claimed the devil was called 'Johne'. He lay on top of her cow and was like a cow.
MeetingNotes: Several meetings at various places. Often met at the house of the person who they intended to harm
FolkNotes: Often met the devil and others at 12 o'clock at night.
DiseaseNotes: Confessed that she complained to the devil about people who had insulted her or owed the group money and the devil would punish them and kill them. Caused death of people and animals. Took a man and tried to drown him.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery investigated accusations and took confessions. Letter to be sent to the justice of the peace and ordered to imprison the group.
PostTrialNotes: Note in presbytery records on 23/6/1658 that Margaret Duchill was dead.

Notes: also recorded as Katherine, Katharine, Kathren and Blak.  She and Elizabeth Black were able to sign a supplication to 'the commissioners of justice' protesting their guilty verdict.
Charnotes: Witness statements said that people overheard her talking about the Devil.  But not enough information to make a solid characterisation.
DevilNotes: Mention of giving her daughter over to the Devil. The circuit court handwritting is difficult to make out.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of malefices.
CaseNotes: She was ordered to be released from prison on 28/12/1658 due to ill health (bloody flux).  She was tried twice (with two others).  In her first trial on 23/3/1659 in the circuit court she was found guilty and ordered to be transported.  Until that could be arranged she was to be held in Stirling prison.  Apparently after two years of imprisonment they petitioned privy council, who ordered another trial due to irregularities in the first trial.  The second trial was a local one, we don't know the outcome.

CaseNotes: She was ordered to be released from prison on 28/12/1658 due to ill health (bloody flux).  She was tried twice (with two others).  In her first trial on 23/3/1659 in the circuit court she was found guilty and ordered to be transported.  Until that could be arranged she was to be held in Stirling prison. PretrialNotes: She was first arrested in 9/1658 and eventually released on 28/12/1658 due to illness (bloody flux). She was then rearrested and released on bail.  Testificate (solemn declaration in writing) described her appalling jail conditions (JC26/26).  The order from the Privy Council to release her from prison was addressed to the JPs of Clackmannanshire.  She was then tried in the circuit court and tried again later.
TrialNotes:
JC26 documents show that she was imprisoned and released several times due to illness.  On 18/12/1658, the Privy Council ordered her to be tried at the circuit court of Stirling.  

Assize ordered to go to Edinburgh for 3/8/1658 for trial of Alloway/Alloa witches, (I don't think the trial happened there?)

She pleaded not guilty

I think it is the North circuit even though it is bound in with South and West circuit secion.  She plead not guilty. On an undated list of people from 1658-9 to be arraigned before the justice courts.

Was arrested again and petitioned for release (on 16/3/1659) was granted, trial was set for circuit court in Stirling to be held 22/3/1659.

On 22/3/1659 Katherine and Elizabeth Black wrote a supplication to the justice commissioners asking for a postponement of sentencing and for the jury to be recalled and  instructed at law.  

 Later documents indicate a number of irregularities at this trial and the accused was held in prison until 1661 when an order for another trial was issued.
PostTrialNotes: She was ordered to be held in Stirling tolbooth until arrangements could be made for her banishment.  She was banished from the nations of England, Scotland, and Ireland - essentially she was ordered to be transported.  She gave her mark (signature) stating that once transported she wouldn't return. Held in prison till 1661.

MeetingNotes: They danced in a ring around the broadstone in Gallowhop.  She asked the Devil to get amends of a soldier that quartered in her house, he agreed to get rid of the English man.  She drank wine with Simon the Devil.  Wanted amends of a wobster who kept her cloth over a year, and amends of a minister for a debt.
DiseaseNotes: Wanted amends of people who crossed her from the Devil. Those people suffered.
PretrialNotes: Pre-trial held by JPs in Dunbar, then moved to Edinburgh for sentencing.
TrialNotes: A trial held by JPs. Assume this is a trial because it says that the court was fenced.  The JPs made a verdict of guilty, doesn't seem to have been a jury!  To be taken to Edinburgh for 1/3/1659 for sentencing.  Have an undated indictment.

DevilNotes: He promised her amends.  Devil put his hand on her shoulder and left a pain.
MeetingNotes: They danced in a ring. She confessed that she fell and the Devil took her up the hand (Lacost testified about this prior to her confession!).  They drank ale and wine that they stole. Meeting around the broadstones at Gallowhop, asked for amends for a man who stole meal.  Wanted amends on the English because they took her to the grange and left her there. Devil couldn't help because they were no longer in Scotland. [so did the Devil only have power in Scotland?]

PretrialNotes: Referred to civil magistrate by presbytery, 5/1/1659.  Interrogated at Stenton.  And in the tolbooth of Dunbar at a JP quarter session 23/1/1659.  She was 'seriously exhorted' to tell the truth about her relations with the Devil.  She denounced many people who she then confronted at the next interrogations.  The JPs held  interrogations on 8/2/1659 and she confronted the 5 people she denounced.
TrialNotes: They wanted to prosecute her so they asked the commissioners how to proceed.  No evidence of how they proceeded.  The people she named were all tried by the JPs and sent to Edinburgh for sentencing.  Have an undated indictment.

FolkNotes: A woman went to her for advice on how to cure her daughter.  Margaret told her to put something above her door, which the woman refused and her daughter died.

Charnotes: It is simply a list of people and whether or not they ratified their witness statements.  Impossible to tell what the dittay said.  We have a document called the Manner of the Charmes of the Stirling Witches, lots of descriptions!
FolkNotes: To cure blasted people, washed them with water from the hollow ground after an ebb in the sea with a quantity of meal and straw placed in four corners of the bed, and she used a horseshoe, a hook and a piece of raw flesh.  She said father, son and holy ghost three times.  To cure maw turned she walked people around an oak pole three times, said some words to God and St. Brisbane.  For curing someone that is wronged by an other at variance with them, go them and crave your health back (basically curing the quarrel, words, misfortune illnesses).  For keeping folks from harm, bury a quick modiewort  in a box under the outside of a threshold.
PretrialNotes: confessed to charming, but denied witchcraft
TrialNotes: I think this is the North Circuit, even though it was bound in with the South and West circuit materials.  She plead not guilty.  On an undated list of people from 1658-9 to be arraigned before the justice courts.  Witness list issued on 16/3/1658

Notes: Her husband was a 'gairer'?  She confessed to being with Satan for 24 years.  Age estimated at 49
FolkNotes: she knows a blasted person, which means a bewitched person 'by the gogling of their eyes and turning hither and tither to ather side.'  Washes their clothes in St. Ninian's well for healing.  This will either 'end them or mend them.'  She learned it from lady McFarlens daughter 24 years prior.  She transfers the disease if she meets anyone on the way back from the well.  Also layed two foxtree leaves under their head and middle.  She cures maw turning by leading people around an oak tree three times, repeating words.  For curing persons forespoken she recites words and takes some of the illness into herself.  For curing heart fires she uses a belt and two threads she rolls them and if the threads are on the top and the bottom the person has heart fires.
PretrialNotes: She confessed to healing with deeds, but denied using any words.
TrialNotes: In a later addition to the book labelled South and West, but this is a mistake.  She confessed to healing with deeds, but denied witchcraft or using of words.  On an undated list of people from 1658-9 to be arraigned before the justice courts.  16/3/1658 witness list issued.  Witnesses were summond on 18/3/1659 for trial.  She pleaded not guilty

DevilNotes: Saw the Devil in her bed, implied sex.
MeetingNotes: When describing a meeting (presumably in response to being asked to name names) she said, there were 40 women at the meeting but they were behind a mist and the place where the men were was also covered in mist.  She said that Fermor came to her while sleeping and took her to a meeting.
PretrialNotes: Arrested on order of the JPs,
TrialNotes: Tried by the JPs and moved to Edinburgh for sentencing.  JPs decided that the confessions were proof enough of guilt.  She was indicted at the Kirk of Stenton on 14 March 1659.  Have their formal indictment.

Notes: Described as 'living out of wedlock'. And says that she committed lots of sins from that.  Could be single but I think it means that she is with a man but not married. Going to put very poor socioeconomic status because she was seeking alms.
DevilNotes: When seeking alms from Fermor, Fermor told Jonnet that there was a better way to live and introduced her to the Devil in grey clothes who looked like a gentleman.  She confessed that the Devil locked her heart until a minister prayed and she received peace.
MeetingNotes: Said there were 11 people at her meeting.  The Devil was angry when she was away (when she missed a meeting?).
PretrialNotes: Arrested by order of the JP
TrialNotes: Investigated by the JPs.  She was indicted, probated, examined and confessed on 2/3/1659.  But does not appear to have been tried at that point.  The JPs decided that confessions were proof of guilt and they were to be moved to Edinburgh for sentencing.  Have their formal indictment.

DiseaseNotes: She struck a man in the face with a kaird (comb used to prepare wool) to the 'efusion of his blood'.
TrialNotes: She was ordered to be tried in the Roxburgh Roll of 8/4/1659.  The persuar was the Advocate General.

PretrialNotes: Earl of the Cassillis Lord Justice General wrote to the kirk session on 25/11/1660. The kirk session said they knew nothing about this except for the confessions that were now in the hands of a church elder Walter Scott.  Scott agreed to bring the confessions to the Justice General and question neighbours about her.  He specifically asked her neighbours about malefices, charms or superstitions.  No witnesses came forward so released on caution.  She was visited in the Tolbooth by her husband.  The whole thing was referred to the Lord Justice General on 27/11/1660.  The note says that lots of people had been released on caution by the JPs sitting in Tranent.

Charnotes: She was consulted by Katherine Ross, Lady Fowlis to destroy heirs.  She seems to have been Lady Fowlis' right-hand woman.  She was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady Fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheritance of land, titles, and property.
DiseaseNotes: Poisoned ale.

PretrialNotes: Earl of the Cassillis, Lord Justice General, wrote to the kirk session on 25/11/1660. The kirk session said they knew nothing about this except for the confessions that were now in the hands of a church elder Walter Scott.  Scott agreed to bring the confessions to the Justice General and question neighbours about her.  He specifically asked her neighbours about malefices, charms or superstitions.  No witnesses came forward so released on caution.   The whole thing was referred to the Lord Justice General on 27/11/1660.  The note says that lots of people had been released on caution by the JPs sitting in Tranent.

MeetingNotes: She confessed to being taken our of her body for a meeting.
She confessed to being taken our of her body for a meeting.
PretrialNotes: She is listed in a draft dittay with 12 other suspects, with the date 7/8/1661 on it.  Unlcear why she didn't proceed to trial?
TrialNotes: The justice found that the confession was not compelling.  She changed it to say that if she met the Devil it was all in a dream.  The charges were dropped.

Notes: Met the devil about 7 years before 25+7=32.
DevilNotes: Devil was described as lying heavy upon her while she was in bed with Helen Speiris, another mentioned witch.
PretrialNotes: Listed in a draft dittay with 12 other people, but she wasn't included in the High Court Books of Adjournal like most of the people from this draft dittay were.  Unclear why?  Mabye it was because she was 'not present' on the day this draft dittay was dated (which was the same day as the trial)

Charnotes: She was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady Fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheritance of land, titles, and property.

PretrialNotes: Released from prison on bond, 1/8/1661.

Notes: Recorded as an indweller in Dalkeith.
Charnotes: She was delated by Janet Watsone
DevilNotes: Met the devil after discord with her husband.  She knew it was the Devil because he vanished more quickly than a normal man.
MeetingNotes: meeting happened on 'beal fire night' (Beltane)

Notes: Recorded as an indweller in Dalkeith.
Charnotes: She was delated by Janet Watsone
DevilNotes: Met the devil after discord with her husband.  She knew it was the Devil because he vanished more quickly than a normal man.
MeetingNotes: meeting happened on 'beal fire night' (Beltane)
PretrialNotes:
After she was denounced she demanded the trial [meaning the test of pricking to prove her innocence].  This backfired and they found three marks, she then confessed.  Then William Scot and Calderwood exorted her to confess, which she did.
The PC records appear to indicate a later commission issued to try her and 2 others after she had confessed.
TrialNotes: She was listed as appearing with a group of Dalkeith witches who were all tried together, but her case did not make to the High Court trial held at Dalkeith.  A side note to her case says 'passes this pro loco et tempore'

Notes: Recorded as an indweller in Dalkeith
MeetingNotes: Meeting on the last beal fire night (i.e. Beltane)

Notes: Recorded as an indweller in Dalkeith
MeetingNotes: Meeting on the last beal fire night (i.e. Beltane)
PretrialNotes: PC records note that accused was already imprisoned and had confessed to witchcraft, demonic pact and renunciation of baptism. This commission seems to have been issued after the date of trial.
TrialNotes: She did not appear in the Books of Adjournal as having a High Court trial, but she was part of the trial.  I think the charges may have been dropped because a side note says 'she was so [??Brinted] that schoe knew not common sense'

Charnotes: May have confessed to pact
DevilNotes: Did not renounce her baptism.

Charnotes: May have confessed to pact
DevilNotes: Did not renounce her baptism.
PretrialNotes: Commission issued after some in the group had confessed to pact and renunciation of baptism(6/9/1661). Others still only suspected of the crime. No details about where imprisoned. Appealed to PC after 40 weeks imprisonment.

CaseNotes: Could not find these in the source referenced by Larner.
Could not find the sources referenced by Larner.

Notes: Reputation of 14 years; husband was a collier
DevilNotes: Pact was in exchange for a new petticoat, and she confessed that the Devil as a '[?] gentleman' had come over the water to the colliers.  She was called Clear Keys because she had keys with her, according to her confession.
CaseNotes: Larner has another Janet Daill from Moffat Dumfries listed with a Thomas Wilson the date of 16/7/1661.  I didn't find these cases.
PretrialNotes: She ratified her confession in front of two groups of witnesses.

Charnotes: He was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady Fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheritance of land, titles, and property.
FolkNotes: He was sent to the Egyptians to get poison for Lady Ross. He was paid 8 shillings and some cloth.
DiseaseNotes: Was sent to Egyptians to get poison.  He supposedly bought poison in Tain, Ross and Elgin.
PostTrialNotes: Mentioned in a later trial that he had been burnt.

Charnotes: He was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady Fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheritance of land, titles, and property.

Notes: JC26/27/1 item 10, says she was 34 years old.
DevilNotes: Went to him because of her poverty.  Received a stone from the Devil.  Had pain after receiving the mark.  Said his nature was cold after sex.
TrialNotes: The whole high court went out to Musselburgh with the Book of Adjournal.

Notes: Confessed to making a pact with the Devil 13 years before, and said he was carrying coal to Edinburgh when he met the Devil.
DevilNotes: Got the mark when the Devil put his finger on his leg.
PretrialNotes: He was interrogated in the tolbooth of Musselburgh on 19/7/1661 and then he confessed again.  On 28/7/1661 he said he only confessed because he was put in a 'haircloath' that he knew nothing of witchcraft, but that he wouldn't deny his confession in court.
TrialNotes: The whole central justiciary went there with the Books of Adjournal.

Notes: Reputation for one year,  pre-trial notes gave her age.
DevilNotes: Strange one; the Devil wanted her to keep his house because his previous wife had died. He gave her silver which turned into stone.  She denied having a mark although they found one on her.  She confessed to getting paid for her service to the Devil.
MeetingNotes: Said there were many other 'masked folkes' there.
DiseaseNotes: denied committing any malefice

DevilNotes: Met the Devil in the house of a friend who introduced them, they all shared a cup of ale.
DiseaseNotes: Said she had committed no malefice
PretrialNotes: Must have been moved from Edmestoun to Musselburgh sometime before 29/7/1661 the date of her second confession and trial.
TrialNotes: Trial took place in Musselburgh, but in the High Court, they took the Books of Adjournal out to Musselburgh.

Charnotes: She was denounced by Elspet Millar and Grissel Scot from Newton (c/la/2799, c/la/2800)
DevilNotes: Received money from the Devil, which disappeared when he left (around 40 pennies).

Charnotes: She was denounced by Elspet Millar and Grissel Scot from Newton (c/la/2799, c/la/2800)
DevilNotes: Received money from the Devil, which disappeared when he left (around 40 pennies).

Charnotes: May have confessed to demonic pact.
DevilNotes: She retracted all this stuff that she had originally confessed.

Charnotes: May have confessed to demonic pact.
DevilNotes: She retracted all this stuff that she had originally confessed.
PretrialNotes: Commission issued after some in the group had confessed to pact and renunciation of baptism. Others were still only suspected of the crime. Accused appealed for release from prison in 1/1662.

Charnotes: Hard to tell what was going on, but a lot of devil stuff.  She was delated by Jonet Watson (c/egd/365)
DevilNotes: The Devil appeared when she was angry with her son.  She spoke with the Devil in the form of a black dog at the mill while her daughter was there.  The devil kissed her and called her buntein (buntin = plump, short, dumpy).
MeetingNotes: The meeting at the dam was supposedly on the 'last beal fire night' meaning Beltane.  Confession document has some descriptions of these meetings.
FolkNotes: Definite fairy things here: Devil in green clothes and a witches meeting on Beltane night.

Charnotes: Hard to tell what was going on, but a lot of devil stuff.  She was delated by Jonet Watson (c/egd/365)
DevilNotes: The Devil appeared when she was angry with her son.  She spoke with the Devil in the form of a black dog at the mill while her daughter was there.  The devil kissed her and called her buntein (buntin = plump, short, dumpy).
MeetingNotes: The meeting at the dam was supposedly on the 'last beal fire night' meaning Beltane.  Confession document has some descriptions of these meetings.
FolkNotes: Definite fairy things here: Devil in green clothes and a witches meeting on Beltane night.
PretrialNotes: She confessed to everything but renouncing her baptism.  She confessed repeatedly was witnessed by her son, and confronted by her daughter for meeting with the Devil in the shape of a dog.  She also confessed to contemplating suicide on 18/7/1661.  Very detailed confession information.
TrialNotes: This was a High Court of Justiciary trial held in Dalkeith.  The substitute advocate and the Books of Adjournal were brought out to Dalkeith.
PostTrialNotes: ordered to be executed between 2 and 4 in the afternoon

Notes: Reputation for 40 years, but JC26/27/9 said she was 71 years old.  Used to live at the stemare in Liberton Parish, but I think she moved to Dalkeith.
Charnotes: I think that under questioning, etc. she retold an fornication or adultery episode as a meeting with the Devil. The accusations made to the KS include verbal threats against her neighbours and her own son.
DevilNotes: William Twedie, the Devil, gave her a pair of black gloves.  She denied that Devil laid with her.  There were two William Tweedies, her landlord and his evil half brother.  Some confusion, she confessed to having an affair with the half brother who fled to 'Irland'  this person was always present when the met the Devil and the Devil didn't appear after he had left.  I he morphed into the Devil for her.
DiseaseNotes: Seems to have threatened her neighbours. Told them they would be poor, their horse took ill and they were reduced to poverty. Also angry about her son and told his wife he would have a bad homecoming. On his return he took ill and died.
CaseNotes: She may have gotten caught up in the witch panic because she was already a accused of fornication and adultery.  The Devil as william twedie could likely be a re-telling of an adulterous affair.  Also, she used to live in Liberton Parish, so that maybe the connection between the Dalkeith and Liberton witches?  Fergusson denounced a few Dalkeith people, that may have started the chain?
PretrialNotes: KS investigate accusations. She initially denied them and said she wanted to be searched for the mark (to prove her innocence?). Marks found. She was then recorded as being a 'confessing witch' so must have made a confession after this.
PostTrialNotes: ordered to be executed between 2 and 4 in the afternoon

DevilNotes: This same information is in the JC2 and JC26/27/9 item 5.
This same information is in the JC2 and JC26/27/9 item 5.
PretrialNotes: She was exhorted for days by William Scot and William Calderwood.
PostTrialNotes: ordered to be executed between 2 and 4 in the afternoon

DiseaseNotes: threatened that a woman would remain childless; confessed to killing her brother saying that she was worthy of death for that reason, fall outs, cursing, death
CaseNotes: The main issue in her case was that she killed her brother, for which she expressed extreme remorse and thought she should die (lots of witnesses testified to this).  She seemed to have lived with her brother at the time, more likely she lived just next door, perhaps in a semi-attached kind of house.  She had many conflicts within her immediate family, her brother and a nephew.
PretrialNotes: She mostly confessed to having killed her brother, but it doesn’t seem to have been through witchcraft?  She tried to flee but failed.  Janet Cock's first trial (c/egd/409) says that Wilsone was brought to Niddry to confront other suspects on 10/6/1661.
TrialNotes: Her trial was a High Court trial held in Dalkeith, the Books of Adjournal, and the substitute to his majesty's advocate, were brought out to Dalkeith.  A pre-trial 'report' lists a commission from the Committee of Estates for her trial, but she wasn't tried under that commission, don't know why.
PostTrialNotes: ordered to be executed between 2 and 4 in the afternoon

DiseaseNotes: threatened that a woman would remain childless; confessed to killing her brother saying that she was worthy of death for that reason, fall outs, cursing, death
CaseNotes: The main issue in her case was that she killed her brother, for which she expressed extreme remorse and thought she should die (lots of witnesses testified to this).  She seemed to have lived with her brother at the time, more likely she lived just next door, perhaps in a semi-attached kind of house.  She had many conflicts within her immediate family, her brother and a nephew.

Charnotes: its all about the Devil
DevilNotes: the Devil changed from a beast to man to get into bed with her.  The draft dittay says she saw the Devil in her own house as a man with a meikle headed body.  Very detailed confession concerning sex with the Devil.
PostTrialNotes: ordered to be executed between 2 and 4 in the afternoon

Notes: She was described as having left her 'pock' in the house of a family that appear to have been colliers, and then angrily retrieved it.  This could mean she was storing something, or that she was a beggar?
Charnotes: Her charges seem to have stemmed from disputes about her pock with her neighbours.  She also had disputes about the death of her cat, and she seemed to have been a midwife, but it was the disputes that seem to be the crux.  In her confession she was interrogated about her midwife practices, but she said there was no ill in them.  She was delated by Issobel Fergusson
DevilNotes: Someone testified that they saw a strange cat standing on its hind legs (implying that it was Beatrix).
FolkNotes: After a quarrel about Beatrix storing a pock in the house of William Young and Agnes his wife, they tried to appease her with ale. She drank but wouldn't speak. Later Beatrix ,as an apparition cat, attacked him, and their children were hurt in the coal pit.  She said that after meeting the devil she was frequently carried in her sleep to the company of many brave souls.  She practised definite rituals in midwifery. She stuck a baro knife between the bed and the straw and sprinkled salt and saying words.
DiseaseNotes: Quarrelled and cursed, harm followed. The two wifes that suffered harm had also killed Beatrix's cat. The coal pit collapsed  The deaths were in revenge for killing her cat.  Tried to heal her cow by rubbing a sick woman's shirt on it.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Burned down a house
DefenseNotes: She claimed that the Devil never promised her anything and that she was prone to fits of madness.
CaseNotes: She was accused of causing death through the collapse of the coal pit.  She must have lived near the pit and been a part of the pit community?
PretrialNotes: Confessed to everything except renouncing her baptism.
PostTrialNotes: ordered to be executed between 2 and 4 in the afternoon

Notes: Joined Devil 11 years before, 25+11=36.
DevilNotes: Devil gave her £12 while she was gathering sticks, but it turned into stone.  She confessed that the Devil rang a bell to call her.
MeetingNotes: They had a meeting while she was gathering sticks.
PostTrialNotes: to be executed at Gilmerton, between 2 and 4 in the afternoon

DevilNotes: Devil came in black clothes like a gentleman, and looked like her husband.
PostTrialNotes: to be executed at Gilmerton, between 2 and 4 in the afternoon

DevilNotes: Devil came in black clothes like a gentleman, and looked like her husband.
Put her hand on her head.
MeetingNotes: She confessed that the meeting happened around 10:00pm in Gilmerton ward with 40 other masked people.
PostTrialNotes: to be executed at Gilmerton, between 2 and 4 in the afternoon

DevilNotes: Devil appeared to him at night while he was in bed. He was described as lying upon him heavy in the shape of a man.
PostTrialNotes: to be executed at Gilmerton, between 2 and 4 in the afternoon

DiseaseNotes: Became angry when her husband sold a cow.
PostTrialNotes: to be executed at Gilmerton, between 2 and 4 in the afternoon

Charnotes: She was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheretance of land, titles, and property
FolkNotes: Said by Ross to have used wax/clay images to cause harm.

Charnotes: She was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheretance of land, titles, and property
FolkNotes: Said by Ross to have used wax/clay images to cause harm.

DevilNotes: The Devil bade her remove something unreadable, probably an item of clothing.  She found his nature cold.
PretrialNotes: In her trial confession, she said she had been free of the Devil for 13 weeks and did not know he was the Devil till after she had sex with him.
PostTrialNotes: to be executed at Gilmerton, between 2 and 4 in the afternoon

Notes: Larner had her from Liberton/Duddingston. Others accused associated with her were from Liberton so it is likely she was from there as well.
Larner had her from Liberton/Duddingston. Others accused associated with her were from Liberton so it is likely she was from there as well.
PretrialNotes: In her confession her meetings with the Devil turned into possibly being men she encountered in daily life.
TrialNotes: She did not confess anything on 7/8/1661.

Charnotes: Pact confessed but few other details
DevilNotes: Devil as man lay down with her and he was as heavy as a millstone. He offered her money which she did not receive.
PretrialNotes: There may have been a central trial, process notes include her confession.

Charnotes: Pact confessed but few other details
DevilNotes: Devil as man lay down with her and he was as heavy as a millstone. He offered her money which she did not receive.

Notes: Husband was tailor
DevilNotes: Accused of having carnal copulation with the devil and abusing her body, which should have been a 'temple to the Holy Ghost'. The devil gave her a dollar which later turned out to be 'sklait stone. The appearance of the devil is not described.
MeetingNotes: The devil told her to meet with him and her neighbours.
PretrialNotes: Note about confession in process notes

Notes: May have been from Duddingston as witnesses to confession included the minister. Also recorded as Robertson, and may be related to Jonet Robeson (c/egd/531)
Charnotes: Pact confessed but few other details of charges.
DevilNotes: Devil was cold to touch. Met him at 11 am.
PretrialNotes: May have been central trial as confession included in process notes. No torture used.

Notes: May have been from Duddingston as witnesses to confession included the minister. Also recorded as Robertson, and may be related to Jonet Robeson (c/egd/531)
Charnotes: Pact confessed but few other details of charges.
DevilNotes: Devil was cold to touch. Met him at 11 am.
Devil arose out of the water at Tweedsyde and helped her over it for a meeting.
MeetingNotes: Meeting between 11 and 12 at night at the 'green dykes'.  This could be a ditch or a turf boundary wall (more likely the latter).  Also met the Devil when she was coming from Edinburgh through the park.

DevilNotes: Devil arose out of the water at Tweedsyde and helped her over it for a meeting.
MeetingNotes: Meeting between 11 and 12 at night at the 'green dykes'.  This could be a ditch or a turf boundary wall (more likely the latter).  Also met the Devil when she was coming from Edinburgh through the park.
PretrialNotes: Confronted Issobell Ramsay (c/egd/402).
TrialNotes: She confessed, so very little other information.  The assize was mostly from Edinburgh not her locality.
PostTrialNotes: taken back to Wester Duddingston for execution

Notes: Accused of having caused harm 26 years before (25+26=51). Also meeting with the devil 5 years before. Recorded as having been named as witch in 1650.
Charnotes: Seems to have had a reputation and people wanted to stay away from her, unclear why. With so many witnesses and disputes over land it is possible that this was a neighbourhood dispute.
MeetingNotes: A group of witches blew up a locked door and wanted to take a woman's new born baby during her lying in period, but they had no power and left in confusion.
FolkNotes: Accused of using orations to make Mungo Steill ill, but no description. Met the devil at dusk. Went down on her knees and cursed a man.
DiseaseNotes: Dispute over entitlement (tailzie) of a piece of land. Threatened man who later took ill. Two animals died after man refused to sell her a sheep or a horse.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused of using charms, sorcery and witchcraft
PretrialNotes: High Court ordered her to be moved back to kirkListon for her trial, because it was too difficult to get the witnesses and assize members to Edinburgh, 19 July 1661.  The ministers and elders of kirkliston ordered to appear in Edinburgh 13 august 1661.  Then she appears in Edinburgh for her trial.  She denied all charges at her trial.  She confessed to the minister and kirk session of Kirkliston.  Robert Wilson told her to confess and she wouldn't be tortured.
TrialNotes: She was tried with a random group from a different area.  The assize was mostly from Edinburgh, not from Kirkliston. Although another document lists several from Kirkliston, Winchburgh, Ingliston. There was an order for a trial for 20/9/1661 which may never have happened.

Notes: Name recorded a number of different ways. Thomas McAnemoir McAllan McHenrik. Peter Maxwell Stuart had him as McKane.
Charnotes: He was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady Fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheritance of land, titles, and property

Notes: Name recorded a number of different ways. Thomas McAnemoir McAllan McHenrik. Peter Maxwell Stuart had him as McKane.
Charnotes: He was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady Fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheritance of land, titles, and property

Notes: Reputation for 40 years (40+25=65).  Lots of people testified to her reputation for witchcraft.  Husband was a reader.
Charnotes: Denounced under oath by Jannet Ker and Marjorie Fairwell.  Confessed pact with devil
DevilNotes: She sent three cats to someone's house to make noise and cause illness. The devil promised her money. Devil took her in his arms ?sexual implication.
FolkNotes: A male victim suffering from pains like child birth and swelling went to a English doctor in Leith,  who declared that he was bewitched.  New charges in second restatement of trial.  Her master Andro Lauder and his wife asked if she had fallen out with anyone. Disease was taken off and moved to a cat, there was a cold wind when the cat died.
DiseaseNotes: A piece of raw flesh was found under a male victims loom after he chased Hutchison off his land, which when cast in the fire caused a loud noise and the death of his cat.  Aflicted a whole household after a competition between male head and her husband.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Caused a man to have pains like a women in child birth.  Suffocated a new born child at midnight when she was in apparition form after appearing for 8 nights.  Tried to kill a woman who wouldn't return her cauldron, but killed her dog by mistake.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused of harming people and goods by using charms, sorcery and witchcraft.
DefenseNotes: No words or deeds. Defence argued relevancy of accusations: witchcraft or nature.

Notes: Reputation for 40 years (40+25=65).  Lots of people testified to her reputation for witchcraft.  Husband was a reader.
Charnotes: Denounced under oath by Jannet Ker and Marjorie Fairwell.  Confessed pact with devil
DevilNotes: She sent three cats to someone's house to make noise and cause illness. The devil promised her money. Devil took her in his arms ?sexual implication.
FolkNotes: A male victim suffering from pains like child birth and swelling went to a English doctor in Leith,  who declared that he was bewitched.  New charges in second restatement of trial.  Her master Andro Lauder and his wife asked if she had fallen out with anyone. Disease was taken off and moved to a cat, there was a cold wind when the cat died.
DiseaseNotes: A piece of raw flesh was found under a male victims loom after he chased Hutchison off his land, which when cast in the fire caused a loud noise and the death of his cat.  Aflicted a whole household after a competition between male head and her husband.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Caused a man to have pains like a women in child birth.  Suffocated a new born child at midnight when she was in apparition form after appearing for 8 nights.  Tried to kill a woman who wouldn't return her cauldron, but killed her dog by mistake.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused of harming people and goods by using charms, sorcery and witchcraft.
DefenseNotes: No words or deeds. Defence argued relevancy of accusations: witchcraft or nature.
PretrialNotes: Denied all charges.  When she was tortured. She told people to beware, 'she had gotten her heart will on'. A few observers later died.
TrialNotes: The assize was ordered to reappear on the 27/8/1661 to read their verdict again.  Unclear why, maybe they were supposed to change their verdict?  They were mostly from Edinburgh, not her locality.  The first verdict from the trial was not guilty, the second verdict on 10/9/1661 was guilty. (see second trial for details)
PostTrialNotes: The verdict was still disputed. The assize was ordered to appear on 10/9/1661 to give the verdict.  She was to be executed between 3-4pm in Wester Duddingston

Notes: Reputation for 40 years (40+25=65).  Lots of people testified to her reputation for witchcraft.  Husband was a reader.
Charnotes: Denounced under oath by Jannet Ker and Marjorie Fairwell.  Confessed pact with devil
DevilNotes: She sent three cats to someone's house to make noise and cause illness. The devil promised her money. Devil took her in his arms ?sexual implication.
FolkNotes: A male victim suffering from pains like child birth and swelling went to a English doctor in Leith,  who declared that he was bewitched.  New charges in second restatement of trial.  Her master Andro Lauder and his wife asked if she had fallen out with anyone. Disease was taken off and moved to a cat, there was a cold wind when the cat died.
DiseaseNotes: A piece of raw flesh was found under a male victims loom after he chased Hutchison off his land, which when cast in the fire caused a loud noise and the death of his cat.  Aflicted a whole household after a competition between male head and her husband.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Caused a man to have pains like a women in child birth.  Suffocated a new born child at midnight when she was in apparition form after appearing for 8 nights.  Tried to kill a woman who wouldn't return her cauldron, but killed her dog by mistake.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused of harming people and goods by using charms, sorcery and witchcraft.
DefenseNotes: No words or deeds. Defence argued relevancy of accusations: witchcraft or nature.
TrialNotes: The charges from previous trial were added on. New witness statements were produced.  Basically the same assize, brought back for a new trial.  Sentencing was on 11/9/1661.
PostTrialNotes: To be executed in Wester Duddingston, and maintained by the locality in a competent manner till then.

Notes: Devil appeared as her husband.  She seems to have travelled a lot to and from Edinburgh.  Daughter testified against her.
Charnotes: Demonic pact featured in detail although malefice also important.
DevilNotes: Devil gave her a sixpence which she used to buy meal.  Probably sex implied because the Devil supposedly appeared to her in her bed in the likeness of her husband. Gave her a dollar which she said later turned to 'sklait stane'. She denied that she had renounced her baptism.
FolkNotes: Appeasement was tried but failed. Claimed by witness that a cat (?Ramsay) appeared 3 times in his house and that later 2 of his boys died and his wife was ill for 26 weeks.
DiseaseNotes: A youngish girl dropped her' kitt' on Ramsay's brow causing a headache. Ramsay cursed the girl, whose mother tried to reconcile with Ramsay, but failed. The girl was blown over by a blast of wind and lost the power of her hand.
OtherChargesNotes: By 'charmes and malifices' she caused the death of many people.

Notes: Devil appeared as her husband.  She seems to have travelled a lot to and from Edinburgh.  Daughter testified against her.
Charnotes: Demonic pact featured in detail although malefice also important.
DevilNotes: Devil gave her a sixpence which she used to buy meal.  Probably sex implied because the Devil supposedly appeared to her in her bed in the likeness of her husband. Gave her a dollar which she said later turned to 'sklait stane'. She denied that she had renounced her baptism.
FolkNotes: Appeasement was tried but failed. Claimed by witness that a cat (?Ramsay) appeared 3 times in his house and that later 2 of his boys died and his wife was ill for 26 weeks.
DiseaseNotes: A youngish girl dropped her' kitt' on Ramsay's brow causing a headache. Ramsay cursed the girl, whose mother tried to reconcile with Ramsay, but failed. The girl was blown over by a blast of wind and lost the power of her hand.
OtherChargesNotes: By 'charmes and malifices' she caused the death of many people.
PretrialNotes: She confessed only to having received the money which then turned to stone. Confronted by Jonet Ker (c/egd/398) who confirmed she met Ramsay at meetings.
TrialNotes: Her daughter testified against her, saying that when she told her mother that people thought she had caused supernatural harm, her mother replied 'so I did and will ever doe'.  Ker confronted her saying she saw her at a meeting on the green dyke and 'knew her be her face and be her speich'.  The assize was mostly from Edinburgh not her locality.
PostTrialNotes: Taken back to Wester Duddingston for execution.

Notes: Larner had her from Liberton/Duddingston. Others involved came from Liberton so she was probably from there as well.
MeetingNotes: Taken to a meeting in the hills, by a whirl wind.  She masked herself at her meeting and was assigned a certain number of a malifices.

Notes: Larner had her from Liberton/Duddingston. Others involved came from Liberton so she was probably from there as well.
MeetingNotes: Taken to a meeting in the hills, by a whirl wind.  She masked herself at her meeting and was assigned a certain number of a malifices.
PretrialNotes: Her dittay was included with 12 other indictments, some of whom had trials recorded in the Books of Adjournal, but hers wasn't.  It is unclear why, perhaps it was because she was 'not present' on the day this dittay was dated?

Charnotes: Her case doesn't even seem to a real case.  She hints that she is only guilty of having sex with several different men.  She claims they weren't the Devil and she didn't renounce her baptism or become anyone's servant.
DevilNotes: Said that she had sex with someone three times.  She claimed it was not the Devil but Henry Bear.  But she said he was cold the first two times.  She said she heard a bee and a butterfly. She refused to be the Devil's servant.  Unclear, very vague pact stuff.
TrialNotes: She is listed on the same date and place as a group trial, but for some reason her case was not presented to an assize at this time.

Notes: Confessed to being with the Devil for 22 years, 25+22=47.
CaseNotes: She was ordered released from prison on caution not to use charms, sorcery or witchcraft again.

Notes: Confessed to being with the Devil for 22 years, 25+22=47.
CaseNotes: She was ordered released from prison on caution not to use charms, sorcery or witchcraft again.
TrialNotes: She was ordered to be set free from jail under the condition that she uses no charms, sorcery or witchcraft on 6/9/1661.

Notes: Possibly from Gilmerton or Liberton.
Charnotes: Some information about quarrelling with neighbours over borrowed money, and working conditions.
DevilNotes: Devil promised her all the pleasure in the world.
CaseNotes: She was ordered released from prison on caution not to use charms, sorcery or witchcraft again.
PretrialNotes: She was lumped in with a group trial in the preliminary drafts of 7/8/1661, but a side note says that her charges didn't go to an assize.  No idea why?  Perhaps it was because she didn't confess on 7/8/1661, saying that 'great oppression' made her confess before.
TrialNotes:
She was in an earlier version of a Books of Adjournal entry as not passing to the assize, presumably the charges were dropped.
She was ordered to be set free from jail under the condition that she used no charmes, sorcery or witchcraft on 6/9/1661.  2 women and 2 men gave in evidence against her pre-trial.

Notes: Reputation for 24 years (24+25=49).  The first trial was all about disputes, the second trial has more information about healing, but still mostly disputes.
Charnotes: She was a party to several healing attempts that transferred the disease on to a child and a dog.  She was not the main person, but an assistant.  In second trial she appears more of a healer, turning up when people were ill (or bewitched by a different witch) and offering a diagnosis and cure.  Neighbourhood dispute is the dominant trend. 2 violent altercations between Janet and her accusers are described in the 2nd trial.
DevilNotes: Devil went away from her in whirl of wind.
FolkNotes: After a horse fell ill, 'a country man' said that if they put the horses' shoes in a red hot fire and took them out, the bewitcher would appear if it was witchcraft, then Janet Cock showed up without a pretext.  When Janet Cock appeared above a new mother and her child, the new mother said 'the spirit of grace be in this house' and the witches and devil disappeared.
DiseaseNotes: Tried to steal a new baby while mother was lying in.  Helped another witch transfer a disease from a child to a dog. Left a dish of blood and the dog was found decapitated. Her curses included: 'O! thame that called me a witch' and 'what rakis robin'
OtherMaleficiaNotes: In second trial, she was described as a 'skilled woman' in relation to healing and diagnosis of disease.  Diagnosed with 'gripping' and prescribed cures.  She cured a cold and colic using 'black wool', garlic and aqua vitae, and forbade prayer.
CaseNotes: First trial she was acquitted, second trial convicted.  The make up of the assize in first trial was 7 from Edinburgh, 1 from Canongate, 7 from Dalkeith.  For the second trial it was 6 from Edinburgh, 1 from Canongate, 8 from Dalkieth - giving the Dalkeithers a swing vote.  The first chancellor was from Edinburgh, the second from Dalkeith.  Someone wanted her to be found guilty and changed the jury by just one person.
PretrialNotes: William Scot was ordered by the High Court when it was sitting in Dalkeith to take her to Edinburgh tolbooth on 9/8/1661.  On 20/8/1661, Scot and Calderwood ordered to get the witnesses ready for her trial.  Trial date was reset for 10/9/1661. She was ordered to pay six pence perday for maintenance till her trial.  She confronted Margaret Grintoun in Gilmerton 14/8/ 1661.  After her not guilty verdict she petitioned the Privy Council to be released from prison. The petition was denied because the minister at Dalkeith had more charges pending.
TrialNotes: She was not released from prison after her trial.  7/9 and 9/9  witnesses were called from Dalkeith (a lot of these people appeared in other Dalkeith trials as well).  Defence witnesses called on 10/9/1661.

PretrialNotes: She was called up to the kirk session of Dalkeith for drunken behaviour on 22/1/1645.  Her two daughters petitioned for her release from prison.
TrialNotes: Doom pronounced on 12/11/1661. The PC ordered that she be tried on the new charges in their response to a request from Janet to be released from prison after her first trial's verdict of not guilty.  New witnesses were called on 9/11/1661.
PostTrialNotes: Taken to the usual place of execution in Dalkeit. The day was a Tuesday., between 10 and 2 in the afternoon.  William Scot, bailie was ordered to carry out the sentence.

CaseNotes: The project did not check Larner's reference to this printed secondary source as part of the research.

Charnotes: She was known as a notorious witch.  She was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady Fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheretance of land, titles, and property.
FolkNotes: She provided Lady Fowlis with elfshot.

Notes: She seems to have worked for the laird of Newhall and stayed in his house, but one item in the draft dittay describes someone buying land possessed by her husband.  Unclear socio-econ status.
DevilNotes: Devil gave her a kiss.  A servant saw a black man go into Margaret's room and he moved around like he had oxen feet.
MeetingNotes: Haddington was written first and then crossed out and replaced with Hodin dean two words.
DiseaseNotes: She was described as being 'like dead' when her victims suffered a trembling and sweating ailment.
CaseNotes: Strange one: the prosecutor was a local laird, who dropped the prosecution in exchange for banishment.
PretrialNotes: 15/8/1661, she denied that she confessed or did any malifice.  20/8/1661 she appeared in High Court, trial was set for 27/8/1661.  The trial was reset for 10/9/1661. Bannatyne ordered to pay her maintenance.  A dittay from 14/11/1661 survives.
TrialNotes: The prosecutor agreed to drop the prosecution if Allan agreed to be on 'good behaviour' and to never enter the bounds of Newhall again.

CaseNotes: Larner et al., 'Source-book' listed this case (#407) as being from JC26/27.  However, the 'Survey' looked through this box and did not find the case.  Larner has this case as mentioned as a witch in someone else's trial.  That means we do not have a trial record for this person.

Charnotes: Denounced by Margaret Greive
PretrialNotes: She was listed (with an indictment) in a draft dittay of 12 people, some of whom had trials recorded in the Books of Adjournal.  She did not. Unclear why.  She is described in her confession as old and sick, perhaps she died before trial?

CaseNotes: The project was unable to locate the source mentioned by Larner at the NAS so were unable to check it. We doubt that it even exists.

Notes: Her husband was a dagmaker - maker of guns.
PretrialNotes: To be tried by the magistrates of Edinburgh and bailies of Canongate.  She was in prison by at least 10/1661.

Notes: Larner had her from Liberton/Duddingston.
Larner had her from Liberton/Duddingston.
The prolocutors in defence were earls and lords.
Charnotes: She and her husband were charged with consulting four witches after a dispute over a davoch of land.
CaseNotes: A process note from 12/7/1590 indicates that they were charged with consulting.
TrialNotes: Trial was ordered by the High Court to be held in the next justice aire in the Sheriffdom of Aberdeen.  The entry in the High Court was for 19/8/1590.  A group of earls and lairds were prolocutors in the defence.

Notes: Larner queried that she was from Gilmerton.

Notes: The entry in JC26/2 index says Cromar
FolkNotes: South-running well.  She supposedly had a kist full of men's secret members made of clay.
DiseaseNotes: Made an enchantment for a woman to put in her master's meat.
CaseNotes: She was mentioned in a process note about Leslie and Achinleck on 12/7/1590.  The same people were involved in the prosecutions.
PretrialNotes: Summons against her on 23/7/1590. She was fugitive and her husband was ordered to get her to report for trial. She appeared later for her trial.

Notes: This name was recorded as Cowie but it is Bowie

Charnotes: All of the accusations against her revolved around business type dealings, land, borrowing money, payments in kind.  She seemed to have been suspected of witchcraft after many convicted witches accused her. The accusations were believable because of quarrels followed by harm.  Many documents mention her common repute as a witch.  She was previously denounced in 1649 with no mention of what happened there.  She was denounced by James Welch sometime before 1662. Petition to parliament from Earl of Haddington. He claimed that witchcraft was increasing in his lands and had imprisoned the suspects. He also claimed that two of them were accused of robbery as well.
DevilNotes: Accused of giving her newly born baby to the Devil and claiming that it had died in childbirth.  Confessed that she became a witch after discord with her husband.
MeetingNotes: Welch denounced her for being at a meeting at Haddington mill, and being at a meeting to destroy someone with two wisps at a barn door.
FolkNotes: Her husband offered ale to one of her accusers.
DiseaseNotes: She was heard to say 'a ha, a ha' before killing a horse by taking a piece of flesh the size of a golf ball out of its mouth and leaving pieces of flesh that looked like tobacco pipes nearby. She possibly deliberately aborted her pregnancy.
DefenseNotes: No acts alleged
CaseNotes: Part of the large number of people denounced by James Welch.  He was deemed too young to stand trial so he was imprisoned.  But his confession and some of his denunciations were taken seriously by the authorities.

PretrialNotes: She confessed to Judges Commissionate on 20/5/1661. Someone drew up a memorandum outlining the case in 1662. The confession was disputed and presented as extrajudicial.  Earl of Haddington said she was a burden to his tenents while awaiting trial, presumably because they had to watch and ward her.  She is also listed in process notes in the Privy Council from 1649
TrialNotes:
Found her not guilty of the substantive charges, but guilty 'by repute and delation'. On 28/1/1662, justice was postponed until 3/2/1662.  We have the trial text in JC2 (i.e. High Court Books of Adjournal) and in draft form in JC26/28.
The rest of the group were not tried with her at the High Court - they may have had a local trial.

Notes: Described as a poor begging boy.  He was a minor so couldn't be tried.  I estimate his age at 15 on the assumption that 16 was when minor status ended.
Charnotes: He was a young boy who confessed to over 15 meetings with witches and the Devil and delated around 90 people.  His confessions involved the Devil and were most likely produced as the result of pressure exerted by the interrogators.
DevilNotes: Brought to the Devil by his mother and his good dame - grandmother  Doesn’t way what their names were.
MeetingNotes: The first meeting at Haddington mill he just saw and it was after that he claimed he was brought to the Devil.  Didn't say where the second meeting was, but he was brought by his mother and good dame.  He confessed to drinking ale and wine at some meetings and eating meat.
CaseNotes: He denounced about 90 people from East Lothian sometime in 1661.
PretrialNotes: He confessed and delated 85 people sometime in 1661.  Was moved from Haddington to Edinburgh in 16/1/1662.  He confessed again before the Presbytery of Edinburgh. They deemed him too young to stand trial, his case was eventually decided in April.
TrialNotes: deemed too young for a trial, so was sentenced to be held in a correction house for a year and a day on 17/4/1662

Notes: Nurse to the Laird of Boquhane, is this a wet nurse?  She was picking lint with other women.  She had been living with a man for 12 years, he was perhaps her common law husband.  She was a servant to Leslie and Achinleck who consulted her for witchcraft.
DevilNotes: She was accused of stealing gold and gold jewellery from her employer, the Laird of Balquhene (John Leslie).  She claimed that the Devil gave them to her.
FolkNotes: She did some kind of charm with a compass in the earth.  Three worms came out of a hole in the middle of the compass, a big one, a little one and then a big one that died.  She interpreted this as a man, his unknown infant in the womb, and his wife who would die of childbirth, and she did.
DiseaseNotes: Took away a woman's milk in order to prevent her from being a wet nurse.  She had a grudge against a particular family.
CaseNotes: Mentioned in a process note about Leslie and Achinleck.
PretrialNotes: Summons against her on 23/7/1590, but she was fugitive at that time. Later appeared for trial.

Notes: A lot of family connections here.

CaseNotes: She was hired to kill someone.

Notes: Said he was a 'charmer'.
Mentioned as being from Cromar ?Cromarty.  Within the parish of coucht (?).  Parish is definitely called Cromar.
DevilNotes: Raising the Devil
DiseaseNotes: Destroyed the wife and kids of a man she committed adultery with.  Went to a bog in Cultis to heal herself.  She 'witched' people to death=bewitchment.  Lots of slaughter, incuding a young laird
CaseNotes: Mentioned in a process note about Achinleck and Leslie.  Same people involved in her trial as theirs.  Charged with adultery previously.
PretrialNotes: summons against her on 23/7/1590, she was fugitive and her husband was ordered to bring her to trial.
TrialNotes: listed on a High Court index for 22/7/1590

Notes: The documents says lx (but very badly written)
DevilNotes: A meikle black man met her on the road between Dalkeith and Edinestoune when she was carrying the sark of a dying child.  This was at 12:00am.
FolkNotes: this one is very badly written, seems to be telling the same story about a bairn in blanket brought into a barn.  But I can't make it out.  She made a drink out of mugword and Mynt
DiseaseNotes: murdering of twa infant bairns, took the milk away from cows.
TrialNotes: She was questioned on 14/4/1590, questioned again on 20/4/1590

Charnotes: Denounced by James Welch.
MeetingNotes: Was accused by James Welch of being at 3 meetings with the Devil - West Kill of Haddington, Lethair Burn and Kirkyard of Haddington on 5/9/1659. No details from Blyth herself.
CaseNotes: Part of the large number of people denounced by James Welch.  He was deemed too young to stand trial so he was imprisoned.  But his confession and some of his denunciations were taken seriously by the authorities.

Notes: He used to live in Tranent.
DevilNotes: The Devil appeared to him so he could get revenge on a guy for broken promises.  He claimed to have agreed to join the Devil for revenge.  He got the Devil's mark in bed, the devil struck him with a rod, he was then in 'grit extasies and transis', he was carried around to mountains.
MeetingNotes: He confessed to be carried along the water.  Satan stood as in a pulpit and preached sermons, some of which is quoted in the trial text.  They kissed the Devil's behind.  The Devil carried him across the see to the Queen's ship.  They travelled to a ship where they drank good wine and ale then went home.  He sat on the left side of the Devil and was lead about widdershins then kissed is arse.  Satan told them to collect all the cats, he was seen chasing cats.  Accused of dismembering unbaptised babies.  Supposedly a blue flame at the meeting.  See Agnes Sampson for a description fo the North Berwick kirk witches' meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more detials about the North Berwick meeting.
FolkNotes: Use of cats to raise winds to sink ships.  They took an object that looked like a fute-ball and cast it in the see to raise 'ane vapour and ane reik' to send the King's ship off.  He blew on a woman's hand to open a lock.  He lit a horse with candles, a magical thing.  He carried the mole's feet around as a talisman so that he wouldn't lack silver.  He walked withershins.  He could predict the future of when and how people would die if he knew their birth day.  Night flying.  Newes From Scotland, describes a foiled love magic attempt.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: The Devil persuaded him to burn down a house in revenge for not keeping a promise.
PretrialNotes: Newes From Scotland describes extreme toture being used against him - notably the bootes.

Notes: He used to live in Tranent.
DevilNotes: The Devil appeared to him so he could get revenge on a guy for broken promises.  He claimed to have agreed to join the Devil for revenge.  He got the Devil's mark in bed, the devil struck him with a rod, he was then in 'grit extasies and transis', he was carried around to mountains.
MeetingNotes: He confessed to be carried along the water.  Satan stood as in a pulpit and preached sermons, some of which is quoted in the trial text.  They kissed the Devil's behind.  The Devil carried him across the see to the Queen's ship.  They travelled to a ship where they drank good wine and ale then went home.  He sat on the left side of the Devil and was lead about widdershins then kissed is arse.  Satan told them to collect all the cats, he was seen chasing cats.  Accused of dismembering unbaptised babies.  Supposedly a blue flame at the meeting.  See Agnes Sampson for a description fo the North Berwick kirk witches' meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more detials about the North Berwick meeting.
FolkNotes: Use of cats to raise winds to sink ships.  They took an object that looked like a fute-ball and cast it in the see to raise 'ane vapour and ane reik' to send the King's ship off.  He blew on a woman's hand to open a lock.  He lit a horse with candles, a magical thing.  He carried the mole's feet around as a talisman so that he wouldn't lack silver.  He walked withershins.  He could predict the future of when and how people would die if he knew their birth day.  Night flying.  Newes From Scotland, describes a foiled love magic attempt.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: The Devil persuaded him to burn down a house in revenge for not keeping a promise.

Charnotes: Denounced by James Welch.
MeetingNotes: Was accused by James Welch of being at 3 meetings with the Devil - West Kill of Haddington, Lethair Burn and Kirkyard of Haddington on 5/9/1659. No details from Raeburn.
CaseNotes: Part of the large number of people denounced by James Welch.  He was deemed too young to stand trial so he was imprisoned.  But his confession and some of his denunciations were taken seriously by the authorities.

Notes: His father, Gilbert McGill was also executed in Haddington.
Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
DevilNotes: Others said he met the man as a 'mekle black man'.
MeetingNotes: See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more details about the North Berwick meeting. Said to have been at the meeting at the kirk in North Berwick where a trump was played.
FolkNotes: Said by others to have been involved in rituals using corpse and corpse powder and attended rituals at Halloween.
CaseNotes: There is a Johne Makgill from Garvald mentioned in Haddington Presbytery records as a suspect in 12/6/1588 but not clear if it is the same person. No further details,
PostTrialNotes: listed in Calandar of State Papers

Notes: There is a possible note about her in Dalkeith presbytery.
Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick hunt, that revovled around witchcraft and treason.  She was definitely a folk healer who got mixed up in the treason trials.  She implicated 59 people for witchcraft.  She was a folk healer who healed very high status people.
DevilNotes: Devil came to her after her husband died, she was moved by poverty and the chance for revenge.  At the time she thought the Devil's mark was a hurt she received from one of her children who was in bed with her.  In order to heal she called the Devil by the name of 'Elva' and he came as a dog.  The Devil carried a staff.  She confessed to these things in front of King James VI.  She denied that the spirits she met were the Devil.
MeetingNotes: One of the meetings was like a party at sea with good wine and ale.  She travelled over the water in a boat like a chimney and the Devil went before them in a ruk of hay.  They baptised a cat.  Witches meeting with nine people.  She described 11 separate witches meetings.  North Berwick meeting was a classic description of a black mass.  First there was dancing. The women payed homage, then the men.  The men walked withershins 9 times, the women 6 tymes.  Fean was the right hand man, Johnne Gray-meil guarded the door.  There were prayers, black candles and a whole service.  There were supposedly 6 men to 94 women at the meeting.  She also denied all the North Berwick stuff in a mega-confession.  Then later in the confession she talked about the North Berwick stuff (was she tortured?)
FolkNotes: Predicted someone's death.  She said the Devil was responsible for storms around Michaelmas and that they would continue.  Learned her healing from her father.  Gripping to cure.  She did lots of rituals with cats, passing them around and combining them with joints (dead people's).  They cast live cats into the sea, the cats swam out again.  Did a version of the Lord's Prayer, Ave Marias.  She was paid to heal very high status people (Lords, lairds, and their wives) from a large territory.  She prescribed an egg dipped in vinager, and one dipped in white wine, rubbed a patient with Aqua vitea.  Healed someone on Halloween.  She blessed a ring.
DiseaseNotes: She was accused of failing to heal many times.  Her range in healing was large, North Berwick, Direlton, Preston, Dalkeith.  She was hired by rich and poor people for healing.  She was paid for her services.  She helped ease the pain of childbirth.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Part of the witches' crew that wanted to destroy King James VI and Queen Ann of Denmark.  The Devil bad them party on a ship, but the mariners could not see them, the Devil raised wind and rocked the boat.  She confessed that she quarreled with J. Straton
CaseNotes: A copy of her confession was sent from Bowes to Burghley, in it he said that she confessed to 58 out of the 102 items in her dittay.  She died penitent and praying to God for her salvation.

CaseNotes: A copy of her confession was sent from Bowes to Burghley, in it he said that she confessed to 58 out of the 102 items in her dittay.  She died penitent and praying to God for her salvation.
PretrialNotes: Mega-confession where she denied the demonic elements and confessed to folk healing.  She denied all the North Berwick stuff, but eventually confessed to it, the questioning took place over a week, but the document is not in good condition and the date is destroyed.  She was confronted with other suspects on the 15 January but can't read the year, probably 1591.  She was confronted with Gellie Duncan and Jonat Campbel.
TrialNotes: described as convicted by an assize and 'brint' 28/1/1591 in calendar of State papers.
PostTrialNotes: The date was given in Calendar of State Papers.

OtherChargesNotes: Sorcery and charming listed on accusation but no details of what she was claimed to have done.
CaseNotes: Several entries in the Privy Council record the length of imprisonment and pleas from the accused to the PC to order a speedy trial or release her. More commissioners added to list in 1666. BD again appealed to PC in 1667 and commissioners were ordered to explain to PC why no trial had been held. 7/5/1667 she was eventually released and ordered to attend for trial when she was called.
PretrialNotes: Commission 12/1664 for local trial. Had been taken to Edinburgh for central trial but then returned to Stirling for local trial. Claimed that she was also held in Dunblane. Held in prison for over a year and she appealed to PC to order her trial or release. In 1666 further commission ordered trial to be held by 10/1666. 31/1/1667 Drummond again appealed to PC saying that her accusers had refused to attend the trial.  The high court books of adjournal deserted her diet and ordered the case remitted back to the locality.

OtherChargesNotes: Sorcery and charming listed on accusation but no details of what she was claimed to have done.
CaseNotes: Several entries in the Privy Council record the length of imprisonment and pleas from the accused to the PC to order a speedy trial or release her. More commissioners added to list in 1666. BD again appealed to PC in 1667 and commissioners were ordered to explain to PC why no trial had been held. 7/5/1667 she was eventually released and ordered to attend for trial when she was called.
TrialNotes: Diet was deserted by order of the Privy Council, and she was remitted to be tried in the place from which she came.

Notes: She is described as from the 'hielands and Isles'.
PretrialNotes: Commission granted by the Privy Council for the trial and punishing of witches in the Highlands and Isles.  She fled and is believed to be 'lurking mor about the citie of Edinburgh'.

Notes: He was born in 1607 (possibly), but described as about 70 when he died.  He was described as a 'tall, black man' with a staff.  He was born in Lanarkshire but moved to Edinburgh.
Charnotes: He was not accused of witchcraft at his High Court trial, but commentators after his death described him as a witch.
CaseNotes: Have not found evidence that he was actually tried for witchcraft.  He seems to have been tried for incest, adultery and beastiality. His sister was tried for withcraft, however.  Larner has transcribed a description of his life and death from The Fraser Manuscript, p. 307-312 in the National Library of Scotland, called 'a Collection of Providential Passages Antient and Modern Forreign and Domestick', dated 1670.  He is described as a warlock in this document - and there are vivid descriptions of his arrest and strange happenings with his possessions (his staff and two clouts that made dancing rings when burned).

Notes: Originally from Kirktown, lived most of her adult life in Dalkeith, keeping and teaching at a school.
Charnotes: I think she was investigated for the witchcraft, consulting and fairy contacts after the charge of incest was made public.
DevilNotes: She did not meet the devil as such, but dealt with a 'woman' described as most likely a spirit who was 'evidently the devil or a sorcerer'.
FolkNotes: The spirit woman offered to go to the queen of fairy to get help for Jean.  After receiving help from the woman who went to talk to the queen of fairy Jean was spinning and found a lot of money.
CaseNotes: Linked with the incest, bestiality and adultery charges launched at her brother.  He was convicted and executed.  But I found no mention of witchcraft in his trial transcript in JC2/13 f. 8v-9v.

TrialNotes: No pursuer so the diet was deserted, and all of her cautioners were freed from obligation.

CaseNotes: Larner et al., 'Source-book' listed this case (#579) as being from JC26/40.  However, the 'Survey' looked through this box and did not find the case.   The citation may be incorrect because the box seemed to contain information from 1671, not 1670. Larner has this case as being processed with an unknown outcome.
