Notes: She was twice widowed and accused of killing both of her husbands.
Charnotes: She was delated by two other known witches as having consulted them for the murdering of her husbands.  She supposedly received help with her charms for killer her husbands.
FolkNotes: On both accused killings she placed something under her then husband's bed.  For her first husband it was an piece of enchanted raw flesh.  For the second it was enchanted powder - the powder supposedly caused him to have problems in is 'privy parts' with burning.
DiseaseNotes: She was accused of bewitching her two husbands to death.  Accused of damaging a man's private parts with a powder.

Notes: I think she was accused by her daughter.
FolkNotes: Accused of using spells
TrialNotes: I think she was acquitted, it says 'Abs' next to her name.

Notes: She is from the parish of Redick (Redkirk or Rerrick?).
Charnotes: Mostly quarrelling and threats.  But, Janet Callen, executed for witchcraft in 1659, had lived with Elspeth and supposedly left holes in her hearth stone.  This could have played a part in her developing witch reputation.  Interesting reference to Thomsone being upset at not getting an invitation to a baptism (very much like Sleeping Beauty).
DevilNotes: A delerious man claimed to have seen the Devil as a rat that bit him and that he saw him coming towards him in his yard.
FolkNotes: People were taking thatch from her roof, especially from above her door, to stop her harmful magic from working.  Interestingly, she was described as earnestly offering apples to someone who refused (presumbably out of fear that they were tainted).  Elspeth was suspected of becoming angry at this refusal and caused harm.  She interferred with milk churning, and injured infants of people she quarrelled with.  Neighbours testified that Janet Callen, executed for witchcraft in 1659, had left holes in Elspeth's hearth stone from when she lived there.
DiseaseNotes: She killed a baby after she wasn't invited to the baptism. Quarrels about work, borrowing things, and social slights.
PretrialNotes: The corpse bleedingordeal was conducted unofficially.  Witness statements were given on 23, 30 April 1671, 7 May 1671 and 13/5/1671.  Janet Callen has supposedly lived with Elspeth before Callen was charged and executed for witchcraft.  On 2 May 1671 she was summond to appear at Dumfries on 12 May 1671 for her trial.

Notes: Says she was from Aird?  Not on our list?
Charnotes: It says that the panel was poinded by her main victim.  She had a lot of threats and curses followed by harm.  And had a solid witchcraft reputaiton.  Also said she used charmes but doesn't specify whether that meant for healing or harming so have not ticked folk healing as there is no evidence that she healed anyone.
DiseaseNotes: Quarrels and threats
PretrialNotes: Witnesses called on 3 May 1671 for her trial to be held on 12 May 1671.  On 16 April 1671 she was summond to appear for trial in Dumfries.
TrialNotes: Not a complete record, so could be more people involved

Notes: Says he was from Liven.
Charnotes: Seems like nothing happened with his trial.
FolkNotes: A strange case with lots of strange detail about him trying to get good luck?
PretrialNotes: He was imprisoned in the tolbooth of Jedburgh under suspicion of witchcraft, but they refused to try him.  He was being held by the request of the Sheriff of Berwick.  The High Court ordered him released from prison on caution and to appear when called for trial.  Says he was orginially investigaed in the 'Englishe tymes when they wold put no person to death without proven Malefice against them.'
TrialNotes: He was ordered to be moved to the tolbooth of Edinburgh on 24/5/1671.  Apparently that never happened.

Charnotes: Seems like nothing happened in her trial.
CaseNotes: She was released and cautioned to stand trial
PretrialNotes: She was held in the tolbooth of Jedburgh, and she petitioned the High Court for her release, arguing that there were not any formal charges against her.  She was ordered released.
TrialNotes: The circuit court says that she was to be released and cautioned to appear for trial in Edinburgh if called, 24/5/1671.

Notes: Held in Jedburgh but not sure where he is from.
PretrialNotes: Ordered to appear at the 'south court in May last' on charges of witchcraft, but held in the tolbooth of Jedburgh.  He was ordered to be set at liberty but cautioned to appear when called for trial.

Notes: 'Having no livelihood excpet what he acquires with his daily work'.  He was a day labourer.  He was first mentioned in the High Court, then he was indicted for witchcraft in the circuit court held in Edinburgh.
MeetingNotes: He claimed he could not play the pipes and couldn't have been at a meeting because he has witnesses to say he was drinking ale with a group of people.  Nor did he have a staff, some mention of a brass tobacco pipe.  I assume he was answering charges of being at a witches' meeting and playing the pipes, but we don't have the actual accusations, only his statement.
CaseNotes: His diet was deserted.  The edinburgh porteous roll of delinquent dittays from 8/9/1679 all have the standard tag line of accusations: witchcraft, sorcery and necromancy; and renunciation of baptism and giving themselves over to the Devil, body and soul.
PretrialNotes: He was arrested and has sat in prison a long time, he was ordered released on a 1000 merk caution
TrialNotes:
listed on a porteous roll of deliquent dittays on 8/9/1679

His diet was deserted.  On 22 Sept. 1679 he was listed in the porteous roll.

Charnotes: Indication of neighbourhood dispute, but not enough for a primary characterisation.
DiseaseNotes: quarrels followed by threats.
TrialNotes: listed on two Aberdeen rolls (with mostly the same information)

CaseNotes: Larner et al., 'Source-book' listed this case (#596) as being from JC26/38/41 [a source that doesn't exist, probably a typo].  However, the 'Survey' looked through this box number 38 did not find the case.  Larner has this case as processed in some way with an unknown outcome.

DiseaseNotes: This one is all quarrels about work and living, followed by threats and illness and death.
TrialNotes: I believe she was headed for a circuit court trial.

Charnotes: She performed many of her healing rituals on holy days.
FolkNotes: Her case is all about healing.  She seemed to specialise in healing children and infants.  She did many of her cures on the Sabbath and other holy days.  Diagnosed bewitchment.  A transcription of some of her case is in Larner et al.'s Sourcebook, p. 269.  Some of her cures invovled moving the sick child around and putting it in a cradle.  She supposedly left her 'witchcraft' on the hearth stone of her former house.  The next family that moved in suffered losses to their cattle.  She caused a cow to be put through a circle of green yarn for a cure.
DiseaseNotes: She cured cows and children.  Also killed a cow.

Charnotes: The minimal indication given in the circuit court books is that she was accused of one count of a fallout, followed by threats followed by disease.  But not enough to base a whole charactarisation on.
DiseaseNotes: Just one item described

PretrialNotes: She was held in the tolbooth of Stirling, ordered to be released but to compear before the lord's commissioners of justiciary the third day of the next erand to be holden for the sheriffdom of Stirling.

Charnotes: This case is all about quarrels, threats and misfortune.
FolkNotes: A boy had a nightmare that she was gripping him and he woke up on the floor in pain.  She asked for someone's health on her knees and the person recovered.
DiseaseNotes: Angry because a man killed her dog after it had killed his lambs. Went away murmering after refused fodder and straw.  Dispute over the price of the produce from a croft. Quarrel and threats with the miller. Son refused a herding job.
CaseNotes: This group was first processed in 1671 and 1672.  Not sure what happened to reopen things again in 1679 with the addition of Margaret Fleming.
PretrialNotes: They were arrested on April 1671, and brought before the Western Circuit in Dumfries on May 13, 1671.  But no charges were presented so they were held in prison.  The High Court ordered that they be released on caution and tried by the next Western Circuit.  In 1679 they were listed as diet deserted.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more detials about the North Berwick meeting.

CaseNotes: This group was first processed in 1671 and 1672.  Not sure what happened to reopen things again in 1679 with the addition of Margaret Fleming.
PretrialNotes: They were arrested on April 1671, and brought before the Southern Circuit in Dumfries on May 13, 1671.  But no charges were presented so they were held in prison.  The High Court ordered that they be released on caution and tried by the next Southern Circuit.

PretrialNotes: They were arrested on April 1671, and brought before the Southern Circuit in Dumfries on May 13, 1671.  But no charges were presented so they were held in prison.  The High Court ordered that they be released on caution and tried by the next Southern Circuit.  They reappear in a list of people whose diets were deserted.

Notes: Named by others. Escaped for 12 years.
Charnotes: Confession of pact.
DevilNotes: Devil in the form of a leper which she confessed she knew to be an evil spirit. In 1662 she confessed that she met 2 men, one was a gross copperfaced man whom she knew was an evil spirit, the other was a well favoured young man.
MeetingNotes: Confessed that she met others at Bute Quay and she fell in the water but the good looking man pulled her out.
DiseaseNotes: confessed several acts of malefice but no details.
CaseNotes: Initally accused in 1662.
PretrialNotes: She made confessions in 1662 but appears to have escaped prosecution somehow, as she was re-investigated in 1673.

PostTrialNotes: To be executed on the gallows at Rothesay.

PretrialNotes: On 1/6/1674 her trial date was set for Wed. 3/6/1674 and she was given caution to appear for trial.  Her trial was continued again, her husband ordered to 'stand ableidged' for her appearance.  She was previously to stand trial in front of the Justice of the Peace in the Sheriffdom of Banff, but the High Court accepted her appeal, heard the case and dismissed it because the local pursuers did not come to Edinburgh when summond.
TrialNotes: orderfor trial given by the High Court.  She was previously persued in Banff by a two lairds and a bailie.  She appealed to the High Court on the grounds that they were not fit to try her and had not followed proper procedure (i.e. giving her a list of the assize and witnesses, hearing witness testimony in her presence, and that they were not sufficiently educated to hear the case).  The High Court agreed.  The diet was deserted because her pursuers did not appear as they were charged and summond to do.

DevilNotes: She turned to the Devil in despair of her poverty.  The devil always asked if she wanted revenge of anyone.  Got her devil's mark in a privy place, and it hurt until 'the devil lay with her' then the pain was eased.
MeetingNotes: There was a witness to their coming home, Jannet hendry tried to destroy him but couldn't because she didn't have any malice for him.  They had a blue light so the meeting could continue past dark.
PretrialNotes: She confessed first to bailies of Culross, then to the open court in Edinburgh.  They all confessed twice in Culross and then again twice in Edinburgh.  They said that their confessions were voluntary and without torture.

DevilNotes: For sex, she cast her face down to the ground and the devil used her 'after the maner of a beast'.  Her spirit was named Laurie Moir
MeetingNotes: There was a witness to their coming home, Jannet hendry tried to destroy him but couldn't because she didn't have any malice for him.  They had a blue light so the meeting could continue past dark.
PretrialNotes: She confessed first to bailies of Culross, then to the open court in Edinburgh.  They all confessed twice in Culross and then again twice in Edinburgh.  They said that their confessions were voluntary and without torture.

Notes: described as having the 'reputation and charactar of a witch'
DevilNotes: She owned a spirit that appeared to her as her spirit - his name was Peter Drysdale.
MeetingNotes: There was a witness to their coming home, Jannet hendry tried to destroy him but couldn't because she didn't have any malice for him.  They had a blue light so the meeting could continue past dark.
PretrialNotes: She confessed first to bailies of Culross, then to the open court in Edinburgh.  They all confessed twice in Culross and then again twice in Edinburgh.  They said that their confessions were voluntary and without torture.

Notes: Her mother was executed for witchcraft 34 years ago, and Katherine supposedly got it from her mother.
MeetingNotes: There was a witness to their coming home, Jannet Hendry tried to destroy him but couldn't because she didn't have any malice for him.  They had a blue light so the meeting could continue past dark.
DiseaseNotes: got a white powder from the Devil to poison her brother.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Wanted revenge on her brother for getting more of her father's estate after his death.
DefenseNotes: professed her willingness to die for her sin
PretrialNotes: She confessed first to bailies of Culross, then to the open court in Edinburgh.  They all confessed twice in Culross and then again twice in Edinburgh.  They said that their confessions were voluntary and without torture.

TrialNotes: The prosecutor was the Lord Advocate.
It is likely that the accused was executed as the commission mentioned it, but no details.

Notes: wobster's wife
Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: planning meeting to getQueen Anne's ship on its way to Scotland.

DevilNotes: She denied having sex with the Devil, she did not get a Devil's mark and the Devil did not give her a new name.
MeetingNotes: she danced and made mirth
TrialNotes: The prosecutor was the Lord Advocate.

Notes: Described as a witch in the trial of Marion Veitch.
MeetingNotes: She supposedly carried her neice out to the fields to give her over to the Devil.

Notes: Confessed to becoming a witch after falling out with her daughter.  She confessed to being a witch for 13 years.  She was probably more like 63 (fallout with an adult daughter 13 years previous).
DevilNotes: She confessed that the Devil appeared to her after a fall out with her daughter offering her revenge, she agreed.
TrialNotes: The prosecutor was the Lord Advocate.

Notes: confessed to having been a witch for 10 years.
DevilNotes: Devil drank to her and she drank to him
DefenseNotes: She doesn't wish to live because she has kept up with the sacraments and church going the whole time she was a witch.
TrialNotes: The prosecutor was the Lord Advocate.
Did not appear for trial and was declared fugitive and put to the horn.

DevilNotes: He kissed her and he had no breath (the man in green clothes).  She denied to any harm
MeetingNotes: accused of being at a meeting by another accused witch.  She denied the cows burn meeting.
DiseaseNotes: Marion Veitch (c/egd/694) said she helped kill her grandson.

DevilNotes: He kissed her and he had no breath (the man in green clothes).  She denied to any harm
MeetingNotes: accused of being at a meeting by another accused witch.  She denied the cows burn meeting.
DiseaseNotes: Marion Veitch (c/egd/694) said she helped kill her grandson.
PretrialNotes: confronted M. Russel, M. Dods, K. Halyday, M. Bannytyne, H. Laying - they all denied it.
TrialNotes: Did not appear for trial and was declared fugitive and put to the horn.

Notes: Involved in a number of investigations of witchcraft during 1649/50 and 1661. Later accused of scandalous behaviour himself which culminated in an accusation of witchcraft in 1678.  He was then indicted for witchcraft at the circuirt court in 1679 with 4 other from Crichton.
Charnotes: It is difficult to characterise this case as there is no evidence of accusations related to witchcraft. The concerns of the presbytery relate more to his 'scandalous carriage' such as his affair with his servant, non-attendance at kirk, lack of visiting of his parishioners and pilfering of the poor fund rather than practising witchcraft or magic.  He was indicted for witchcraft with a group in the circuit court.
CaseNotes: he was indicted for witchcraft on 8
PretrialNotes: No details about witchcraft accusation in presbytery minutes. Only entries related to his scandalous carriage. Last entry notes that he was imprisoned under accusation of witchcraft.  Commission for arrest issued to sheriff and depute in Edinburgh to bring him to the tolbooth to await trial.  He was put under caution by the High Court on 13/9/1678 to appear for trial when summoned.  16/10/1678 he was ordered to be arrested for a trial on 2/12/1678.  On 13/1/1679 he was ordered by the High Court to be released from the Edinburgh tolbooth on caution.  He wanted to be released because he was a 'weak and tender old man.'
TrialNotes: Order to be brought to Edinburgh for trial on 13/9/1678.  On 16/10/1678 he was ordered to appear before the Privy Council or other lawful court on 2 December 1678. He was eventually tried in a circuit court held in Edinburgh.

Notes: she had a servant, Jannet Burton also accused of witchcraft.  Due to the servant I have put her as middling.  Also described as living in Keith.
MeetingNotes: Devil's meeting described by Margaret Dods
DiseaseNotes: Accused of killing the daughter of Katharine Halyday (c/edg/619).

Notes: husband was a couper
Charnotes: Accused by another witch of trying ot kill her own daughter.

Notes: Servant to Sarah Cranston
DevilNotes: While she was sleeping, Sarah Cranston woke her and told her that 'it behoved her to speak with a gentleman', he was a black man who took her in his arms and kissed her.  She said that Marion Veitch gave her child of one year to the Devil.
MeetingNotes: accused of being at two meetings by another accused witch.  She said that Sarah Cranston rode a horse to death from riding to and from meetings.

Notes: Servant to Sarah Cranston

TrialNotes: The prosecutor was the Lord Advocate.

Notes: 11 year reputation
DevilNotes: She described the Devil as an Englishman with the last name Webb, who cured diseases gave her a drink to make her fertile.  She later knew he was the Devil.

Notes: Few details.
CaseNotes: Listed in presbytery with others accused of witchcraft.
PretrialNotes: Commission granted for assize to try for witchcraft.  Presbytery minutes record that accused thought to be guilty of witchcraft and assize to be held. Mr Patrick Turnour requested brethren to attend.
PostTrialNotes: No specific details. There is a Margaret Hamiltoun 'burnt as a witch' mentioned 1/8/1629 (RPC 2nd series, vol 3, p 155) but it is not clear if it is the same one.

Notes: This primary source listed this person as being from Moray.  But Moray was a region and a county.  Because, part of this group were definitely from Nairn, I have changed this to case to Nairn.

PretrialNotes: They (six of them), having  already been put the horn for not appearing in court, were ordered to be arrested and delivered to the Justice and his deputes.  The commissioners were to assemble a group of armed men to find the suspects.  They were put to the horn on 11/6/1629 by his Majesties Treasurer and Advocate for not appearing for their witchcraft trial.  I put them as central trial, because they were meant to be tried by the justice and his deputes in Edinburgh.

Notes: She was described as a guidwife
Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
DevilNotes: Said by Napier and Sampson that she met the devil as a 'mekle black man'.
MeetingNotes: Others claimed that she was part of the planning in the conspiracy to sink James VI ships on the way back from Denmark.  See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more details about the meeting at the kirk in North Berwick and at the saltpans. A trump was played at these.
FolkNotes: Others said she was involved in rituals with corpse, corpse powder and a cat and attended meetings at Halloween.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Others claimed that she was involved in rituals to sink the royal ships by raising winds and storms.

Notes: Servant to Helen Laying another accused witch.  She confessed to being pregnant two years prior when the devil came to her.
DevilNotes: First he kissed her, he didn't lay with her immediately because she was pregnant.  He lay with her after she was kirked (i.e. lying in period).  He rebaptised her and three others by a 'waff' of his hand across their faces.  Helen Laying and the Devil laid hands on her for the renunciation of her baptism.
MeetingNotes: Lots of witches and a flaming fire 'Devil gave them a kind of sacrament and preached among them and blasphemed God'.
FolkNotes: While in the shape of bees she and Marion Veitch carried the poison used to kill Veitch's grandson in their 'cleuchis, wings and mouth'.  She claimed that Helen Laying (her master) kept her from church and had her carry water from a well instead.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of killing the daughter of Katharine Halyday (c/edg/619).  Helped Kill the grandson of Marion Veitch (c/egd/694).
PretrialNotes: Local laird and others requested permission for local trial which appears to have been refused. They were tried eventually in Edinburgh.
TrialNotes: The prosecutor was the Lord Advocate.  They were to report the execution back to the Privy Council.
PostTrialNotes: Execution took place at Pentson Muir not in Edinburgh.

Notes: Servant to Helen Laying another accused witch.  She confessed to being pregnant two years prior when the devil came to her.
DevilNotes: First he kissed her, he didn't lay with her immediately because she was pregnant.  He lay with her after she was kirked (i.e. lying in period).  He rebaptised her and three others by a 'waff' of his hand across their faces.  Helen Laying and the Devil laid hands on her for the renunciation of her baptism.
MeetingNotes: Lots of witches and a flaming fire 'Devil gave them a kind of sacrament and preached among them and blasphemed God'.
FolkNotes: While in the shape of bees she and Marion Veitch carried the poison used to kill Veitch's grandson in their 'cleuchis, wings and mouth'.  She claimed that Helen Laying (her master) kept her from church and had her carry water from a well instead.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of killing the daughter of Katharine Halyday (c/edg/619).  Helped Kill the grandson of Marion Veitch (c/egd/694).

Notes: accused of murdering her husband, confessed to being a witch for 7 years.  Issobel Eliot was her servant.  I have ticked middling because she had a servant.
DevilNotes: Denies having a new name, denies sex with the devil, denies that she did anything wrong.  She was obviously questioned about these things!
MeetingNotes: Devil's meetings described by Margaret Dods, Helen confessed to meeting the devil in her yard and as ward burnes.  She denied bringing anyone else to meetings.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of killing the daughter of Katharine Halyday (c/edg/619).  Accused of killing her husband, William Laying.  She denies being guily of any malefice.
DefenseNotes: Denies being guilty of malefice
PretrialNotes: Execution ordered. Financial accounts demonstrate that the local laird and others had requested commissions for local trial which were refused. The trial appears to have been held in Edinburgh.  She was confronted by Marion Cambpell, she denied all the charges.
PostTrialNotes: Execution took place at Peaston Muir not in Edinburgh between 2 and 4 p.m.. Local community had to pay the costs.

Notes: accused of murdering her husband, confessed to being a witch for 7 years.  Issobel Eliot was her servant.  I have ticked middling because she had a servant.
DevilNotes: Denies having a new name, denies sex with the devil, denies that she did anything wrong.  She was obviously questioned about these things!
MeetingNotes: Devil's meetings described by Margaret Dods, Helen confessed to meeting the devil in her yard and as ward burnes.  She denied bringing anyone else to meetings.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of killing the daughter of Katharine Halyday (c/edg/619).  Accused of killing her husband, William Laying.  She denies being guily of any malefice.
DefenseNotes: Denies being guilty of malefice

Notes: She was most likely a good deal older because she was described as being too old to be able to reach her foot for the 'crown of her head, sole of her foot' renunciation of baptism.
DevilNotes: She could only manage to put her hand as low as her knee for the 'head and foot'.  His nature was cold and he had no breath.
PretrialNotes: Warrant for execution issued. Financial accounts demonstrate that the local laird and others had attempted to obtain commission to hold the trial locally. These appear to have been refused and the trial was eventually held in Edinburgh.  She was confronted by Marion Campbell.
TrialNotes: The prosecutor was the Lord Advocate.  We have the assize verdict.
PostTrialNotes: execution took place at Penston Muir not in Edinburgh between 2 and 4 p.m.

Notes: She was most likely a good deal older because she was described as being too old to be able to reach her foot for the 'crown of her head, sole of her foot' renunciation of baptism.
DevilNotes: She could only manage to put her hand as low as her knee for the 'head and foot'.  His nature was cold and he had no breath.

Notes: Her aunt is described as a witch.  Humbie is also called Keith in the records.  I think the parishes split after our period.
DevilNotes: Devil required her to destroy her nieghbours but she couldn't do it because God woulnd't allow it.  Her aunt, Marioun Veitch carried her to the fields to meet the Devil.
FolkNotes: She left her body at the kirk in Pencaitland when she went out as a corbie.
DiseaseNotes: confessed to killing her grandson at the Devil's request.
PretrialNotes: Warrant for execution issued.  Local laird and others requested permission for local trial which appears to have been refused. They were tried eventually in Edinburgh.
TrialNotes: They were to report the execution back to the privy Council.
PostTrialNotes: execution took place at Penston Muir not in Edinburgh between 2 and 4 p.m.

Notes: Her aunt is described as a witch.  Humbie is also called Keith in the records.  I think the parishes split after our period.
DevilNotes: Devil required her to destroy her nieghbours but she couldn't do it because God woulnd't allow it.  Her aunt, Marioun Veitch carried her to the fields to meet the Devil.
FolkNotes: She left her body at the kirk in Pencaitland when she went out as a corbie.
DiseaseNotes: confessed to killing her grandson at the Devil's request.

Notes: confessed to being in the Devil's service for 30 years prior.
Charnotes: It is all from her confession, no indication of why she was accused.
DevilNotes: She confessed that she wasn't fast enough in renouncing her baptism and that the Devil dragged her by her coat and broke the band.  She said she was the Devil's 'slave', he struck her and abused her, she tried many times to confess her sins to a minister, but the Devil wouldn't let her.

Notes: confessed to being in the Devil's service for 30 years prior.
Charnotes: It is all from her confession, no indication of why she was accused.
DevilNotes: She confessed that she wasn't fast enough in renouncing her baptism and that the Devil dragged her by her coat and broke the band.  She said she was the Devil's 'slave', he struck her and abused her, she tried many times to confess her sins to a minister, but the Devil wouldn't let her.
TrialNotes: Court was adjourned till wed at 12:00pm for the verdict.  Trial continued on 6/11/1678 and the verdict was read.

Charnotes: It is all from her confession, no indication of why she was accused.
DevilNotes: She was promised by Sara Crantoun that the Devil would make her well liked by women for her career as a midwife.  Sara also promised her a 'cheise', but she never got it.  She said that it was 'greed of her imployment that engaded her to the devillis service'.
TrialNotes: Court was adjourned till wed at 12:00pm for the verdict.  Trial continued on 6/11/1678 and the verdict was read.

Notes: confessed to becoming Devil's servant 20 years prior.
Charnotes: It is all from her confession, no indication of why she was accused.
DevilNotes: At first the Devil just embraced her.  Later at Heriot Back, 'the devill tempted her to uncleannes and hade carnall copulation with her and that he wes all as cold as ire.'
DiseaseNotes: She killed animals  by riding them to death
TrialNotes: Court was adjourned till wed at 12:00pm for the verdict. Trial continued on 6/11/1678 and the verdict was read.

Notes: The porteous roll says she is from the shire of Stirling, Larner had her from Nairn.
Charnotes: She was accused of killing two high ranking men with image magic.
FolkNotes: She was accused of making  a wax and clay images and putting them over a fire to kill two high ranking men (Lord Cochran and Hammilton)
CaseNotes: listed as a fugitive from dumbarton, but the document clearly states she is from Stirlingshire.  Ordered to appear in Edinburgh on 5/1/1680.
TrialNotes: A Dunbarton porteous roll dated 5/9/1679 says the diet was deserted then.   Circuit court held in Stirling where her dittay was handed in, but the High Court deserted the dittay in 5/1/1680.  Don't know when the circuit court case was heard.

Notes: Described as from the 'regality of borrowstounness'.
MeetingNotes: The clothes Bessie supposedly wore to a meeting were described by Elizabeth Scotland - Red coat, black caille with a hood on her head, pearling on her face and a plaid about her shoulders.

Notes: Described as from the 'regality of borrowstounness'.
MeetingNotes: The clothes Bessie supposedly wore to a meeting were described by Elizabeth Scotland - Red coat, black caille with a hood on her head, pearling on her face and a plaid about her shoulders.
PretrialNotes: The bailie of Bo'ness set a trial date for a local trial, and she protested to the High Court.  The main prosecutor, Robert Hamiltone (bailie) did not appear at the high court.  Her complaint claimed that the regality did not have the authority to hold a witchcraft trial and that the evidence against her was weak.
TrialNotes: She was put to caution and released

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
DevilNotes: Said by Sampson and Napier to have met the devil as a 'mekle black man'
MeetingNotes: See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See Napier (c/egd/103) for description of other meeting. They said she was at meetings at the shore and at the kirk in North Berwick, where a trump was played.
FolkNotes: Detailed description by others of how she was supposedly involved in preparation for North Berwick meeting. Said to have used corpse, corpse powder, snake skin, toad, urine and wax/clay images in rituals. Also meetings at Halloween.

PretrialNotes: The procedure was going ahead locally, but the High Court and the commissions sent people out to investigate allegations of torture.  The central representatives found evidence of torture (of several kinds), ordered all the suspects released, and cautioned for if new charges were brought.  She and Elizabeth Hutcheon were released from prison on 3/4/1680.

Notes: Husband a merchant in Bo'ness.  She worked in a shop, presumably a place where people bought her husband's wares?
DevilNotes: He promised her pearls and jewels which he showed to her.  At first she refused to have sex with him because of her husband.  She exchanged words with the Devil 'I am thyne and thow art mine.'  He appeared in her shop and dissapeared when people came in.
PretrialNotes: The procedure was going ahead locally, but the High Court and the commissions sent people out to investigate allegations of torture.  The central representatives found evidence of torture (of several kinds), ordered all the suspects released, and cautioned for if new charges were brought.  She and Margaret Whytt were released from prison on 3/4/1680.

Notes: for 23 years she dwelled at Bonhard in Carneth.  She was due to remarry before she was accused.
DevilNotes: Devil appeared at a dam where a woman had killed herself.  He told her he would be a good husband to her.
MeetingNotes: Meeting at the links after the last harvest.  She described the clothes Bessie Gibb's clothing wore to the meeting and said there were 18 people there.  She went to the meeting on horseback.
PretrialNotes: The procedure was going ahead locally, but the High Court and the commissions sent people out to investigate allegations of torture.  The central representatives found evidence of torture (of several kinds), ordered all the suspects released, and cautioned for if new charges were brought.

DevilNotes: She went to collect a debt from Elizabeth Scotland and was chased by a black thing.  The Devil claimed to be a wealthy man who had lived in Linlithgow and promised to lend her 100 merks, which he failed to do.  The Devil shook hands with her and her hand was sore.
CaseNotes: The project did not check Larner's reference to this case in a printed secondary source as part of the research. The unchecked secondary source indicates a date of 10/5/1680 - possibly an execution?
PretrialNotes: The procedure was going ahead locally, but the High Court and the commissions sent people out to investigate allegations of torture.  The central representatives found evidence of torture (of several kinds), ordered all the suspects released, and cautioned for if new charges were brought.

DevilNotes: Promised her gold money and great riches.
MeetingNotes: dance and be merry
PretrialNotes: The procedure was going ahead locally, but the High Court and the commissions sent people out to investigate allegations of torture.  The central representatives found evidence of torture (of several kinds), ordered all the suspects released, and cautioned for if new charges were brought.

CaseNotes: I could not find this source in the NAS, and I could not find anyone else who knows what it is.  Therefore, I can not put any information about Robertson in this records.

Notes: Greenock is in two counties.
She was confessed to 'fornication' with George Wallace, her servant in 7/6/1681 in front of the Mauchline kirk session

TrialNotes: It seems likely that the accused was executed as the commission mentioned it, but there are no details.
She gave a statement on 17/6/1590 after her condemnation for witchcraft

Notes: She appeared as a witness in a kirk session investigation to find the father of someone's baby in 26/11/1676.
Two other women with the same last name from Crichton were tried with him.  I believe they were his sisters.
CaseNotes: The edinburgh porteous roll of delinquent dittays from 8/9/1679 all have the standard tag line of accusations: witchcraft, sorcery and necromancy; and renunciation of baptism and giving themselves over to the Devil, body and soul.  He and the three others were mentioned in JC26/62 bundle 4, Edinburgh Porteous Roll for July 1683 - indicted and accused of witchcraft and necromancy.
TrialNotes: listed on a porteous roll of deliquent dittays.  Not sure what happened he is listed in a Porteous roll again for 1683.  Marginal note says 'all absent and resited' (all refers to three others in group).

CaseNotes: Listed by Larner as being on an Edinburgh porteous roll from 1683, but Larner did not provide a full reference with a box number.  Therefore I was not able to find this reference and did not find it in the boxes I surveyed, which covered the year 1683.  It is possible this person was accused only of charming and that I did not take a note of it.  I have ticked Mixed Central/Local Trial, because porteous rolls were drawn up for circuit courts.

The edinburgh porteous roll of delinquent dittays from 8/9/1679 all have the standard tag line of accusations: witchcraft, sorcery and necromancy; and renunciation of baptism and giving themselves over to the Devil, body and soul.  Tried in the circuit court with G. Penman and others from Crighton for witchcraft.  She and the three others were mentioned in JC26/62 bundle 4, Edinburgh Porteous Roll for July 1683 - indicted and accused of witchcraft and necromancy.
TrialNotes: listed on a porteous roll of deliquent dittays.  she was indicted again on a proteous roll from 1683.   Marginal note says 'all absent and resited' (all refers to three others in group).

Notes: Husband was James Wilson

She and the three others were mentioned in JC26/62 bundle 4, Edinburgh Porteous Roll for July 1683 - indicted and accused of witchcraft and necromancy.

She and the three others were mentioned in JC26/62 bundle 4, Edinburgh Porteous Roll for July 1683 - indicted and accused of witchcraft and necromancy.

Notes: from Holme of penport.
TrialNotes: She was on a dumfries roll

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.

CaseNotes: Larner et al., 'Source-book' listed this case as being from JC26/62.  However, the 'Survey' looked through this box and did not find the case.  Larner has this case as being processed with an unknown outcome.  A porteous roll means that it was due to be heard at the ciruit court.  Possible black was accused as a charmer, not for witchcraft?
TrialNotes: Porteous roll means circuit court tiral.

CaseNotes: Larner et al., 'Source-book' listed this case as being from Annandale roll 1683 without mention of which box it is from.  Therefore we were unable to find the case.   Larner has this case as being processed with an unknown outcome.  We did not find her in any of the sources we surveyed.

Notes: Her husband was a miller
Charnotes: Accused of tormenting Margaret Laird (i.e. possession).  She was also delated by Elizabeth Anderson from the 1697 Renfrewshire cases.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
FolkNotes: supposedly killed a minister's child and tormented as if they were being strangled.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

Notes: described as a tenant in Spittel of Killerman.  His wife was also accused of witchcraft.
CaseNotes: He was tried on a commission and acquitted but the judges banished him anyway.  The high court absolved him.

Notes: described as a tenant in Spittel of Killerman.  His wife was also accused of witchcraft.
CaseNotes: He was tried on a commission and acquitted but the judges banished him anyway.  The high court absolved him.

Notes: husband described as 'elder' which could mean elder in the Kirk, but more likely means he has a son of the same name.
Charnotes: She seems to have been quarrelling with neighbours, but the witchcraft thing seems to have solidified with her being delated by Margaret Laird, a girl claiming to be possessed.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
FolkNotes: Use of an object (called a 'charme') but doesn't say what it was.
DiseaseNotes: Caused the children of a woman who had called a witch to get sick.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.

Notes: she ran a school, not just a teacher.  I think someone who ran a school would be middling.  Reputed a witch for 20 years
Charnotes: Her accusations stem from quarrels about the school and children falling ill.  Also lots of mentions of her being associated with loud noises of rats and cats - a lot of them.  Doesn't seem like enough to base a primary characterisation.
FolkNotes: Mention of her being associated with a multitude of noisy cats and rats.
DiseaseNotes: Muttering after quarrels.  A rat was seen on a child that later became ill.
CaseNotes: Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

FolkNotes: Others said that she was involved in using a corpse and corpse at halloween.

Charnotes: She was accused only of having a devil's mark and for tormenting Margaret Laird.  Not much detail.  See Agnes Supp for description of the possesion.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

Notes: Her husband was a merchant
Charnotes: Just described as tormenting Margaret Murdoch and Margaret Laird.  She also appeared to a guy in his bed chamber with Marion Ure and Jannet Gentleman.  See Agnes Supp for description of the possesion.
FolkNotes: appeared as an apparition to a guy in his bed chamber with 2 other witches the three also appeared as animals - a sow, a cat and an ape.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, and Margaret Murdoch in Govan.  Both girls claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird  and Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699, from Laird) and  Glasgow (22 April 1699 from Murdoch).  Testimony came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

Charnotes: He did not show up in the processes from 1697, but was said to have been denounced at that time.  He was denounced by Margaret Laird and girl claiming to be possessed.  Very detailed documents.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.
PretrialNotes: He was delated by Thomas Lindsay, Elizabeth Anderson and Christian Shaw from 1697 Refrewshire cases.  Delated again by another possessed girl, Margaret Laird.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

Notes: She was a servant to the father of Margaret Murdoch, the tormented girl who denounced a lot of the 1699 accused witches.
Charnotes: She was named by Margaret Murdoch for tormenting her. See Agnes Supp for a description of the torment/possession.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Murdoch in Govan, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Her father was John Murdoch of Craigtown in the parish of govan.  Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Glasgow (22 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Murdoch's fits and denunciations among other things.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

Notes: his mother was also a witch.  He was not older than 15.
Charnotes: He was told another child that he was a warlock and that his mother was a witch.  He was accused of tormenting a boy and a possessed girl.  He was subjected to the water test (possibly by other children?) and failed  - he did not sink.  They did the test on another boy who sank.
DevilNotes: His mother told him to do the head and foot to give himself over to the devil.  The Devil took him away with him.
CaseNotes: Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.
PretrialNotes: he was young and told another child that he was a warlock and that his mother and dead brother were witches.

Notes: son also accused of witchcraft.  She was accused of making her son join with the Devil.
Charnotes: She was a poor woman who seemed to move around a lot.  She was denounced by her son (sort of) when he told other kids that he was a witch and that so was his mother.  She was accused of tormenting Margaret Laird one two girls claiming possession in 1699.  Very detailed documents.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possession.
DevilNotes: Accused by her son of making him join the Devil (see c/egd/735) for details of his case.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations.
TrialNotes: Witness statements were taken on 21/4/1699 and a dittay was drawn up. A trial was set for 19/5/1699 in Glasgow, doesn't seem to have happened. Diet deserted in 1700 in the high court.

Notes: she seems to have moved a bit.  Described as late in paisley, but she definitely wasn't dead at that time.  I think she was landless status because she was described as begging.
Charnotes: She seems to have been a troublesome woman, asking for charity and doing lots of cursing and offensive gestures.  Lots of muttering after refused charity.  She begging at people's homes and at an Abbey in Paisley.  Accused of causing an undescribed tormenting.
FolkNotes: She was offered a dollar for appeasement.  Lots of muttering and curses.
DiseaseNotes: mostly curses and illnesses.  She cursed someone at a like-wake.  She stuck her tongue out after making curses.

Testimony came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.

Notes: Port Glasgow and Newark were all joined at this time as the parish of Kilmacolm.  She was married to a shoemaker.
Charnotes: Just says that she had a devil's mark, nothing more.
CaseNotes: Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

Notes: her dead husband was a Baxter, but I think she was of lower status because she was listed as being refused lots of alms.
Charnotes: She was originally denounced after a problem at the mill.  But she was denounced by Margaret Laird one of the possessed girls from the 1699 paisley group.  I think she was a trouble maker with a reputation for harmful magic who got swept into a possession prosecution.  The main accusation was causing harm after refusal of alms or charity.  She supposed denounced quite a few others.  Very detailed documents.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
FolkNotes: Used a 'charme' meaning an object to cure someone.
DiseaseNotes: turned blood to milk, interfered with butter.  Damaged a mill because of refusal of alms.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations.
PretrialNotes: Was first named as a witch in March 1695.
TrialNotes: Witness statements were collected and put into a dittay dated 21/4/1699.  The trial was set for 12/5/1699.  But that didn't happen and her diet deserted by order of the High Court in 1700.

Charnotes: Definitely about quarrelling and cursing followed by magical harm. But she seems to have been swept into the the possession cases of 1699 in Renfrewshire.  Supposedly the tormentor of Margaret Laird and Christian Shaw.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
DevilNotes: Was pricked for the mark.
DiseaseNotes: good description of the curse accompanied by clapping.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
DevilNotes: Sampson said he met the devil as a 'mekle black man'.
MeetingNotes: See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more details about the North Berwick meeting. Others said he was at the meeting at the kirk in North Berwick where a trump was played.
FolkNotes: Others said he was involved in using corpse and corpse powder at Halloween.

Notes: We know she had dairy cows.
Charnotes: she was accused of causing tormentings of Margaret Laird and of stealing milk with sympathetic magic, as well as of cursing followed by harm.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
FolkNotes: Very interesting description of a sympathetic magic ritual.  She was accused of holding a leather strap as if she were milking a cow.  This action supposedly magically took the cows milk from her neighbour, thereby increasing her output and destroying her neighbours milk/dairy output.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

Charnotes: Complicated case involving numerous accusations of murdering children through magical strangulation and possession of several children.  Much of the evidence was derived from the testimony of children who claimed to be possessed and tormented by witches.  But there was great concern over the murdered children and a murdered minister.  The record describes the physical torment of the possessed children in great detail.  An extraordinary document!  The second arrest, was about the possession of two girls Margaret Laird and Margaret Murdoch Laird was unable to eat or drink but there are no details about whether there was some personal dispute involved.  The usual possession symptoms - spitting pins, contortions, pain, bite marks, and calling out names of tormentors.  Very detailed documents.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
DiseaseNotes: accused of killing a child.  Main accusation was possession.
CaseNotes: She was released from prison due to pregnancy.  She was confined to Edinburgh by the Privy Council on 6 September 1698 to answer to them any time before 15 November 1698 for accusations of witchcraft.  She seems to have been charged again in 1699 and then the diet was deserted in 1700.  This is the same general trajectory as Annabel Reid (c/la/2971)  Her husband's bond of caution survives - 20/5/1699.  Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, and Margaret Murdoch in Govan.  Both girls claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird  and Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699, from Laird) and  Glasgow (22 April 1699 from Murdoch).  Testimony came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.
PretrialNotes: She was originally part of the 1697 Renfrewshire witches, but she was not tried at that time due to pregnancy.  She was confined to Edinburgh by the Privy council on 6 Sept. 1698.  (joyce notes) I think this is mixed trial as presbytery note that committee of justiciary was due to travel through to the west in 4/1699. JC references imply that there was supposed to be a trial in Glasgow in May 1699.
TrialNotes: She was indicted in 1697 and released due to pregnancy.  But I think she was rearrested in 1699 and then her diet was deserted in 1700 see second trial

Charnotes: Complicated case involving numerous accusations of murdering children through magical strangulation and possession of several children.  Much of the evidence was derived from the testimony of children who claimed to be possessed and tormented by witches.  But there was great concern over the murdered children and a murdered minister.  The record describes the physical torment of the possessed children in great detail.  An extraordinary document!  The second arrest, was about the possession of two girls Margaret Laird and Margaret Murdoch Laird was unable to eat or drink but there are no details about whether there was some personal dispute involved.  The usual possession symptoms - spitting pins, contortions, pain, bite marks, and calling out names of tormentors.  Very detailed documents.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
DiseaseNotes: accused of killing a child.  Main accusation was possession.
CaseNotes: She was released from prison due to pregnancy.  She was confined to Edinburgh by the Privy Council on 6 September 1698 to answer to them any time before 15 November 1698 for accusations of witchcraft.  She seems to have been charged again in 1699 and then the diet was deserted in 1700.  This is the same general trajectory as Annabel Reid (c/la/2971)  Her husband's bond of caution survives - 20/5/1699.  Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, and Margaret Murdoch in Govan.  Both girls claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird  and Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699, from Laird) and  Glasgow (22 April 1699 from Murdoch).  Testimony came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.
PretrialNotes: witnesses were question twice, the second time in Glasgow 22/4/1699.

Notes: He was a known healer and was from Inverkip originally.  His reputation as a healer of animals began to grow in 1672. Age 28 + 25 = 53.
Charnotes: Was indicted with others accused of tormenting children.  But he seems to be a straightforward failed healer who got caught up in the 1699 prosecutions.
FolkNotes: Used hair as a charm to cure.  The objects were used to heal. Used rowan tree belt wrapped nine times to cure ?frigidity. Used nail clippings, eye brow hair and hairs from the crown of the head and half a penny wrapped in cloth. Told witness to sow some milk in with his corn on Beltane day. Told another man to boil a stirck (young cow) and burn the rest of the bones to ashes and then bury them. Dougall said this would cure the sturdie (scrappie) disease in his beasts.
DiseaseNotes: He was noted as unsuccessful at healing a girl, seemed to be better at healing animals. Used charms to heal frigidity and convulsions. Hair, money and nails were left so whoever found them would get the disease and remove it from the first person.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Claimed he had taught a man how to get part of another man's fishing.
CaseNotes: He was accused with others who were denounced by tormented girls, but he appears to have been a healer (called a charmer in the record).  Connected with the Margaret Murdoch cases.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery and kirk sessions investigate and question witnesses and the suspect between 3/6/1695 and 12/11/1695. Decide on public repentance and censure at this time. Name to be given to the local sheriff.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

Notes: Father was a smith.  Mother also accused of witchcraft
Charnotes: Delated by Margaret Murdoch for causing her tormenting.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
FolkNotes: accused of doing a charme with a frog at the threshhold.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Murdoch in Govan, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Her father was John Murdoch of Craigtown in the parish of govan.  Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Glasgow (22 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Murdoch's fits and denunciations among other things.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

Notes: Husband was a beadle with implies at least middling status
Charnotes: Was delated by Margaret Murdoch for tormenting her and troubling her with 'evil spirits'.  Gilmore had a good reputation till then, but her mother was reputed a witch.  See Agnes Supp for description of the tormenting/possesion.
FolkNotes: was accused of using a frog at the threshold for a charm.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Murdoch in Govan, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Her father was John Murdoch of Craigtown in the parish of govan.  Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Glasgow (22 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Murdoch's fits and denunciations among other things.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

Notes: Daughter also accused of witchcraft.  Married to a smith.
Charnotes: She was mostly accused of causing the tormenting/possession of Margaret Murdoch after Murdoch stole from Janet.  She was also accused of trying to get Murdoch to give herself over the devil, by signing a piece of paper and by doing the head and foot.  See Agnes Supp for description of torment.
DevilNotes: Tried to get someone to do the head and foot.
FolkNotes: She was blamed for a charme involving a frog at the threshhold.  She also advised someone to wade into the Clyde.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Murdoch in Govan, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Her father was John Murdoch of Craigtown in the parish of govan. Notes: Her husband was a beadle which implies at least middling.
Charnotes: Accused of tormenting Margaret Murdoch and of appearing to a guy in his bed chamber with Marion Ure and Margaret Duncan.  See Agnes Supp for description of the possesion.
FolkNotes: appeared as an apparition to a guy in his bed chamber with 2 other witches the three also appeared as animals - a sow, a cat and an ape.
CaseNotes: Her husband's bond of caution for her survives - 1699.  Denounced by Margaret Murdoch in Govan, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Her father was John Murdoch of Craigtown in the parish of Govan.  Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Glasgow (22 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Murdoch's fits and denunciations among other things.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

Notes: Her husband was a merchant
Charnotes: She was accused of tormenting Margaret murdoch and of appearing in a guy's bed chamber with Margaret Duncan and Jannet Gentleman.  See Agnes Supp for description of the possesion.
FolkNotes: Danced as an apparition with 2 others in a guys bed chamber - they also appeared as a sow, a cat and an ape.
DiseaseNotes: She spoke threatening words to a man and later appeared in his bed chamber
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Murdoch in Govan, a girl who claimed to be tormented by witches.  Her father was John Murdoch of Craigtown in the parish of govan.  Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Glasgow (22 April 1699) and it came from people who witnessed Murdoch's fits and denunciations among other things.

Notes: wife of a smith
Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
DevilNotes: Sampson and Napier said she met the devil as a 'mekle black man'.
MeetingNotes: See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more details about the North Berwick meeting. Said by others to have been at the meeting a the kirk in North Berwick where a trump was played.
FolkNotes: Others said she had been involved in using corpse and corpse powder at Halloween.

Notes: Larner had her as being from Perth.  The source had Torryburn which is a parish in Dunfermline, Fife.  So I changed her county to Fife.
TrialNotes: Released on a bond of caution, supposed to appear at next circuit to Perth no evidence that she did.

Notes: Also recorded as having been in Kirkcudbright after being banished from the Dumfries synod area.  She was listed in a porteuous roll of Oct. 1708 as sometime in the parish of Troquer but now in Rockhall.  Another person of the same name was listed as being in Collin in the parish of Gothorald(?) at the same time?  Possibly two different people, but I think not because Joyce found her in the Prebytery records that she was banished so she probably moved around a lot, and it is an uncommon name.  The porteous roll also says she had been banished from the presbytery of Dumfries
Charnotes: Indicted for using spells and enchantments and for corresponding with the Devil.  I think this could be refused charity because there is a mention of pain in her bowels when she asked for food.
DevilNotes: corresponding with the devil
DiseaseNotes: wronged several of her neighbours cattle.  Some evidence of quarrels and threats. She was refused entertainment (i.e. food).
PretrialNotes: Presbytery investigated the case but there seems to have been a long delay.  No details about accusations against her. By 2/4/1700 it was noted that the civil judge was not going to pursue the case. Mr Paton appointed to apply to the sheriff and stewat deputes to get an order to banish her.  At some point she requested a testimonial from the Presbytery of Dumfries and was refused due to her mala fama.  The JC40/11 document narrates that she took a voluntary banishement from Dumfries to avoid trouble, but was seen in those parts.
TrialNotes: No details but investigation by Dumfries presbytery in 1700 resulted in her being banished from the area of the presbytery and synod. She agreed to do this and it seems that she then re-appeared in Kirkcudbright area.

Notes: Also recorded as having been in Kirkcudbright after being banished from the Dumfries synod area.  She was listed in a porteuous roll of Oct. 1708 as sometime in the parish of Troquer but now in Rockhall.  Another person of the same name was listed as being in Collin in the parish of Gothorald(?) at the same time?  Possibly two different people, but I think not because Joyce found her in the Prebytery records that she was banished so she probably moved around a lot, and it is an uncommon name.  The porteous roll also says she had been banished from the presbytery of Dumfries
Charnotes: Indicted for using spells and enchantments and for corresponding with the Devil.  I think this could be refused charity because there is a mention of pain in her bowels when she asked for food.
DevilNotes: corresponding with the devil
DiseaseNotes: wronged several of her neighbours cattle.  Some evidence of quarrels and threats. She was refused entertainment (i.e. food).
TrialNotes:
She was previously banished and now brought up for charges under the circuit court again.  She was put under caution in 1708.  There were two porteous rolls, one from Oct. 1708 and one from 1709. 
The verdict was handed back on  4/5/1709.

Charnotes: mention of using curses and enchantments against her neighbours.  And also for 'corresponding' with the Devil.
PretrialNotes: An arrest warrant for 15/4/1709 was drawn up in accordance with the porteous roll for Dumfries.
TrialNotes: There were two porteous rolls, one from Oct. 1708 and one from 1709.  She was also branded on the check.  The verdict was handed back on 4/5/1709.

Notes: Says she is from Clune?
DiseaseNotes: She was accused of murder using witchcraft.
CaseNotes: Don't know what happened in terms of a trial so I have not ticked any type of trial process.

Notes: From Antuabey Thane?  Unable to modernise the names.
DiseaseNotes: accused of taking away men's members
PretrialNotes: Not sure about the process of her trial, all we have is a statement that is now in the JC40 so I don't know from which source it originated.

FolkNotes: Others said she was involved in using corpse and corpse powder at halloween.

Her case was reffered to Sir George Maxwell of Pollok for trial.

DiseaseNotes: Malefices
PretrialNotes: She confessed to her minister.  The suspects were interrogated in their parishes, referred to the Presbytery and then the JPs asked the presbytery to present their susptects to the JPs for trial.
TrialNotes:
The Justice of the Peace was to investigate and report back at the next court.

Ayr Court list from 6/4/1658

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
DevilNotes: Sampson and Napier said she met the devil as a 'mekle black man'.
MeetingNotes: See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more details about the North Berwick meeting. Others said she was at meetings at the kirk in North Berwick where a trump was played.
FolkNotes: Others said she was involved in using corpse and corpse powder at Halloween.

Notes: not the same as Wallas, c/egd/303.
TrialNotes: The Justice of the Peace was to investigate and report back at the next court.

Notes: Her daughter testified against her. She was most likely either widowed or married to a man named Schaw.
Charnotes: she was delated by other witches, not specified in the record.  Most of the accusations seem relate to quarrels followed by harm, but the evidence is sketchy.
DevilNotes: delated by witches but doesn't say who.
FolkNotes: Someone asked for their health for God's sake.  She diagnosed Colic for her daughter.
DiseaseNotes: proposed marriage for her daughter, refused, revenge. Neighbour refused to reciprocate ale round, curses, illness. Man refused to cart her herring, threats, illness. Refusal to pay a fee to her daughter, threats, illness.
PretrialNotes: She was orginally arrested in 1651.  Also, it seems that a former provost and two former bailies tried to exonerate her and the three other arrested with her (7 October 1651).  There is some evidence of a commission being granted that was not acted upon (from 13 July 1652).
TrialNotes: On two porteous rolls on 31 March 1658 summond to appear on 6 April 1658.  First mentioned in 6/4/1568   the Justice of the Peace was to investigate and report back at the next court.   They made a report that is in JC26/26. The trial was held on 30/3/1659 almost a year later.  Both appearances before the circuit court were in the tolbooth of Ayr.  Also have a list of witnesses 14 men and 10 women.  Her daughter testified against her.

Notes: Her daughter testified against her. She was most likely either widowed or married to a man named Schaw.
Charnotes: she was delated by other witches, not specified in the record.  Most of the accusations seem relate to quarrels followed by harm, but the evidence is sketchy.
DevilNotes: delated by witches but doesn't say who.
FolkNotes: Someone asked for their health for God's sake.  She diagnosed Colic for her daughter.
DiseaseNotes: proposed marriage for her daughter, refused, revenge. Neighbour refused to reciprocate ale round, curses, illness. Man refused to cart her herring, threats, illness. Refusal to pay a fee to her daughter, threats, illness.

Notes: Her husband was a messengaer. Middling or possibly even higher status?  I am going to stick with middling classification she is described as a portioner who lost her land from the Provost after a quarrel. Her husband had stables.  Reputation 19 years back, estimate her age as at least 44.
Charnotes: Definitely neighbourhood dispute, lots of quarreling over work, animals, ale purchases, stolen aqua vitae fire, rent collection.  She was accused of flyting.  She threatened a Kirk searcher who found her not at church on a Sunday.  Another accused witch had been hired by her neighbours to stop her and in the process she implicated Sawer for witchcraft.  She was denounced by Helen Gavin.  She denied it all!
FolkNotes: horses that died on lammas were blamed on her.  A woman saw four cats dancing 'as it weir dancing the reill dance', the cats went to Jannet's house.  Jannett also accused a woman of stealing an ingle [fire] from the aqua vitae pot, the supposed thief suffered great pain and boils.  I think this was a counter-strategy tried on Jannett.  A man who was going to report her to the session for missing church on a Sunday got ill on the Monday and just before his death saw her with 'a devil out of hell'.
DiseaseNotes: she was mentioned as taking away a woman's milk, bewitching people and animals, and killing a bairn.  Quarrelling over stables, over payment to her son, rent collection, theft.  She was summond to the Kirk session for stealing wort and ale.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: The Ship of Balfast came to Ayr for takell (it was bound for Barbados), she supposedly raised a storm to destroy it.  Jannett was seen lying within the sea mark with her mouth up, sucking the air 'lyk ane adder'.
CaseNotes: Her execution was described in a letter of Colonel Robert Sawrey, dated 26 April 1658.  He described her speech in which she denied all witchcraft and confessed to her wicked life and made exhortations to the living.  The speech is used in the letter to show that Ayr is hunting witches.  We already knew this from the many trial records we have.
PretrialNotes: She was orginally arrested in 1651.  Also, it seems that a former provost and two former bailies tried to exonerate her and the three other arrested with her (7 October 1651).  There is some evidence of a commission being granted that was not acted upon (from 13 July 1652).
TrialNotes: On two porteous rolls on 31 March 1658 summond to appear on 6 April 1658.

Notes: Mentions her Goodman, and she had  at least one daughter.  Unable to modernise her surname.
Charnotes: looks like a neighbourhood dispute one, but we don't have the dittay, just the witnesses responses to the dittay.  That does not give us enough information to tell for sure.
DiseaseNotes: accused of getting magical revenge for harm done to her family.
PostTrialNotes: to be executed on the first Wednesday in May, between 2-4 in the ordinary place.

Notes: Rerrick was formerly called Dundrennane.  She is listed as from Dundrennane. Reference to the accused being consulted as a 'witch woman'.  She travelled very far for healing.  Possibly widowed?
Charnotes: No specific details about Miller but according to Dumfries presbytery records it appears she was noted as a 'witch woman' but seems to have given advice about folk healing.  Her draft dittay shows that she was a recognised healer who travelled far and wide.  Her witchcraft reputation seems to have come from failed healing attempts and because she told people to keep her cures from the ministers.  Lots of fairry stuff.  The church and others might have been threatened by her advice to her patients to keep her cures a secret.  This may have lead people to believe that what she was doing was wrong?
DevilNotes: Says she convenit [convened] with the Devil in her dream.  She confessed to having a familiar, but it was not described as an an animal and it could have been a familiar spirit?  She claimed that the Devil gave her power to heal.  After her husband, [died?] she worried about her livelihood that is when the Devil came to her.  The Devil allowed her to hear the threatenings of other witches and see the diseases at great distance.
FolkNotes: Foxtree leaves (foxglove) used to cure sickness. The consulter was told to take her mother to a certain place, wash her and use foxtree leaves, and leave the sickness at the place where she got it.  She diagnosed an illness as possibly related to the fairries having taken his tongue, if this was true she could be no help to him.  But he should try foxtree leaves and S. running water.  She gripped a child and told them to keep it close and away from the minister.  Diagnosed a child with 'Ferrie blast'.  She did a cure where the victim had to sit between three fires.  A ritual with smoke and fire to get a man out of a witch's grip.  Again told to keep it close especially from the minister.  Advised to keep the bible near for a cure for distempter.  She said a man became ill after digging up a thorn tree.  She diagnosed bewitchings as caused by Kirkcudbright and Dumfries witches (told the victims to get 3 stopings of straw from the witches' roof and burn them).
DiseaseNotes: She denied doing any malefice, but said she could 'take off' diseases (i.e. cure). Healing ritual recorded in Dumfries presbytery records. She advised taking sick person to the place they got illness and carry out ritual in order to cure them.
PretrialNotes: Appears to have been investigated in 1656 by Dumfries presbytery. No details from Kirkcudbright as the presbytery records start too late, but no specific action taken/punishment.
TrialNotes: 7 men and 8 women testified in her draft dittay. She was mentioned in a Kirkcudbright Roll 1648.
PostTrialNotes: to be executed on the first Wednesday in May, between 2-4 in the ordinary place.

Notes: Rerrick was formerly called Dundrennane.  She is listed as from Dundrennane. Reference to the accused being consulted as a 'witch woman'.  She travelled very far for healing.  Possibly widowed?

She said a man became ill after digging up a thorn tree.  She diagnosed bewitchings as caused by Kirkcudbright and Dumfries witches (told the victims to get 3 stopings of straw from the witches' roof and burn them).
