Charnotes: because such a large number were accused it is possible there was some form of local dispute involved
CaseNotes: named with 26 others.

Charnotes: charming was one of the accusations so folk healing element but few other details
OtherChargesNotes: accused of charming and witchcraft and told to make public repentance.
PretrialNotes: Accusations were to be investigated by local minister. She was Later told to make public satisfaction at the kirks of Stobo, Manon, Lyne, Eddleston, Innerleithen, and Peebles.  Presumably the action was dropped as an official witchcraft trial and the church decided to handle the allegations on their own.

Notes: may be same as Margaret Dalgleish from Peebles, 1627, C/EGD/2237. This one was in trouble 5 years before.
DefenseNotes: Entry in presbytery records, 29/2/1644, notes that the accused denied the charges.
PretrialNotes: Dalgleish recorded as fugitive in 1643 and had been in trouble 5 years before.
TrialNotes: Entry in presbytery records (4/1/1644) that accused to stand trial the next Thursday and the ministers were to encourage witnesses to attend the trial.

Charnotes: No details about accusations or confession
DiseaseNotes: She had been consulted by someone in Stow.
PretrialNotes: Note that accused was  held in Peebles and commissioners requested ministers to hear her confession and prepare her for death. No further details
PostTrialNotes: no details but presbytery note that execution to be carried out at Traquair

Notes: husband recorded as an indweller. Also recorded as Lizzie Mudie.
DevilNotes: The demonic pact was suspected but few details
PretrialNotes: commission to try accused issued to provost and baillies of Haddington and other named commissioners. Commission stressed that no torture to be used. She had already been imprisoned.

Charnotes: Named as witch in kirk session records but accused of giving advice about healing charms for sick children
DiseaseNotes: Recorded as having told three woman how to heal their sick children
PretrialNotes: No specific details, only entry in kirk session that before her execution she named those who had consulted her.
TrialNotes: no details but KS notes that she was to be burnt.

PretrialNotes: Few details about the case but the presbytery entry notes that a commission against the accused had been issued as early as 1/6/1650 and that she had been fugitive. 31/12/1661 the presbytery with the laird of Langton, Archibald Cockburn, refer the case to the sheriff depute. No more details in the presbytery records.
Commission issued although suspect already imprisoned.

Notes: This may be the same person as Marjorie Lyell (C/EGD/865) tried for witchcraft in Jedburgh in 1613. There were two hospitals in the parish - Spital Rule and Crailing Spital - but unclear which one in the presbytery records.
PretrialNotes: To be apprehended (20/4/1608) but no further details

Notes: few details
PretrialNotes: No details apart from investigations by the church. No outcome or further referral recorded.

Charnotes: Seems to have got into trouble because she advised people to use healing rituals.
FolkNotes: Entries record that she advised the use of the blood and feathers of a black hen as a healing charm. Note: black cocks were used to cure the falling sickness but there is no mention of the illness or symptoms she was treating.
DiseaseNotes: No details about the symptoms of illness which she could cure.
PretrialNotes: The presbytery considered the case over several months before referrring it to the magistrate in Jedburgh. No further details.

Notes: She and her husband may have been paupers. Confessed to events taking place about 30 years before.
Charnotes: Although the Devil was not mentioned specifically it seems that the descriptions of fairies indicated demonic involvement. The king of fairies seemed to = the Devil.
DevilNotes: Mentioned that man in black clothes made her go forward and was at meetings with them all. She also referred to one man being the king of fairies who lay with her. She was asked if his nature was hot or cold to which she replied that it was cold. Told minister that she renounced her baptism to the king of fairies.
MeetingNotes: A number of cats came to her house which turned into men and women. Also went with a group of male and female fairies and one man had sex with her and another woman.
FolkNotes: Used water from St Mungo's well to heal her father and spoke verse/charm.
DiseaseNotes: Confessed she and others had caused death of Mr James Ross and one of his children. This may have been the James Ross who was minister at Livingston and who died in 1641.
PretrialNotes: No official permission to hold trial appears to have been granted to the church authorities.
TrialNotes: No details of a trial, but she was executed and seems to have been tried without any reference to central authorities.
PostTrialNotes: According to kirk session records she appears to have been executed, but it is not clear if the church requested permission from Sir Walter Murray to burn or bury her as the writing is quite difficult.

Notes: May have been a pauper.
Charnotes: Demonic as primary as it seems those involved may have read fairies as meaning the Devil or devils. The Devil was only mentioned once compared to several mentions of fairies.
DevilNotes: She confessed that she put her own hand on the crown of her head and the other upon the sole of her foot and declared all betwixt the two over to a black man with black clothes and that the devil appeared to her.
FolkNotes: Used term 'good neighbours' who wore green kirtalls. The fairies wanted a nurse for one of their own offspring. BP told them to go to a neighbour's house but the woman would not go with them and so her child was killed. This may indicate a changeling type motif but it is not mentioned specifically.
DiseaseNotes: One of the company whirled them all in the wind. Woman in green put sickness on one of her neighbours. She put whirl wind in the house of one of her neighbours and caused the woman to 'rattell till death'.
PretrialNotes: No official permission to hold trial appears to have been granted from central authorities.
TrialNotes: No details about a trial, but it seemingly took place and without any central authorisation.
PostTrialNotes: No exact description of execution but records note that she is to be buried or burnt(?) without a kist in Kirktounside mure.

Notes: Husband was recorded as a mill-gardener in Falkland
Charnotes: no details but examined by pricker
PretrialNotes: Held in prison for 6 weeks, no record of any commission for trial. Accused claimed that there was no evidence against them. The pricker had been used and had found marks on her but she knew nothing about them.

Charnotes: Had been examined by pricker for marks.
DevilNotes: She was pricked, so they were looking for a Devil's mark.
PretrialNotes: Recorded that accused in prison for 6 weeks but no evidence apart from examination by pricker. Ordered to be released and a legal trial to be arranged. No record of commission for trial from PC.

Notes: Parish was known as Kirkbride or Kilbride. Daughter Janet Hair/Hare questioned. She was a servant so old enough to be working.
Charnotes: The information is limited apart from the slandering and counter slandering. The implication is that the minister believed she had caused his ill-health.
DiseaseNotes: Minister Peter Rae requested her to give him back his health. He also appears to have scratched her on the forehead in order to identify her as a witch.
OtherChargesNotes: Kirkpatrick and minister involved in complex slander and counter slander case.
PretrialNotes: Complicated case which involves slander and counter slander between the minister and the accused. Inquiry held at presbytery level and several witnesses called for both sides. Eventually Mr Rae's case was proven and Kirkpatrick sentenced to lesser excommunication. Rae then wanted the case, now an accusation of witchcraft, referred to bailie of regality of New Dalgarno.  The suspect was scratched (a form of counter-magic) in 1706.
TrialNotes: No trial appears to have been held apart from interrogation of witnesses and two main parties. Case referred to bailie of regality who ordered her to be 'put out of bounds'. This sentence is only recorded in the presbytery book.

Charnotes: Nothing about accusation or confession.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery note about referral to local sheriff in order to secure her, but no indication if she was held or where.  She was the subject of an ongoing Presbytery investigation, but the ink in the volume was difficult to read.
Order to be released from imprisonment on caution, to be tried later.
Released from imprisonment on caution to appear later, no further details.
Ordered to be released but no further details
Ordered to be released after suspect held for 22 weeks. To be set free on caution and to attend any later legal trial.

Notes: Noted as a vagabond within Strathspey and Moray.
Charnotes: Noted as having confessed to pact and renunication of baptism but no details from confession or accusation
DevilNotes: Commission records that accused confessed to pact and renunciation of baptism, but no details.
PretrialNotes: Order for trial after accused had confessed.

Notes: Recorded in RPC as vagabond in Strathspey and Moray.
Charnotes: Demonic pact and renunciation of baptism noted in RPC but no details of confession or accusations.
DevilNotes: RPC entry records that accused confessed to demonic pact and renunciation of baptism but no specific details of confession.
PretrialNotes: Commission issued after accused had confessed.

Charnotes: recorded as having confessed pact and renunciation ot baptism but no details from confession
PretrialNotes: Commission issued after accused had confessed

Notes: accused's husband was cordiner burgess in Jedburgh
PretrialNotes: Husband petitioned PC for his wife to be put to a trial or set free. Local magistrates counter-petitioned and PC ordered to report on process to be given to them before sentence. No further entries.

Notes: Only one of several people who were accused, see C/JO/2899. She was the only one to be named in the presbytery records.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery sent ministers to Caerlaverock to investigate and question those involved. Besse Heslope is the only one who they do not question. Decided to refer the details to the Queen's Advocate, 27/3/1705 since they could not decide whether or not witchcraft had been proven. He replied that no criminal process would be undertaken and presbytery decide to drop the matter.

FirstName: Beak Nean Finley Vic Ean Vic
Notes: Parish recorded as Conveth in RPC but probably Kiltarlity and Convinth parish.  Unable to modernise this name.
CaseCommonName: Homas,Beak Nean Finley Vic Ean Vic
PretrialNotes: Commission issued after the accused had confessed.

Charnotes: Complicated case as a number of people from the McLean family accused. There may have been some family rivalry between the McLeans and Chisholms and the Chisholms wanted to acquire the lands belonging to the group. Claimed that the McLeans had been 'kindly tenants' for several hundred years.
PretrialNotes: McLean complained about the treatment of his relatives by the Chisholms. He alledged that they were trying to obtain the lands and property belonging to the McLeans and using witchcraft as an excuse. Reference to a commission for execution issued in 6/1662. Chisholm counter-petitioned and charges against him were dropped by the PC in 9/1662.

Notes: recorded as an indweller in RPC.
PretrialNotes: Commission issued after the accused had confessed.

Notes: Husband was a burgess in Lauder
PretrialNotes: Accused petitioned PC about her imprisonment. Claimed that as she was being held in prison over the harvest she would lose her crops and income. PC ordered her to be released on payment of 2000 merks and caution her to appear at a later date.

MeetingNotes: Confessed that some of the company went to Saltoun with candles.
Confessed that some of the company went to Saltoun with candles.

Notes: Husband recorded as an indweller in RPC.
PretrialNotes: Bailies of the Canongate to proceed to trial without torture.

Notes: No details about her place of residence etc. Only mentioned in RPC because she died after being pricked.
PretrialNotes: Died after being pricked by John Ramsay.
Local minister reported that he was investigating the suspect, but no further details.

Notes: parish also known as Craufurddouglas.
Charnotes: Accused by Janet Coutts, who with George Cathie (pricker) named a large number of people who were later shown to be innocent. In McBirnie's case, however, some neighbours did accuse her of being the cause of some illness and death.
DiseaseNotes: accused of causing William Brown (slaterer) to fall of a house and break his neck after she had exchanged evil words with him. After another falling out with a neighbour she cursed them and prayed that there might be 'blood boils'. Daughter later fell ill
PretrialNotes: Named by Janet Coutts (C/EGD/1817) along with several others. Presbytery investigate and requested commission from Committee of Estates. There were some witnesses against McBirnie who accused her of causing harm but, after further investigation, case was dismissed. Birnie wanted Coutts brought to confront suspects but this appears not to have happened.

Notes: parish also recorded as Craufurddouglas
Charnotes: Named by Janet Coutts along with several others
PretrialNotes: Denounced by Janet Coutts (C/EGD/1817) and presbytery investigated case. There seems to have been little evidence or witnesses apart from Coutts and Cathie the witch-pricker, although commission was granted. Case dismissed.

Notes: parish also recorded as Craufurddouglas.
Charnotes: One of the many people denounced by Janet Coutts
PretrialNotes: Denounced by Janet Coutts. George Cathie witch pricker involved. Presbytery investigated the case and got commission. After imprisonment and pricking there seems to have been insufficient evidence to pursue the suspects. Bessie Gibson is not recorded as having been released (as most of them were) but it is likely that she was too.

Notes: parish also recorded as Craufurddouglas
Charnotes: One of the many denounced by Janet Coutts
PretrialNotes: denounced by Janet Coutts (C/EGD/1817) and case investigated by presbytery. Commission granted and suspects examined by Cathie the witch pricker, who seem to have a bit of a double act with Coutts. However the investigators did not come up with sufficient evidence and case dismissed.

Notes: parish also recorded as Craufurddouglas
Charnotes: One of several denounced by Janet Coutts
PretrialNotes: Denounced by Janet Coutts (C/EGD/1817) and case investigated by presbytery. Commission granted and suspects imprisoned and pricked. However there appears to have been no witnesses apart from Coutts and George Cathie, the pricker, and the case was dismissed.

Notes: parish also recorded as Craufurddouglas
Charnotes: Named as a witch by Janet Coutts
PretrialNotes: denounced by Janet Coutts (C/EGD/1817) and the presbytery investigated the case. Commission applied for and granted, suspects imprisoned and pricked but apart from Coutts' accusation and the evidence of Cathie, the pricker, there appears to have been no other evidence or witnesses and case was dismissed.

Notes: The record says he was 12 at the time of trial and therefore too young to count as a full witness.  His brother was 14. JM had him from Bargarrane - this was from the Presbytery, the trial record clearly has him and his brother from Blackhall?
Charnotes: He was suspected then became a star witness.  Not prosecuted.  Complicated case involving numerous accusations of murdering children through magical strangulation and possession of several children.  Much of the evidence was derived from the testimony of children who claimed to be possessed and tormented by witches.  But there was great concern over the murdered children and a murdered minister.  The record describes the physical torment of the possessed children in great detail.  An extraordinary document!
CaseNotes: Accused but not indicted for witchcraft.  Instead he and his brother were witnesses.  Deemed too young to have made a viable pact with the Devil.  Was not indicted with the large group on 13/4/1697 or tried with the seven who actually stood trial on 12/5/1697.  He was mentioned on the last day of that trial (19/5/1697) in the closing arguments.
PretrialNotes: One of several people accused by Christian Shaw of bewitching her. Suspect held in the houses of the local ministers.  He was determined to be a witness not a suspect due to young age.  He was mentioned in the Privy Council commission but wasn't  tried with that group.
TrialNotes: Note in presbytery records on 17/3/1697 that the ministers and commissioners are to meet in Renfrew tomorrow for the trial.  Trials of other witches started on 13/4/1697 but was continued until 12/5/1697 it lasted until the 19th.  He was never actually tried for witchcraft.  The charges were dropped due to young age.

Notes: Few details
PretrialNotes: Presbytery note that the details were to be sent to the judge competent in order to get a commission. Later, 29/1/1650, referred to burgh magistrates who were to approach Privy Council.

Notes: Husband was a burgess in Dumbarton so middling status.  Unable to modernise the surname.
DiseaseNotes: Confessed to malefice done to several neighbours but no details
PretrialNotes: Presbytery note that commission to be requested from Privy Council after she was referred to burgh council

Notes: Husband was a merchant so upper.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery note that they advised the magistrate about the suspect, and later note that they recommend requesting a commission.
TrialNotes: I think she was released as APS commission for John McWilliam mentioned putting others to liberty on caution to answer at a later date.

Notes: husband was a cooper.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery note that they advised the magistrate about the suspects and later that they recommend applying for a commission.
TrialNotes: I think she was freed as APS commission for John McWilliam mentioned setting the others to liberty to answer under the law at a later date.

PretrialNotes: Presbytery note that the suspect was to be recommended to the 'judge ordinair' after she had confessed witchcraft.
Presbytery note that the accused had confessed to witchcraft and they recommend referring her to the 'judge ordinair'.

Notes: Last name is really difficult to decipher so I am not at all sure Wikean is correct.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery note that they recommend referring details to the 'judge competent'. Later 2/7/1650, they recommend the magistrate apply for a commission.
TrialNotes: I think she was freed as commission from APS to try John McWilliam mentioned putting the others at liberty to answer at a later date.

PretrialNotes: Presbytery note that the accused was to be imprisoned in Balliemore and to appear at the next provincial presbytery meeting. No further details recorded in the minutes.

Notes: Accused with another woman of being a witch. They both denied the accusations.
Charnotes: The accusations against the two women were not proved by witnesses and the charges dropped. The accuser had to make public repetance.
DevilNotes: Accused of having the devil's mark but there was no evidence and the charge was dropped.
DiseaseNotes: Was accused of having caused the death of a woman but the charge was not proven.
PretrialNotes: The presbytery investigated the accusations, which were raised by another woman. The other witnesses all denied the charges or were vague about just what had happened and the charges were dropped. The accuser had to make public repentance.

Notes: Unable to modernise this surname.
Charnotes: The accusations against the two women were not proven by witnesses and the accuser had to make public repentance.
PretrialNotes: The charges brought against the accused were not proven by witnesses. They denied or were vague about details and the charges were dropped. The accuser had to make public repentance for raising the scandal.

MeetingNotes: Note that the accused had confessed to attending meetings with the devil.
CaseNotes: MacDonald 'The Witches of Fife' (East Linton, 2002) p. 109 indicates that she tried to clear her name in 1654 after being investigated in 1649.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery records note that the accused was imprisoned and had confessed to witchcraft. The minister was to send confessions to the judge in order to proceed with a trial.

MeetingNotes: Records note that accused confessed to meetings with the devil but no details.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery records note that the accused was imprisoned and had confessed to witchcraft. The minister was to send confessions to the judge in order to proceed with a trial. Another entry in Aberdour kirk session notes that the accused and 2 other women accused a third woman who was brought to confront them in prison.

Notes: There is also a Helen Birrell from Kirkcaldy in 1616 and 1626 (C/EGD/2572), who may be the same person.
PretrialNotes: The presbytery minutes record that they think they have enough grounds to apprehend her.

Notes: Accused of causing a ship to sink 22 years before. Also had an adult son.
DevilNotes: Foullthief (or ?foulfiend) - the devil - appeared as a man in her own house. It kissed her but she withdrew from it. Asked how she was able to do so since he was a spirit and she was only flesh and blood. Answered she was very strong.
DiseaseNotes: Accused confessed to causing death of woman and a horse, burning a mill and stealing milk but denied that she had caused the sinking of a ship.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery questioned the accused and witnesses. Appears to have been imprisoned and confessed but no further details.

Charnotes: Document implies that suspect may have caused an episode of madness in another woman who received an 'act of witchcraft'.
DiseaseNotes: Accused appears to have cast a 'madness' on another woman who then appears to have pestered a man from the town.

Notes: She may have been accused with Geils Merser (C/JO/2984).
PretrialNotes: The presbytery discussed the matter and appointed ministers to assist the magistrates of Perth. By 6/5/1646 the presbytery again discussed the delay in this matter and decide that the accusations were not fully or sufficiently proven and could not find her guilty. Process to stop for the time being.

Notes: She may have been accused with Christian Gardner (C/JO/2983) also from Perth.
Charnotes: No details about accusations.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery involved in investigation. Merser applied to presbytery to be put to trial as she claimed she had been slandered by a local man. Presbytery note that the justice depute, Mr Alex Colville, to be contacted. Last entry records that witness deposition produced (no details) but no indication about next step.

Notes: recorded as a vagabond in the presbytery records.
Charnotes: First in trouble with the presbytery for charming, although no details given about what kind of charming she carried out.
FolkNotes: entry records that she was accused of 'turning the fyne'?
PretrialNotes: Appears to have been fugitive in 1607 and then again in 1627, so presumably she had returned to the parish at some point. First note records her as a charmer but the later one notes that she is dilated for both charming and witchcraft

Notes: I have recorded the accused as female because of the patronymic nein. Dod is also short for George so her name may be nein George. It is likely that she was Gaelic speaking but the records give no indication of this or her ethnic origin.
Charnotes: Very little information but the accused was consulted by 1 other to carry out a charm so that they would get the profit back from 'the danke' which was formerly theirs.
DiseaseNotes: Consulted by 2 others to help them get profit back from property that was previously theirs.
PretrialNotes: Called by the presbytery to answer charges but did not appear.

Notes: Probably Gaelic speaking but no reference to ethnic origin in records.  Unable to modernise the surname.
PretrialNotes: Called before presbytery in 1672. Seems to have cursed and shouted at one of the ministers and to have been 'mala fama' for witchcraft. 10/7/1672 ordained to be publicly rebuked at this time, but no further referrals.

Notes: Scalloway was the contemporary name for Shetland presbytery, also called Lerwick.
Charnotes: Accused appears to have been refused alms but also consulted for healing advice. The whole family appear to have been unpopular and asking for charity.
FolkNotes: Accused appears to have advised a man to go to Sandness church, and sit in the dark and smoke some tobacco and he would be cured of a sickness, which he claimed had been caused by being given a banock by one of the Ratter sisters.
DiseaseNotes: She had asked for some corn, which was refused, Told the person that she had got corn from her neighbour the previous year and the neighbour had a very good crop. Implied threat to the crop.
OtherChargesNotes: Presbytery notes that the accused was declared as a 'deluder and abuser of the people'.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery investigated and questioned the suspect and witnesses. Case referred to Mr John Mitchell but no further details. Accused had been earned to leave Calvester.

Notes: Scalloway was contemporary name for Shetland presbytery, also known as Lerwick.
Charnotes: The family seems to have been unpopular and asking for alms, which were refused.
FolkNotes: Witnesses claimed she cursed a man saying 'God should swarfin his body and his ground' and later the man's body decayed. Swarf - to faint or swoon. Also told family of sick woman who was having blood let that this would not help her. Woman later died.
DiseaseNotes: Accused appears to have argued/cursed her neighbours after disputes. Later sickness/death blamed on her. Refused alms, child of house took ill and died - witnesses claimed he had a 'blue weed' (?fever).
OtherChargesNotes: Charged with being a 'deluder and abuser of the people'.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery investigated and questioned the suspect and witnesses. Details referred to Mr John Mitchell Steward of Shetland, but no further details.

Notes: Scalloway was the contemporary name for Sheltand presbytery, also known as Lerwick.
Charnotes: She was investigated at the same time as the Ratter family, and appears to have been unpopular because she asked for charity.
FolkNotes: Cursed people but no record of what she said.
DiseaseNotes: Asked if she was a witch, but denied accusation. Was refused lodgings, later the woman of the house took bad dreams and was out of her wits. Watson agreed that she cursed people if they wronged her.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused was charged as being a 'deluder and abuser of the people', in 1708. In 1725 the steward found nothing that would infer the crime of witchcraft but that she was a deluder of the people and he intended to proceed against her.
DefenseNotes: Denied she could be a witch and not know it in 1708.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery investigated, questioned witnesses and the suspect. Had been called before the kirk session of Sandness. Case referred to Mr John Mitchell Steward of Shetland, but no further details.

Notes: Scalloway was the contemporary name for Sheltand presbytery, also known as Lerwick.
Charnotes: She was investigated at the same time as the Ratter family, and appears to have been unpopular because she asked for charity.
FolkNotes: Cursed people but no record of what she said.
DiseaseNotes: Asked if she was a witch, but denied accusation. Was refused lodgings, later the woman of the house took bad dreams and was out of her wits. Watson agreed that she cursed people if they wronged her.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused was charged as being a 'deluder and abuser of the people', in 1708. In 1725 the steward found nothing that would infer the crime of witchcraft but that she was a deluder of the people and he intended to proceed against her.
DefenseNotes: Denied she could be a witch and not know it in 1708.
PretrialNotes: Later trial investigation in 1725. No details of accusations but Mr George Duncan still involved and matter referred to the steward/civil magistrate. Entry records reply from steward stating that he could find nothing that could infer the crime of witchcraft, but that she was a deluder of the people and so he intended to proceed against her.

Notes: Scalloway was contemporary name for Shetland presbytery, also known as Lerwick.
Charnotes: The Ratter family appear to have been very unpopular, asking for alms and arguing. In Andrew's case the list of harm done was more extensive than his sisters.
DiseaseNotes: Accused shared drink with another man at the peat cutting, man later took ill. Animals took ill or born dead after arguments. Refused butter - cow died later. Given alms (some bread) which he threw in fire, the family then had no calves born alive.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused of being a' deluder and abused of the people'.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery investigated case, questioned witnesses and the suspect. They referred matters to Mr John Mitchell Steward of Shetland but no further details.

Notes: Presbytery note that she was from Stranraer presbytery but had no settled parish. ?vagabond.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery called the suspect and charged her but she denied all the charges. They want the Stranraer magistrates to ward her until  her trial. 1/7/1650 dittays drawn up and note that a commission was to be requested. The commissioners who attended the General Assembly were recommended to be in charge of this.

Notes: Presbytery noted that the group of accused came from Old Luce and new Luce.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery noted that ditays against the group of accused were drawn up and a commission for trial was to be requested.

Notes: Presbytery note that the group of suspects were from Old and New Luce.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery noted that dittays against the suspects were drawn up and a commission for trial was to be requested.

Notes: Presbytery note that the group of accused came from Old and New Luce.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery noted that dittays against the suspects were drawn up and a commission for trial was to be requested.

Notes: Presbytery note that the group of suspects came from Old and New Luce.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery recorded that dittays against the accused have been drawn up and a commission for trial was to be requested.

Notes: Presbytery note that the group of accused came from Old Luce and New Luce.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery recorded that dittays against the suspects were drawn up and that a commission for trial was to be requested.

Notes: Presbytery note that the group of suspects came from Old and New Luce.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery recorded that dittays had been drawn up against the accused and that a commission for trial was to be requested.

Charnotes: It seems that Kennedy was consulted to witch another woman to death, but not clear how she did this or if it worked. The consulter claimed that she only did this in order to prove that Kennedy was a witch.
DiseaseNotes: It seems that Kennedy was consulted by another woman to witch 'Mistress Mowat to death' although it is not clear if this worked. Kennedy was promised beef and tobacco if she did it. The consulter got in trouble as well.
PretrialNotes: Kirk session found several scandalous and horrid things and although they tried to get evidence could not get things sufficiently proven. They referred case to presbytery, who advised consulting the King's advocate and the General Assembly. Held in prison for 1 year and eventually released but banished.
TrialNotes: There does not appear to have been any trial as such but after 1 year she was to be released from prison, and kirk session recommended that she was to be banished and put out of town.

Charnotes: Wharrie took the case herself to presbytery. She tied to prove that the witnesses had malice against her. Witnesses claimed that she had cursed them after they had refused to help her with ploughing or prevented her from crossing their land. It seems that the presbytery were not convinced by Wharrie's version but could not really do much with her.
FolkNotes: It was cliamed that she cursed and swore at her victims.
DiseaseNotes: Witnesses claimed she cursed and uttered an 'ill prayer' that a neighbour's wife 'would have many a bloody day'. Also cows would vomit their grass or rowt/rout (bellow) to death. Also wished a man to take the glengore (syphilis).
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Wharrie asked neighbours to help with ploughing. When they refused they claimed she cursed their beasts and ploughs so that they could not use them to plough their own rigs.
PretrialNotes: Wharrie took the case herself to KS and presbytery and claimed she had been slandered. Presbytery investigated, interviewed suspect and witnesses and referred case to synod. By 12/1697 nothing from the synod and a  lawyer in Edinburgh advised there was too much business to consider the accusations further. She was still around in 11/1699 as presbytery noted that nothing had been done about her.

Charnotes: Claimed in Helene Frasser's dittay that Hendersoune was instructed in the pact by Frasser.
DevilNotes: Hendersoune was told to put her hand on her head and foot by Helen Frasser and to 'beteich quhatevir was betwein hir handis to the Devil' and she would want for nothing, but Hendersoune did not confess to this.

Notes: Don't know name of his wife - she was mentioned as Wyf of Moress, see C/JO/3030.
Charnotes: Andro Man claimed that Moress had learned his witchcraft from his wife.

Notes: Bane appears to have been quite old as her daughter (Rogie, C/JO/3035) ,who was also executed, had a daughter-in-law herself. She was also known as Margaret Clerk. Had been charged to attend justice court for 30 years and had not attended so was at least 55 (30+25=55).
Charnotes: Bane's association with Spaldarge seems to have condemned her although Bane herself seems to have named quite a few others.
DevilNotes: Confessed that her sister Spaldarge had taught her all her skill and witchcraft, and inducted her to the devil's service.
MeetingNotes: In Issobell Richie's dittay it was claimed that Issobell had taken Bane to meetings with the devil and other witches, but no detail from Bane herself.
FolkNotes: With her sister Spaldarge, she seems to have had a vision of a headless man, which they claimed predicted the death of a man. Seen paddling in loch on Nuris Day, throwing water and erd and stane (ritual of land ownership) over her shoulders. Took fire peat from one man's house to her own house and later daughter/son (?) of the man died. Predicted the birth of a child. Did not exchange any greeting with a man who later died. Touched boy on both cheeks, later he died.
DiseaseNotes: Claimed with Issobell Richie she performed acts of malefice. Consulted as midwife to help labour pains, which were transferred to other people. Helped with calf not suckling, but later wife took ill.Cursed man after he said she would burn. He drowned.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Accused  of cursing a man who had argued and hit her son, Duncan Gardyne.

Notes: Bane appears to have been quite old as her daughter (Rogie, C/JO/3035) ,who was also executed, had a daughter-in-law herself. She was also known as Margaret Clerk. Had been charged to attend justice court for 30 years and had not attended so was at least 55 (30+25=55).
Charnotes: Bane's association with Spaldarge seems to have condemned her although Bane herself seems to have named quite a few others.
DevilNotes: Confessed that her sister Spaldarge had taught her all her skill and witchcraft, and inducted her to the devil's service.
MeetingNotes: In Issobell Richie's dittay it was claimed that Issobell had taken Bane to meetings with the devil and other witches, but no detail from Bane herself.
FolkNotes: With her sister Spaldarge, she seems to have had a vision of a headless man, which they claimed predicted the death of a man. Seen paddling in loch on Nuris Day, throwing water and erd and stane (ritual of land ownership) over her shoulders. Took fire peat from one man's house to her own house and later daughter/son (?) of the man died. Predicted the birth of a child. Did not exchange any greeting with a man who later died. Touched boy on both cheeks, later he died.
DiseaseNotes: Claimed with Issobell Richie she performed acts of malefice. Consulted as midwife to help labour pains, which were transferred to other people. Helped with calf not suckling, but later wife took ill.Cursed man after he said she would burn. He drowned.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Accused  of cursing a man who had argued and hit her son, Duncan Gardyne.

Notes: Mentioned as having been burnt as a witch in Edinburgh.  Mentioned in Bane's confessions.  She was probably of middling status with the title 'Good wife'.  Unable to modernise surname.
FolkNotes: gave Issobell Richie a magic belt which if it was ?lost (tyne) would cause the death of bearded men. It was claimed that the belt was a sign of the devil.

Notes: also recorded as Elen.
Charnotes: Implicated by assocation with her mother (M. Bane) who was burnt for witchcraft.
FolkNotes: Accused of having caused her daughter-in-law's illness, which was made worse with some milk that was given to her by Rogie's own mother (M. Bane). Was seen to be carrying out some strange ritual of measuring some land and building a cairn of stones and also casting 'yerd and stane' over her shoulder. Erd and stane was a symbolic ritual associated with land ownership. Rogie did not answer the person who saw her carry out the ritual, who then took ill and died. An image of a man, made of soft lead (?wax/clay) was found in her purse.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of having cast an illness onto her daughter-in-law (aided by her mother Margaret Bane). Caused oxen and horse of a male neighbour to run wild and die.
PretrialNotes: Noted to have fled the area for 3 days when her mother was tried in Aberdeen.

MeetingNotes: meeting the same as several others which were ascribed to Margaret Bane. There does not appear to be any evidence from Robbie about the meetings. Bane claimed Robbie went with her mother and they all dacned round the grey stone.
FolkNotes: Accused of having caused the death of a woman by giving her some mutton that Robbie and her mother (Margaret Og) had bewitched. Also accused of having carried out a special ritual (?protective) with her mother. They threw a knife 3 times over a cow while it was at the bull ?to ensure a fertile union.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of having aider her mother bewitch and cause the death of Lady Auchinhuiff by giving her some mutton that was bewitched,
TrialNotes: Jury found her guilty of being a suspicious person and associated with her mother, but they thought it only merited banishment. Refer to justice. According to Spalding she was banished from Aberdeen sheriffdom and 12 miles beyond.

MeetingNotes: meeting the same as several others which were ascribed to Margaret Bane. There does not appear to be any evidence from Robbie about the meetings. Bane claimed Robbie went with her mother and they all dacned round the grey stone.
FolkNotes: Accused of having caused the death of a woman by giving her some mutton that Robbie and her mother (Margaret Og) had bewitched. Also accused of having carried out a special ritual (?protective) with her mother. They threw a knife 3 times over a cow while it was at the bull ?to ensure a fertile union.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of having aider her mother bewitch and cause the death of Lady Auchinhuiff by giving her some mutton that was bewitched,

FolkNotes: Accused of causing illness of a neighbour. Seen carrying a stoup of water while her hair was loose about her ears. The man also claimed to be troubled by a great number of cats - but does not suggest that Sinclair appeared in the shape of a cat.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery recorded that they are to consider accusations of witchcraft against the accused but no further details.
Presbytery to consider accusations of witchcraft but no further details.
Presbytery note that the sheriff-depute had brought accusations against several people suspected of witchcraft. They appear to have been brought to Kirkwall and imprisoned. No further details.
Presbytery note that the sheriff-depute had brought accusations against several people suspected of witchcraft. They appear to have been brought to Kirkwall and imprisoned. No further details.
Presbytery note that the sheriff-depute had brought accusations against several people suspected of witchcraft. They appear to have been brought to Kirkwall and imprisoned. No further details.
Presbytery note that the sheriff-depute had brought accusations against several people suspected of witchcraft. They appear to have been brought to Kirkwall and imprisoned. No further details.

Notes: She was mentioned as having been burnt as a witch. Last name either Culsetter or Cursetter. Marwick has her as a wanderer/vagabond but no way to check this.
FolkNotes: Accused of having spoken a curse, which then caused a man's horse to fall, break its bones and later die. Also claimed to know how to keep a man's health. Take a cog of water, put three straws in it and put it on the back of a sick cow. Then take some water and put it in the cow's mouth, then put an arm down the cow's throat, which will cure a cow. Also accused of throwing water three times for an evil purpose. Was able to locate lost/stolen money. Claimed that she predicted an outbreak of smallpox.
DiseaseNotes: To preserve health carry the bones of a linnet in clothing as a form of talisman.

Notes: She was mentioned as having been burnt as a witch. Last name either Culsetter or Cursetter. Marwick has her as a wanderer/vagabond but no way to check this.
FolkNotes: Accused of having spoken a curse, which then caused a man's horse to fall, break its bones and later die. Also claimed to know how to keep a man's health. Take a cog of water, put three straws in it and put it on the back of a sick cow. Then take some water and put it in the cow's mouth, then put an arm down the cow's throat, which will cure a cow. Also accused of throwing water three times for an evil purpose. Was able to locate lost/stolen money. Claimed that she predicted an outbreak of smallpox.
DiseaseNotes: To preserve health carry the bones of a linnet in clothing as a form of talisman.
PostTrialNotes: Note in presbytery that she had been burnt for witchcraft

Notes: Age estimated as 50+ as she had an adult son who tried to complain about his mother's treatment and accusations. He brought several complaints against the sheriff-depute and the presbytery so seems to have been quite well educated.
Charnotes: The accusations about Paplay come from the questioning of another suspect (Barbara Boundie). No details seem to have come from Paplay herself and her son denied all the charges. Bowndie then claimed that she had been encouraged to name other 'honest' women in return for her own life.
PretrialNotes: Son of suspect and Paply denied the charges. They claimed she had been slandered by Elspeth Culsetter (C/JO/3044) and later by Barbara Bowdie (C/JO/3046). She was told to submit a bill of complaint about the slander. The complaints by son continued until 1645 but no further details of any trial or accusations.

Notes: Age estimated as 50+ as she had an adult son who tried to complain about his mother's treatment and accusations. He brought several complaints against the sheriff-depute and the presbytery so seems to have been quite well educated.
Charnotes: The accusations about Paplay come from the questioning of another suspect (Barbara Boundie). No details seem to have come from Paplay herself and her son denied all the charges. Bowndie then claimed that she had been encouraged to name other 'honest' women in return for her own life.

Notes: Although the investigation and ?trial took place in Orkney Bowndie may have been from Zetland (Shetland) originally. Marwick has her as a wanderer/vagabond but no way to check this.
DevilNotes: Said the devil appeared in several diverse shapes
MeetingNotes: She later denied that she had attended the meeting and dancing at Muness. Her stories seem to have got confused as she later retracted most of it and claimed she had been urged to name others
FolkNotes: Her statement said that she had been speechless for 1 day and people had said she had been taken by the fairies, she denied this. She denied that she was able to identify other witches.
PretrialNotes: Questioned by ministers and elders about previous statements but appears to have denied much of what she had said, particularly in relation to her naming of other accused.

Notes: Although the investigation and ?trial took place in Orkney Bowndie may have been from Zetland (Shetland) originally. Marwick has her as a wanderer/vagabond but no way to check this.
DevilNotes: Said the devil appeared in several diverse shapes
MeetingNotes: She later denied that she had attended the meeting and dancing at Muness. Her stories seem to have got confused as she later retracted most of it and claimed she had been urged to name others
FolkNotes: Her statement said that she had been speechless for 1 day and people had said she had been taken by the fairies, she denied this. She denied that she was able to identify other witches.

Notes: Possibly of midding status.

PretrialNotes: Presbytery note that she is accused of witchcraft but no further details.
Presbytery record that she was accused. Complainers told to re-submit the bill, but no further details.
Presbytery record that a bill of complaint put in about alleged witchcraft. No further details

Notes: Unable to modernise the surname.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery note that a bill of complaint about alleged witchcraft had been submitted. No further details.

Notes: Noted as a stranger in the kirk session records so may have been a vagabond bu no details.
FolkNotes: Accused of being able to locate stolen goods but no details.
PretrialNotes: Summoned for investigation by kirk session but she did not appear and was recorded as fugitive. No further details.

Notes: No date but sometimes in the mid-seventeeth century.
PostTrialNotes: Noted that as she was hanging a black ball of foam formed around her mouth, which was taken as evidence that she as possessed.

DiseaseNotes: Most of the accusations relate to disputes over cows. Neighbours accused her of causing illness and death of cows after arguments. Also one case of healing human.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery interview witnesses about their allegations. They were requested to imprison her by Mr Henry Livingstone but not sure if this happened. No further details.

Notes: The presbytery records are from Stirling but the accused seems to have come from Glendevon, which is in Auchterarder presbytery. Entry recorded her age as iiixx, ?23. She also said she had moved about quite a but from Methill to Perth, then Glendevon.
DevilNotes: She confes ed to meeting the fair folk, then the devil appeared as an angel but also in the form of a human male, who she named. She confessed that the 'fair folk' and the angel offered to protect her if she served them.
MeetingNotes: The meetings were with the 'fair folk' and attended by herself and several others including Richie Graham. There is a lot about food.
FolkNotes: Claimed to have used rowan tree and a piece of a dead person's finger to cure the worm. Fairies offered her food but she refused it. Her husband took ill, then her baby was replaced with a changeling. She refused to feed it and threw it in the fire. She then promised to serve the 'fair folk' in return for her child. Said the saw Richie Graham at meetings with the 'fair folk' as well as several other people. While in prison she was visited by a man and asked to identify who had stolen his cow's milk. The man and the woman that Watsonne identified were questioned by the presbytery.
DiseaseNotes: Accused and confessed to healing a man of the worm using rowan tree.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery investigated and recorded her confession. Decided there was enough grounds to refer her to civil magistrate to be put to an assize. No further details.
TrialNotes: Brethren noted that there were sufficient grounds for her to die according to law, but required civil magistrate to put her to assize.

Notes: Recorded in Stirling presbytery records but parish is in Dunblane presbytery. There is another Marion McNab from Stirling (C/EGD/2399) from 1649. Difference in dates suggest a different person.
Charnotes: The accusations all came from one other woman, although both accused and accuser produced lots of witnesses, and relate to something to do with giving the other woman malt to make her husband's malt improve but not sure if it worked. McNab herself later confessed to knowing how to make a cow accept a calf that did not belong to her. Characterised as neighbourhood dispute since this was the accuser's main reason.
DiseaseNotes: Confessed that she knew how to make a cow accept another calf. Put the skin of the dead calf onto the other calf before the cow licked it. This is a common enough agricultural practice. Presbytery seem to have thought it might be witchcraft.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery investigated over several months. Both sides produced witnesses and eventually they referred her to the provost and bailies of Stirling. There is some mention that she was to be put to an assize but also that she was to be set at liberty. No further details.

DevilNotes: Another woman claimed that there were black dogs at meetings of witches, but Murray said nothing about this.
MeetingNotes: Another woman accused Murray of attending dancing with a group of witches. Murray did not appear to make any statement about this.
DiseaseNotes: Cursed man who later took sick. Also with a woman who died. Told a woman in labour that there were cats in her womb, the woman later died. She agreed that she cursed/argued but denied she caused harm.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: She denied that she had taken away the substance of milk.
PretrialNotes: Kirk made some investigations and questioned Murray and witnesses. No further details.
Some investigations by kirk session but no details.
Some kirk session investigations but no details.

Notes: also spelt Lasoun.
DiseaseNotes: Minister of Dalmeny claimed that Lauson had cursed him while on her bare knees.
PretrialNotes: Kirk made some investigations about accusations that Lauson had cursed the minister from Dalmeny. Not many details. She may have been imprisoned as there is a later entry asking about making a collection to pay for the costs.  Her case was reviewed by the presbytery of Linlithgow.

Notes: May have been from Dalmeny as named as a witch by people from there, but details found in Queensferry South Old kirk session records.
PretrialNotes: Entry in kirk session records that she had been named as a witch by people from Dalmeny. Later entry noted that there was to be a collection to pay the costs of keeping the witchcraft suspects warded so she may have been imprisoned.

Notes: The entry was in Stirling presbytery records as Denny was in Stirling presbytery until 1601.
Charnotes: Accused of observing the Lord's Supper in a Catholic way, although she denied this. No other details of any witchcraft.
FolkNotes: Seems to have been accused of observing the Lord's supper in a papistical way. She denied all charges.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery investigated and questioned witnesses. She denied accusations. Later local sheriff was requested to raise a commission for trial. No details if this was done.

Notes: Appears to have been from Kincardine-in-Menteith as noted as having been tried there.
Charnotes: No information about Murray herself but mentioned in a slander case. Woman was slandered that she had consulted Murray who was a suspect of witchcraft. The presbytery noted that Murray had not been convicted of witchcraft at her trial and the case against the other woman was dismissed.
TrialNotes: Entry in presbytery records that she was not convicted at her trial.

Notes: Claimed she met the devil 20 years before (20+25=45)
MeetingNotes: Claimed she met the devil at neighbour's house, in the little chalrmer (room), where they shared some wine. Other women present.
CaseNotes: A group of people (including Garner) appear to have been investigated and recorded in the kirk session records. A further 2 were identifed by a pricker but no details about them
PretrialNotes: Kirk session interview and question accused and witnesses. She named other accused witch.

CaseNotes: There seems to have been a group (including Boswell) investigated. Another 2 were identified by pricker but no details.
There seems to have been a group (including Boswell) investigated. Another 2 were identified by pricker but no details.
PretrialNotes: She was named by Issoble Garner then named 4 more women.
TrialNotes: Entry in kirk session records, 7/8/1649 that Boswell had been 'fyllied' (found guilty) by an assize.

DevilNotes: Confessed that she had carnal relations with the devil and he was as 'cold as ice'.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of causing the death of a child.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused of causing the death of a child but not of child murder.
CaseNotes: Part of a group (including Potter) who were investigated. Another 2 were identified by pricker but no details

DevilNotes: Confessed that she had carnal relations with the devil and he was as 'cold as ice'.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of causing the death of a child.
OtherChargesNotes: Accused of causing the death of a child but not of child murder.
CaseNotes: Part of a group (including Potter) who were investigated. Another 2 were identified by pricker but no details
PretrialNotes: Investigated by the kirk session and recorded as having had a trial. KS notes that those imprisoned were to be searched but there are no details about if this was done.
TrialNotes: Entry in kirk session on 7/8/1649 notes that she was fyllied (found guilty).

DevilNotes: Confessed that she made a covenant with the devil
CaseNotes: Named in a group (including Lodge) who were investigated and tried at Dysart. The accusations stemmed from one and spread out. Another 2 were identified by a pricker but few details.

DevilNotes: Confessed that she made a covenant with the devil
CaseNotes: Named in a group (including Lodge) who were investigated and tried at Dysart. The accusations stemmed from one and spread out. Another 2 were identified by a pricker but few details.
PretrialNotes: Investigated by kirk session and named several others. KS notes that a witch pricker was to search those imprisoned but not clear if this happened to her, as this was after her guilty verdict.
TrialNotes: Entry in kirk session records that she was fyllied (found guilty).

CaseNotes: A number of people were investigated by the kirk session, some were found guilty, others searched for the mark but the fate of most is unknown.
A number of people were investigated by the kirk session, some were found guilty, others searched for the mark but the fate of most is unknown.
PretrialNotes: Investigated by kirk session. Appears to have confessed at some point, but few details. Also ?retracted confession at later date.

Notes: 15 years before was accused of causing malefice/sickness (15+25=40)
DevilNotes: Was searched and mark seems to have been found, but no details.
FolkNotes: She was requested to take the sickness off a child, who it was thought she had made ill.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of having made a child ill after a dispute and requested to restore the child's health by its mother.
CaseNotes: A group including (Burt) were investigated by kirk session. Another 2 were identified by pricker but few details.

Notes: 15 years before was accused of causing malefice/sickness (15+25=40)
DevilNotes: Was searched and mark seems to have been found, but no details.
FolkNotes: She was requested to take the sickness off a child, who it was thought she had made ill.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of having made a child ill after a dispute and requested to restore the child's health by its mother.
CaseNotes: A group including (Burt) were investigated by kirk session. Another 2 were identified by pricker but few details.
PretrialNotes: Investigated by kirk session and ordered to be imprisoned. Searched for Devil's mark.

Charnotes: Demonic included as KS noted he had been searched.
DevilNotes: KS records that a mark was found on him but no details.
MeetingNotes: Male witness told kirk session that Quhyt had been drinking in Kirkcaldy although there does not seem to have been any demonic involvement in this drinking sesssion.
CaseNotes: Part of a group who were investigated by kirk session. Another 3 were identified by pricker.
PretrialNotes: Investigated by kirk session, searched for mark and accused by another man of having been drinking in Kirkcaldy. No details of any other accusations.

Notes: Possibly the same as Margaret Young C/EGD/1299.
Charnotes: No details but witch pricker claimed to find devil's mark.
DevilNotes: KS notes that she was searched and a mark found but no details.
CaseNotes: Indentified by witch pricker. There was bigger group who named each other. Witch pricker was then employed and identified some of the group and 3 others.
PretrialNotes: Searched by pricker and may have been imprisoned. No further details.

Charnotes: Devil's mark found by witch pricker so demonic included.
DevilNotes: Searched for mark but no details.
CaseNotes: Identified by a witch pricker. Larger group named each other. Witch pricker then employed and identified marks on 3 others.
PretrialNotes: Searched for mark and may have been imprisoned but no other details.

Notes: Writing very bad so ?name.
Charnotes: Investigated for use of charms
DiseaseNotes: Investigated for use of charms but no details.
PretrialNotes: Investigated by KS and referred to presbytery and/or banished. Writing very difficult.

Charnotes: Charges appear to relate to charming rituals, which may have gone wrong. There is no mention of any demonic elements.
FolkNotes: Used a belt as part of a healing ritual (met the belt).
PretrialNotes: Investigated for charming (first entry includes reference to other charmers who do not seem to have been pursued). Eventually recorded as being warded.

Presbytery ordered the Stirling ministers to investigate her case. They wanted them to try and examine the accused. Note that she had confessed but no details. No details about accusations or outcome.
Presbytery requested that ministers in Stirling  try and examine the accused. She appears to have been imprisoned and made a confession, but no details. No details of trial, accusations or outcome.

Notes: The note concerning his case was in Stirling presbytery records but he seems to have come from Port of Menteith in Dunblane presbytery.
Charnotes: This is all about healing but the presbytery referred to it as witchcraft.
FolkNotes: Claimed to heal the gut using water and butter.
DiseaseNotes: Claimed he healed the gut and learned it from another called (illegible) Campbell. His mother could cure broken bones?
PretrialNotes: The presbytery was requested by the Laird of Keir  to investigate accusations of witchcraft (really healing). No further details about trial or outcome.
Presbytery questioned her over a few years about her use of charms. Initially ordered to stop using them but did not do so. Accusation then changed to witchcraft but no further details.
TrialNotes: Appears to have been publicly excommunicated.

Charnotes: Appear to have been about using charms, which later became accusation of witchcraft, but no details.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery questioned her mother over some years about charming. By 8/1615 both were implicated and the accusations included witchcraft, but no details. Presbytery record that she confessed.
TrialNotes: Appears to have been threatened with excommunication.

Notes: Recorded as an indweller in Stirling.
Charnotes: There seems to have been quite a lot of healing or failed healing but a lot of the accusations seem to have involved neighbourhood disputes. Most of the witnesses were men.
DiseaseNotes: Descriptions of healing rituals but most of the accusations involved either failed healing, transfer of sickness or causing illness after dispute.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery questioned the accused and several witnesses but no details of trial or outcome.

Notes: Suspected of being a witch for 30 years (30+25=55)
Charnotes: Named by Jonet Tailzour but many witnesses gave evidence about her malefice, which often resulted from disputes and insults.
DiseaseNotes: She seems to have cursed and quarrelled quite a bit and accusations revolved around perceived harm after arguments.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Accused of harming goods and gear after insults and disputes.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery interviewed accused and several witnesses. Had been identified by Jonet Tailzour. No details of trial or outcome.

Charnotes: She was noted as being consulted for childbirth, so was most likely involved in midwifery.  But we don’t have any specific information about Drummond other than what Paton said in her trial.

Notes: might be young and unmarried, described as a 'bonnie lass'.
DevilNotes: She was named as the woman with the black pock at several Devil's meetings.
MeetingNotes: accused of being at several Witches' meetings with a black pock, and using meal from the pock to kill children.

Notes: Name also spelt as Tawis.
PretrialNotes: Fled from justice and goods to be escheat. Aberdeen provost and bailles asked the church elders if they knew anything about the accused. They claimed they knew nothing about her whereabouts.

Charnotes: Accused of malefice after revenge but cleared of charges. Also seems to have consulted Margaret Bane.
FolkNotes: Predicted or threatened that a man's children would not live, because he would not die. Her prediction came true,
DiseaseNotes: Threatened a man that his children would not live, because he would not marry her. Also accused of taking revenge on her previous employer who had taken some of her belongings after she left his house.

PretrialNotes: Order to be apprehended.

Notes: This may be the same as Margaret Reoch C/EGD/868.
Charnotes: Seems to also have been in trouble for sexual misconduct and had been excommunicated in the past.
DevilNotes: Confessed that the devil appeared in her bed between herself and her ?harlot, William Richie. Also said that if she was to die as a witch then he should do so as well because if she was a witch then he was one too.
FolkNotes: Seen hugging the corners of a man's house at dawn. He later took ill and died. Prophesied that a man who had taken on a property would lose it all. Seen to have thrown stones in water, which then appeared to dance. No details about what they were for. Seen to turn the bowl of her shears 3 times in the mouth of her sheep.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of causing a man's illness and death. She was seen hugging the corners of his house at dawn. Seen to have metted a sheep, the threw water between her feet and into the sheep's face. The sheep died.
PretrialNotes: Order to be apprehended. Investigated by the presbytery.

Notes: Possibly same one who consulted Tibbie Smart in 1586, c/la/3140
PretrialNotes: Order to be apprehended.

FolkNotes: Accused of taking three hairs from her cow's tail, cutting it into pieces and putting them in the trough. Later her cow gave milk but her neighbour's did not. Accused of taking a calf under her arm to charm it.  She told a woman to bury clippings from the front hooves in her yard. Carried a newborn calf three times round its mother.
DiseaseNotes: Took a calf under her arm, then (?) told woman to bury clippings from the front hooves in her yard.
PretrialNotes: Order to be apprehended. Presbytery investigated the accusations and decided there was not suffifcient cause to take it further. However they seem to have passed the matter over to the judge to decide if there should be a trial.

Notes:
25+8=33.
From the parish of Coldstone and Logie-Mar.
FolkNotes: Gave a woman a 'tabblet' and a ring to use as a love magic talisman.
DiseaseNotes: Her son claimed that his mother had promised that her magic would protect him (it did not as he was hanged). Also cured a man but transferred the sickness to his sister. Stole livestock.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Stole a man's livestock and killed some his other beasts.
PretrialNotes: Investigation held by kirk session by commission from the provost and baillies of Aberdeen.

Notes: No details about accusations. No commission issued but the presbytery banished the suspect.
CaseNotes: There seems to have been others accused at the same time, but not named (C/JO/3106).
PretrialNotes: Presbytery had received some accusations. Synod advised them to refer case to magistrates, who in turn wrote to the Lord's advocate. Advocate would not issue commission. Presbytery unable to do any more but suspects noted as having been banished.
TrialNotes: She does not seem to have been officially tried, but she was banished by the Presbytery

Notes: 25 + 5 =30 years. Accustions go bac 5 years.
Charnotes: Although accused of variety of rituals, which caused harm to others but from which he benefited, but charges were not sufficient to advance to trial.
FolkNotes: Accused of using rituals involving taking nine handfuls of earth from one man's rig and throwing on to his own. Accused of going withershins about a kiln in which he was drying corn. Said to have thrown water on the threshhold of a neighbour's house causing his servant to flee.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Accused of taking the milk from another woman's cow. Accused of measuring (metting) another man's crops with a white wand and stiking them 9 times so that nothing would grow.
PretrialNotes: Local presbytery investigated accusations and decided that they were not sufficient. However, it seems that the matter was to be remitted to a trial if the judges thought it sufficient. Not clear what happened next.

FolkNotes: Accused of healing a woman of the fevers with a sleeve and thread. Said to have brought a burning coal out her house at Hallowe'en and buried it in her yard.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of causing the death of a man after an argument.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery investigated the accusations and decided that there was not sufficient evidence to pursue further. However it seems that it was remitted to the judges to decide whether to go for a trial.

Charnotes: Charges dropped as no evidence, although she was was cautioned to keep out of trouble.
PretrialNotes: Had been named by Margaret Bane but ivestigators find nothing and charges dropped.

Charnotes: Mother was accused of malefice but there are no specific accusations against the daughter.
PretrialNotes: Local investigations by kirk sessions.
No details but cautioner for trial named.

Notes: Name spelt Milnetown in APS
Charnotes: Petition to parliament from Earl of Haddington. He claimed that witchcraft was increasing in his lands and had imprisoned some of the suspects. He also claimed that two of them were accused of robbery as well.
PretrialNotes: In 1649, process note from the locality to the Privy Council to justify their request to have their specific commission widened to a general commission so they can try all those named, confessed and arrested.  He had been denounced and arrested.  Although he had been named he had not been apprehended or searched by 4/1661. Noted as being fugitive for witchcraft in Humbie KS records.

Notes: Name spelt Milnetown in APS
Charnotes: Petition to parliament from Earl of Haddington. He claimed that witchcraft was increasing in his lands and had imprisoned some of the suspects. He also claimed that two of them were accused of robbery as well.

PretrialNotes: Noted as being fugitive in Humbie KS records in 1661.

Charnotes: appears to have been imprisoned for witchcraft and released. Kirk session the note that she had practised charming.
PretrialNotes: The kirk session recorded that she had been imprisoned but appeared to have been released. She was not attending the church and the church authorities then noted concerns about her use of charming. No further details.

Group of women appear to have been named by Janet Fairlie (C/EGD/1607). They were investigated and presbytery advised they were examined by the pricker. They were imprisoned and kirk session requested witnesses etc. No further details after 12/1649.

Group of women appear to have been named by Janet Fairlie (C/EGD/1607). They were investigated and presbytery advised they were examined by the pricker. They were all 'glad' to be examined this way, according to the KS. They were imprisoned and kirk session requested witnesses etc. No further details after 12/1649.

Charnotes: Demonic included as she was searched by the pricker. Appears to have confessed to charming.
PretrialNotes: Group of women appear to have been named by Janet Fairlie (C/EGD/1607). They were investigated and presbytery advised they were examined by the pricker. They were all 'glad' to be examined this way, according to the KS. They were imprisoned and kirk session requested witnesses etc. No further details after 12/1649.

Group of women appear to have been named by Janet Fairlie (C/EGD/1607). They were investigated and presbytery advised they were examined by the pricker. Charnotes: demonic included as she was searched by a pricker
PretrialNotes: Group of women appear to have been named by Janet Fairlie (C/EGD/1607). They were investigated and presbytery advised they were examined by the pricker. They were all 'glad' to be examined this way, according to the KS. They were imprisoned and kirk session requested witnesses etc. No further details after 12/1649.

Group of women appear to have been named by Janet Fairlie (C/EGD/1607). They were investigated and presbytery advised they were examined by the pricker. They were all 'glad' to be examined this way, according to the KS. They were imprisoned and kirk session requested witnesses etc. No further details after 12/1649.

Charnotes: demonic included as she was searched by the pricker
PretrialNotes: Group of women appear to have been named by Janet Fairlie (C/EGD/1607). They were investigated and presbytery advised they were examined by the pricker. They were all 'glad' to be examined this way, according to the KS. They were imprisoned and kirk session requested witnesses etc. No further details after 12/1649.

Charnotes: demonic included as she was searched by a pricker, also she confessed to charming
PretrialNotes: Group of women appear to have been named by Janet Fairlie (C/EGD/1607). They were investigated and presbytery advised they were examined by the pricker. They were all 'glad' to be examined this way, according to the KS. They were imprisoned and kirk session requested witnesses etc. No further details after 12/1649.

Charnotes: denomic included as she was searched by a pricker
PretrialNotes: Group of women appear to have been named by Janet Fairlie (C/EGD/1607). They were investigated and presbytery advised they were examined by the pricker. They were all 'glad' to be examined this way, according to the KS. They were imprisoned and kirk session requested witnesses etc. No further details after 12/1649.

Notes: Unable to modernise the last name.
PretrialNotes: No details but note that she was imprisoned in the tolbooth for witchcraft.

DevilNotes: Pact implied as she was searched but does not appear to have confessed to any aspects of pact.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of having caused the death of a neighbour's horse.
PretrialNotes: Accusations brought before the KS. Later she was named be another confessing witch (Issobell Fergussone C/EGD/381), was searched for the mark and then imprisoned to await further trial. No more details

DevilNotes: Pact implied as she was searched but does not appear to have confessed to any aspects of pact.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of having caused the death of a neighbour's horse.

Charnotes: Denomic included as she was searched for the mark but does not appear to have confessed anything.
DevilNotes: pact implied as she was searched but no confession of any features of pact.
PretrialNotes: Named as a witch by John McMullan (a confesing warlock). They were searched for the mark.

Charnotes: Denomic included as she was searched for the mark.
DevilNotes: Pact implied as she was searched for the mark.
PretrialNotes: Was named by a confessing warlock, John McMillan, and was then searched for the mark. Does not appear to have confessed.

Charnotes: Demonic included as she was searched for the mark
DevilNotes: pact implied as she was searched for the mark. McMillan also said she had attended meetings with the devil. Wilson denied all the accusations.
PretrialNotes: Was named by a confessing warlock, John McMillan and  searched for the mark. Imprisoned to await further trial. No further details. She denied that she had anything to do with him or the devil.

Charnotes: demonic included as she was searched for the mark
DevilNotes: pact implied as she was searched for the mark and McMillan claimed she had attended meetings, She denied the accusations.
PretrialNotes: Named by a confessing warlock, John McMillan. She was searched for the mark and imprisoned, to await further trial. No more details. She denied the accusations.

TrialNotes: Found guilty on most items of her dittay but acquitted on others.

Notes: Not sure if this is an alias or name, but no  first name recorded. Graycoat may not have been from Thurso as KS gives no indication of disciplining her, just that Graycoat was suspect of witchcraft.
Charnotes: Church records disciplining a woman for consulting her for advice about her sick husband.

PretrialNotes: KS noted that she had confessed. No further details.

Notes: Name might be Seith.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of causing a cow to stop giving milk
PretrialNotes: KS recorded as having investigated accusations. Presbytery noted that she had not been sufficiently cleared and called her to appear before the ministers. She denied charges. Eventually the ministers asked the provost/baillies of Cupar to take her off their hands and imprison her. They refused. The presbytery wanted to apply to Committee of Estates for commission.

Notes: Name might be Seith.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of causing a cow to stop giving milk

Notes: Unable to modernise the surname.
PretrialNotes: Presbytery noted that she had made a voluntary confession and ordered her to appear - no further details.

Notes: She may have been from Abdie or Ceres. The presby records are not clear. Her victim appears to have worked in her house at one time so socioeconomic status has been estimated at middling.
Charnotes: The description looks like it could have developed into a demonic possession style case.
DevilNotes: Accused by a young man (18 years old) of having cast an illness on him after he said her goodame was a witch. Claimed he took fits when he was unable to speak, and that she appeared to him in his bed. Also said he saw her with other woman and a man, that they put a bridle on him and rode him like a horse. The church seemed a bit dubious about this, she denied it all and was absolved.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of having caused a young man to take fits which caused him to speak in tongues, then be unable to speak or stand unaided. The church repeatedly asked him if he dreamt this.
CaseNotes: The process notes record that she was investigated on 26/2/1699 and 25/4/1699.  But she was absolved on 14/3/1699.  These dates don't match up, but this is how they were entered in the Presbytery minute books.  It could be that the final date was the date that the earlier proceedings were recorded.  We don't know.
PretrialNotes: Investigated by KS and presbytery. Witnesses interviewed but decided there was nothing in the charges and she was absolved.

Notes: Saltpreston is Prestonpans parish
DevilNotes: It was claimed that she had confessed to pact and renunciation of baptism.
PretrialNotes: It was claimed the suspect had confessed to pact and renunciation of baptism.

Notes: Daughter was an accused witch.  The unknown witch most likely did not have the last name of Grahame.
Her name was fed to Hammilton during his investigation as a known witch he should denounce.  She was already dead (of natural causes) when he denounced her.
Charnotes: She was denounced by Hammilton, but she was already dead.  She was described as having been 'delate to be ane witche'.
denounced by Alexander Hammilton (c/egd/166)
DevilNotes: called to the meeting by a spirit.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: burned down a mill; destroyed ships during the herring drove.

Charnotes: denounced by Alexander Hammilton (c/egd/166)
DevilNotes: called to the meeting by a spirit.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: burned down a mill; destroyed ships during the herring drove.

Notes: Husband a portioner.
Charnotes: She was a pawn to get Katherine Ross, Lady Fowlis

Notes: He is a servant to the servitor of Francis, Earl of Bothwell
Charnotes: He and Ninane Chirnside were declared rebels for failing to appear on charges of witchcraft and treason
CaseNotes: No trial process, the servitor and his servant (unknown Nesbitt)failed to appear personally before king James VI at Holyrood palace on 6 March 1591 to answer charges of witchcraft and treason.

Notes: Cook to Colene Eviot of Balhousie
Charnotes: Consulted a witch for seduction.
FolkNotes: He tried to use witchcraft and potions to seduce the daughter of his employer, 'by the dobbing on ane apple and ifusing of ane portioun of his awn natur in it' and getting her to eat it, laced her drink with 'Spaniyie fleis, gave her a drink made with daphindillie, then consulted a witch.  None of this worked so he raped her.
CaseNotes: More a case about rape and consulting, but provides interesting information about the services and potions provided by 'witches'.
TrialNotes: He was tried for rape and consulting a witch, he confessed and was still found innocent, but this verdict was over turned by the Privy Council after a complaint dated 21/5/1601.

PretrialNotes: Reviewed by Patrick Archibishop of Glasgow and then shown to the Privy council.

Notes: The original reference had this person listed as being from Moray.  Moray was both a very large region and a county.  The county was the same as Elgin.  Therefore unless we have other indications of the suspect being from a specific county other than Elgin, we have changed 'Moray' to 'Elgin'.

CaseNotes: 'In expenses sustenit in the burning of the witche of Barnweill, in candillis, hir meit and drink, pyk barrellis, colis, rosat, heddir, treis and uther necessaris, £7, 3s. 8d.'
PostTrialNotes: 'In expenses sustenit in the burning of the witche of Barnweill, in candillis, hir meit and drink, pyk barrellis, colis, rosat, heddir, treis and uther necessaris, £7, 3s. 8d.'

CaseNotes: Payment for the messanger, 'twice summoning the assize in Kyle, Carrick and Cunningham' (£7).  And for burning - 'for coles, cordis, tar barrellis and uther graith that burnit Mareoun Greiff witche, £4, 4s.'
PostTrialNotes: Payment for the messanger, 'twice summoning the assize in Kyle, Carrick and Cunningham' (£7).  And for burning - 'for coles, cordis, tar barrellis and uther graith that burnit Mareoun Greiff witche, £4, 4s.'
