Notes: Her father was a miller.
Charnotes: She consulted with Reid to destroy David Libbertoun a burgess baxter in Edinburgh.  I think Reid was hired to remove a bewitchment, he seemed to be taking off lots of illnesses in the Chrystie household, and guiding the attack on D. Libberton for the Chrysties not himself.
FolkNotes: Reid prepared an enchanted piece of flesh for her to lay under her enemies stable door.
DiseaseNotes: She supposedly wanted to get someone, and used Reid to do it.  Reid was a healer, so this may have been somekind of unwitching thing, because lots of members of her family underwent healing rituals from Reid.

DevilNotes: According to Patrick Lowrie she was presented with a hairbelt in the shape of a devil's claw by Helena McBurnie, the 'devilish spirit woman' according to P. Lowrie.
MeetingNotes: Witches' meetings described by P. Lowrie, especially one on Lowdon Hill as well as the kirk and at the shore.
FolkNotes: She was presented with a hairbelt (in the shape of a Devil's claw) from the spirit woman Helena McBurnie according to P. Lowrie, and involved in meetings at Halloween and Whitsunday.
CaseNotes: This Ayr Jonet Hunter was a different person from the one accused of witchcraft who was from Dundonald and was executed before 1604.  Appeared before kirk session for punishment for being a viscious woman and a slandered but no reference to any witchcraft. Disregard the Ayr Kirk session minutes.
PretrialNotes: She was described as 'umquhile Jonet Hunter, ane notorious Witche, and quha was execute to the daith for Sorcerie and Witchcraft'.

DevilNotes: According to Patrick Lowrie she was presented with a hairbelt in the shape of a devil's claw by Helena McBurnie, the 'devilish spirit woman' according to P. Lowrie.
MeetingNotes: Witches' meetings described by P. Lowrie, especially one on Lowdon Hill as well as the kirk and at the shore.
FolkNotes: She was presented with a hairbelt (in the shape of a Devil's claw) from the spirit woman Helena McBurnie according to P. Lowrie, and involved in meetings at Halloween and Whitsunday.
CaseNotes: This Ayr Jonet Hunter was a different person from the one accused of witchcraft who was from Dundonald and was executed before 1604.  Appeared before kirk session for punishment for being a viscious woman and a slandered but no reference to any witchcraft. Disregard the Ayr Kirk session minutes.

MeetingNotes: Said by Beigis Tod that she was part of a group that met the Devil at Beigis' house for drinks.  They cast a cat to the Devil.  They met in the thorns near the iron gate of Seton.  Also did a cat ritual at the gate of Seton.  All according to B. Tod.
FolkNotes: According to Tod she did rituals with a cat and named it Margaret.

Notes: Chrystie would not have been her own name.
Charnotes: She consulted with Reid to destroy David Libbertoun a burgess baxter in Edinburgh.  I think Reid was hired to remove a bewitchment, he seemed to be taking off lots of illnesses in the Chrystie household, and guiding the attack on D. Libberton for the Chrystie's not himself.
FolkNotes: Reid claimed that he prepared an enchanted piece of flesh for her to lay under her enemies' stable door.
DiseaseNotes: She supposedly wanted to get someone, and used Reid to do it.  Reid was a healer, so this may have been somekind of unwitching thing, because lots of members of her family underwent healing rituals from Reid.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: It was said that she wanted Reid to harm crops and animals.

Notes: Mother's-brother's son to Alesoun Piersoun.  Described as a great scholar and doctor of medicine.  Pierson lived with him for a time.
Charnotes: He was described as a doctor of medicine.  Although there is a lot of information about him, it is all from the trial of Alesoun Pierson, not from his own trial.  Therefore the characterisation has to be implicated by another witch, but some detail is provided in the notes fields.
FolkNotes: According to Alison Pierson his father was the king's smith.  He was taken away from his father by one man of Egypt, one gyant, while he was a bairn.  He lived their for 12 years.  His father supposedly died because he opened a 'preist-buik' and looked at it.  Perhaps Pierson was learning from him while she lived with him at the age of 12.  The fairies told Pierson that Sympsoune was one of them.  Pitcairn quotes the 'Legend of the Bischop of St. Androis' for his case.  He told Pierson that he had been carried away (out of middle earth) with the Fairies and that when a whirlwind was heard that was them.  Mention of a tithe to hell.
DiseaseNotes: He supposedly cured Pierson when she lost the power of her hand and foot.

Notes: no modern last name.
Charnotes: He was part of a large group of known witches and assistants to Lady fowlis' supposed plot to destroy members of her family.  This is a a very standard type of early case where witchcraft was used to alter inheretance of land, titles, and property
FolkNotes: Katherine Ross, sent Christiane Roiss to him to purchase some elfshot. No details from McNilland.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick hunt, that revovled around witchcraft and treason.
DevilNotes: Said by Fean to have met the devil as a black man.
MeetingNotes: Said by others to have been at a meeting at sea, which was like a party with good wine and ale. Also it was claimed by Fean that he was at the North Berwick kirk.
FolkNotes: Claimed by others that he was involved in rituals at halloween.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Claimed by others that he was part of the witches' crew that wanted to destroy king James VI and Queen Ann by sinking their ships.

Notes: also spelled Lenchop.  No modern last name
Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: Said by others to have been at a meeting on the ship which was like a party at sea with good wine and ale.  She was supposedly part of the conspiracy treason plot, planned the first assault against the Queen's ship.  She was in charge of a letter and some cat rituals to raise wind. Attended a meeting at the saltpans.
FolkNotes: Said to have used a cat in rituals.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Said to have been involved in trying to raise winds and storms to sink the royal ships.

Notes: name also spelled Lenchop.  No modern last name.
Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: Part of the group accused of treason at North Berwick, this one was supposedly at the early planning sessions involving cat rituals, which took place at the shore.
FolkNotes: Said to have been involved in using a cat in a ritual.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Said by others to have been involved in trying to raise storms and winds to sink the royal ships.

Notes: No modern last name
Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
DevilNotes: Others said she met the devil as a 'mekle black man'
MeetingNotes: See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more details about the meeting at North Berwick kirk.
FolkNotes: Others said she was involved in rituals with corpse and corpse powder and attended meetings at Halloween.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: Sampson said he was part of the planning in the conspiracy to sink Queen Anne's ships on the way from Denmark and was at a meeting at the saltpans.
FolkNotes: Sampson said he was involved in rituals using corpse, glass, salt and thread.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Sampson said he was involved in trying to raise storms/winds to sink the royal ships.
CaseNotes: Pobably the same guy as Johnne Gordoun (c/egd/145), but the two names are both mentioned in Agnes Sampsoune's trial and we don't have enough to merge them.

MeetingNotes: Sampson said she was part of the planning in the conspiracy to sink Queen Anne's ships on the way from Denmark. It was claimed she was at the meeting at the saltpans. See Agnes Sampson's case for description of North Berwick meeting (c/egd/63).
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Sampson said she was involved in trying to raise storms/winds to sink the royal ships.

Notes: She was one of 'twa wyfeis callit Stobbeis'
Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: Sampson said that this person was involved in the coordinated effort with the witches who were at the pans.  They threw the cat into the water at the pier-head.  Part of the planning to destroy the kings ships.
FolkNotes: Sampson said they participated in that throwing of cats into the sea to create wind.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Sampson said they were involved in trying to raise winds/storms to sink the royal ships.

Notes: She was one of the 'twa wyfeis callit Stobbeis'
Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: Sampson said this person was part of the coordinated effort with the witches who were at the Pans and was at the meeting at the shore.  They cast the cat into the water at the pier head.  Part of the planning to destroy the Queen's ships.
FolkNotes: Sampson said involved in the throwing of a cat into the sea ritual to raise storms.
OtherMaleficiaNotes: Sampson said she/he was involved in raising storms/wind to sink the royal ships.

MeetingNotes: Sampson said she was the meeting at the kirk of Garvett (Garvald?) by east burnside.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
DevilNotes: Sampson said she met the devil as a man.
MeetingNotes: Sampson said she was at meetings at the road between Cowsland and Carberry and at Foulsruther.
FolkNotes: Sampson said she was involved in rituals using corpse, glass, salt and thread.

Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
MeetingNotes: Sampson said she was at meetings at the Kirk of Natoun (?Newton) and the road between Carberry and Cowsland.
FolkNotes: Sampson said she was involved in rituals with corpse and corpse powder.

DiseaseNotes: Caused an illness by the 'blas of ewill wind' on halloween.

Notes: Her name would not have been Sampson or Sampsoun.
Charnotes: Part of the North Berwick witch hunt.  It involved many people and many accustions about witches meetings, specifically two separate attempts to sink the royal ships.  The first to sink Queen Anne on her way home, second to trouble King James after he went to get her in Denmark.
DevilNotes: Said by her mother and Napier that she met the devil as a 'mekle black man.
MeetingNotes: see Agnes Sampson for description of the North Berwick kirk meeting (c/egd/63).  See also Napier (c/egd/103) for more details about the North Berwick meeting.
FolkNotes: It was claimed by others that she was involved in ritual with corpse and corpse powder, and attended meetings at Halloween.

MeetingNotes: Said by Sampson that he made much mischief on a ship.

Charnotes: Calendar of State Papers records how he was 'pryncipall of the witches heere'. And that he confessed to avoid death.  He was supposedly hired by Bothwell.  Story about the Italian who prophesied about Bothwell's end.  Bowes himself, writer of the letter in Calendar, was also implicated by Grahame and Gellies Duncane for being part of the plot.
MeetingNotes: made much mischief on a ship.
FolkNotes: Also the head of a young calf, newly calfed.
PretrialNotes: Seems to have been examined by the Privy Council 9/4/1591 where he confessed and said it was all at the instigation of Bothwell.  April 1591, King James VI ordered Maitland to make sure Grahame got his ordinary allowance.  Graham conveyed a verbal complaint about his mistreatment in prison to a the Master of Wark who wrote it down and delivered it to the King.  Graham said he was promised better conditions in ward and a servant.
PostTrialNotes: to be executed, recorded in Calendar of Scottish Papers

Charnotes: Calendar of State Papers records how he was 'pryncipall of the witches heere'. And that he confessed to avoid death.  He was supposedly hired by Bothwell.  Story about the Italian who prophesied about Bothwell's end.  Bowes himself, writer of the letter in Calendar, was also implicated by Grahame and Gellies Duncane for being part of the plot.
MeetingNotes: made much mischief on a ship.

DevilNotes: Said by Napier to have met the devil as a black man.

Notes: miller's wife

Notes: She is definitely not related to Earl of Bothwell, she was described as an old indicted witch of 18 years.  Lady Bothwell was not her title, it was a nickname.
DiseaseNotes: Euphemia Makcalyean consulted her for poisoning.

Charnotes: denounced by James Welch
MeetingNotes: Meeting described by another accused witch, no details from Wood herself.  Witches' meeting with James Welch
CaseNotes: Part of the large number of people denounced by James Welch.  He was deemed too young to stand trial so he was imprisoned.  But his confession and some of his denunciations were taken seriously by the authorities.

Notes: she had a grown niece called Margaret Watson.
MeetingNotes: Another accused witch said that she flew to a meeeting on a thorn tree.

Notes: described as poor and seeking alms.
Charnotes: She confessed to being displeased with alms and refusal to help her.

Notes: He was a 'Scottishman' arrested in England, and the King orded him returned to Scotland for trial.  At time of the letter he was in the March of England.
DiseaseNotes: accused of killing his father
CaseNotes: a note in a letter from Robert Bowes to Burghley (13/2/1591).  A second mention of him in another letter from Bowes to Burghley (23/2/1591).  Yet a third mention in letter of the same people (24/3/1591).  He has still not been handed over.  I have not selected a trial type since he was out of the country.

Charnotes: We know almost nothing about this accused witch.
CaseNotes: This witch (sex unspecified), lately in England, testified against Bothwell.

Notes: probably from somewhere near Stirling.
Charnotes: Described as confessing to trying to kill the King when travelling on the water to Dundee to attend a General Assembly meeting, and he named 'others'.
CaseNotes: Mentioned in a reportage about the king.

Charnotes: The record only has witness ratification of dittay items.  Doesn't say what the dittay said or what the witnesses ratefied.
FolkNotes: A woman found a lump of flesh in her bed in the shape of a hand and fell ill.  The same woman hired a woman from Dunblane to cure her with a drink.  A man cam to her for advice about the removal of a bewitchment.  She told the man to grip the suspected witch's coat tail and drink ale with her and ask for his health 3 times for God's sake.  She made bad predictions which came true.
DiseaseNotes: Prayed Malice on a man who made her pregnant and did nothing to help her.  Blair claimed a woman stopped being nice to her after Blair had healed her husband.
PretrialNotes: She was denounced to the minister by a neighbour.
TrialNotes: I think it is the North circuit even though it was bound in with the South and West circuits.  She denied the whole thing.  On an undated list of people from 1658-9 to be arraigned before the justice courts.  Witness list generated 16/3/1658.  She pleaded not guilty

Charnotes: Denunced by Jonat Millar (c/egd/307).
DiseaseNotes: accused of malefices
TrialNotes: I think it’s the North circuit even though it is bound in the part of the book that says south and west.  She plead not guilty.  On an undated list of people from 1658-9 to be arraigned before the justice courts.  Witnesses summond on 18/3/1659.

Charnotes: Denunced by Jonat Millar (c/egd/307).
DiseaseNotes: accused of malefices

Notes: I think this is the same Jennet Hunter from Ormiston who was denoucned by Elpeth Knox on 9/7/1678, so their records have been combined.
CaseNotes: The Haddington porteous roll of delinquent dittays from 8/9/1679  (like the Edinburgh one of the same date) all have the standard tag line of accusations: witchcraft, sorcery and necromancy; and renunciation of baptism and giving themselves over to the Devil, body and soul.

Notes: Joyce had his brother being from Bargarrane.
Charnotes: He was suspected then determined to be a witness not a suspect due to young age.  Complicated case involving numerous accusations of murdering children through magical strangulation and possession of several children.  Much of the evidence was derived from the testimony of children who claimed to be possessed and tormented by witches.  But there was great concern over the murdered children and a murdered minister.  The record describes the physical torment of the possessed children in great detail.  An extraordinary document!
MeetingNotes: confessed to being at three meetings but not to being a witch.  He claimed to have been present at the meeting to torment Christian Shaw, kill the minsiter Mr. John hardie and murder the boy Mathew Park.  He was accused but determined to be a witness not a suspect.
CaseNotes: Mentioned in the closing arguments of the last day of the only group trial to come out of the 1697 Renfrewshire cases.  Accused but not indicted for witchcraft.  Instead he and his brother were witnesses.  Deemed too young to have made a viable pact with the Devil.  Was not indicted with the large group on 13/4/1697 or tried with the seven who actually stood trial on 12/5/1697.
PretrialNotes: Confessed to being at 3 meetings with the Devil and accused others of being there as well.  Was listed in the 19/3/1697 commission in the Privy Council records but nothing seems to have happened to him.
TrialNotes: was accused of witchcraft but never indicted because he was deemed to young to be culpable.  He was mentioned with the group indicted in 13/4/1697

Notes: He is not the same as John Lindsay alias the Bishop.
Charnotes: Complicated case involving numerous accusations of murdering children through magical strangulation and possession of several children.  Much of the evidence was derived from the testimony of children who claimed to be possessed and tormented by witches.  But there was great concern over the murdered children and a murdered minister.  The record describes the physical torment of the possessed children in great detail.  An extraordinary document!
MeetingNotes: There were seven witches' meetings alleged in the Renfrew trials of 1697.  The meetings were said to have taken place in 1696 for the murder of a minister and several infants and children and the tormenting of Christian Shaw and other young people.  The participants supposedly danced, did image magic, met with the devil, and plotted bad things.  The meetings were described by a few people who confessed and several children who claimed to have been present.
FolkNotes: Accused of participating in 6 meetings where wax images with pins were used to enact murder and roasting the wax image was also used to kill and torment people.  One meeting to strangle a child took place at midnight in the kid's bedroom.  Apparently physical charmes made of bone, blood, and hair were found
DiseaseNotes: The group was accused of murdering children by strangulation. children were in fact murdered in this way by someone. Possession symptoms were thrassing,extraordinary strength,bite marks,welts, spitting pins and hair,vomit,and more.Caused possession fits.
CaseNotes: Part of the Renfrew cases of 1697 - one out of seven to make it to trial out of 28+ accused.
PretrialNotes: the commission was read out in the burgh of Renfrew on 18/3/1697.  This case was under a Privy council commission (see PC1/51 p. 136-9) along with most of the people tried at the same time.  There were other Renfrewshire witchcraft suspects tried at different places and times.  I am keeping this as a mixed/central local because the Privy Council maintained very strict control over the proceedings, even though they granted a commission.  For details of the proceedings of Privy Council in this matter see the no named witches case c/la/3235.
TrialNotes: Trial started on 13/4/1697 but was continued until 12/5/1697 it lasted until the 19th.

Notes: Port Glasgow and Newark were all joined at this time as the parish of Kilmacolm.  She was a servant to a maltman - but he supposedly fired her for her alleged involvement in tormenting Margaret Laird
Charnotes: She was accused of tormenting Margaret Murdoch and Margaret Laird.  Both girls displayed all the typical symptoms that have been described as 'demonic possession' - but the record refers to it as 'tormenting'.  Both girls spit and vomitted foreign object (hair, pins, stones, wool), had convulsions, bite and nip markes on their bodies and faces, extraordinary strength, the ability to sense when their tormenters were near, bruises and blisters, excessive thrashing, and clothes falling off.  Both girls were attended by physicians and ministers in order to diagnose and help them.
DiseaseNotes: All the accusations were for tormented girls.
CaseNotes: Denounced by Margaret Laird in Paisley, and Margaret Murdoch in Govan.  Both girls claimed to be tormented by witches.  Laird  and Murdoch denounced many people while in fits.  Most of the witness testimony was given in Paisley (19-21 April 1699, from Laird) and  Glasgow (22 April 1699 from Murdoch).  Testimony came from people who witnessed Laird's fits and denunciations among other things.
TrialNotes: Witness statements and a dittay from 21 and 22 April 1699.  A Trial was set for Glasgow on 19 May 1699 that doesn't appear to have happened.  Then the diet deserted in the high court in 1700.

TrialNotes: they were examined by the lord commissions they found no presumption of guilt and the charges were deemed malitious, they were released.

Charnotes: a very short entry in the sherrif court book.
DiseaseNotes: She was accused of witchcraft for taking the profit from a mans milk and that she had a reputation.  A sort of theft by witchcraft.
TrialNotes: She was 'dempt to quite tham selffis' to the Sherrif court. Basically this means that she was called and could try to get rid of the charge with oaths from his friends.  She was to do a 'larycht aith' that meant getting two neighbours to swear to her innocence and to pay a 2 merk silver fine.

Notes: no modern first name
DiseaseNotes: accused of stealing their neighbour's butter profit through withcraft. They produced more butter with their 2 cows than their neighbour with 7 cows.  Very suspect.
TrialNotes: They (the husband and wife) were to 'dempt to quite tham selffis' to the Sherrif court. Basically this means that he was called and could try to get rid of the charge with oaths from his friends.  He was to do a 'saxter aith' that meant getting six neighbours to swear to his innocence and to pay a 6 merk silver fine.  Failed the quittance of stowth (theft) 2 merk fine.

Notes: no modern first name

She was to do a 'saxter aith' that meant getting six neighbours to swear to his innocence and to pay a 6 merk silver fine.

DiseaseNotes: She was accused of stealing the profit of her neighbour's milk.
TrialNotes: to 'dempt to quite' herself to the Sherrif court. Basically this means that he was called and could try to get rid of the charge with oaths from her friends.  She was to do a 'Larycht aith' that meant getting 2 neighbours to swear to her innocence and to pay a 2 merk silver fine.

Notes: Not sure about the presbytery
CaseNotes: She was first called up to the Sheriff court on 3 July and refused to compear.  Then by 21 Aug. an accuser is ddemed to untrustworthy and she is to appear with a 'larycht aitch' (i.e. two people to swear an oath to her innocence).
TrialNotes: She was ordered to appear twice and hasn't.  Therefore she is to be tried at the first court of Tingwall to be held at Skalloway.

PretrialNotes: The Court of the Bishopric of Orkney ordered her to be tried by the Sheriff of Orkney for witchcraft.

Charnotes: Some neighbourhood dispute things (quarrels, curses, harm) and some stealing of her neighbours butter profit (i.e. through witchcraft making her cows produce more).
FolkNotes: She was seen in a transe repeating words when her husband was at sea and in trouble.
DiseaseNotes: Accused of stealing the butter from cows and transferring it to her own.  Several quarrels followed by curses followed by harm.
TrialNotes: This was a Court of Justiciary of the Sheriffdom of Yetland, recorded in the Sheriff Court books.

Charnotes: Marwick's notes do not provide solid enough evidence on which to base a primary characterisation.
FolkNotes: Used a wresting thread to cure a wrested cow.  Was paid 40 pennies for a cure.  Made a charm out of something like ground salt put into a cloute and put onto a cow's back.  A blue thread around a man's waist.  Worm grass for curing the worm.  Fasting and meat eating.
DiseaseNotes: Suspected of working with another woman to destroy the Laird of Halcrowe who was oppressing the people.
CaseNotes: She was questioned by the kirk session repeatedly over the course of 15 years for charming and witchcraft.  But they never seem to have formally charged her.

Charnotes: probably folkloric
FolkNotes: She supposedly sailed in a cockle shell.
CaseNotes: maybe folkloric, Supposedly killed between 1620-1640.  No trial information for her.

Charnotes: very little information available
FolkNotes: she supposedly walked about the town counter-clockwise.
PretrialNotes: investigated for suspected witchcraft.

Notes: I think A Wallis means that she is from Walls, however Walls parish is in Shetland.  No modern last name.
FolkNotes: cast a suitor's left shoe over the house to determine if one should marry him.  Walked thrise around the church with a bare head and hair flowing.
DiseaseNotes: cured a cow that almost suffocated in a mire.

DevilNotes: he met her at 2:00 and they kissed, the Devil had no breath.
MeetingNotes: Met the Devil in Sarah Cranston's house.  Sarah Cranston put her hand in the Devil's and the Devil carried Agnes away at night to two meetings.  They danced 'about ane hare'.

FolkNotes: She did a cure using 'plasteris and bathis of ???, and blak snailles upoun ane pece blak mantillone yairin' to cure a bad leg.  Also used bluid cress [watercress?], and a pece of blak clayt.
TrialNotes: She was tried in the burgh court.  She didn't confess, so after much deliberation the assize acquitted her.

Notes: no modern last name

Notes: I think the modern name is Beer.
TrialNotes: She was tried in a circuit court not sure when the Trial happened.  All we know is that two women were fined for non-compearance

Notes: The note said Galloway, but as this was not a county I have changed it Dumfries.
PretrialNotes: His son requested that he either be tried or released on bail at 500 merks Scots.  He claims his father was slandered by 'dispossesed' people with accusations of witchcraft.  He wanted to be tried either at the circuit court or at the High Court in Edinburgh.  The commissioners (not specificed) said that the officials in Galloway either have to release him or pay to move him to Edinburgh tolbooth.  Otherwise, short has to pay his own expences to Edinburgh and summon witnesses.

FolkNotes: Healed by wrapping a woman up in a linen cloth and then burning it.  Also used powder
OtherChargesNotes: His primary charge seems to be charming.
PretrialNotes: Was accused of charming and witchcraft but only confessed to charming.

Notes: Also known as Cristian Huntar.
TrialNotes: Ayr Court list from 6/4/1658, two porteous rolls (one of which dated 31 March 1658 summoned the whole 1658 group to appear  for trial).

Also known as Gavin in Sawer's trial from 1658.
also spelled as McKnacht.  Probably from Kircudbright, she was tried with a bunch of people from there.
Charnotes: We have a dittay and comments from witnesses.
MeetingNotes: Supposedly seen at a witches' meeting by a man who then killed himself by going over the craigs and into the sea.
FolkNotes: McNauth was the object of counter-magic.  Her victim was to seek her health and get three stopings of straw from Janet's lintel and burn them.  She was seen at the ale house with cats and carlings.  Use of a magic charm for protection.
DiseaseNotes: After cursing a woman hired someone to do magic on McNaught.  Janet was in charge of taking cows to pasture, she was angry over a late one and it stopped giving milk. A witch testified that a woman died refusing drink (either Janet or the woman?)
TrialNotes: have courtbook notes.  Pleads not guilty
PostTrialNotes: between 2 and 4 at the ordinary place, sentenced on 5/4/1659, to be executed the next Wednesday.

CaseNotes: M. Wasser says she was tried before the bailies of the regality of Lunores

Notes: Hendry has their parish as Cumnock.  But cumnock is an old parish and was partially merged with Auchinleck in the 17th Century.
From the parish of Alloway in Ayr.  Alloway was its own parish in the early part of our period and merged with Ayr in the latter 17th century.
TrialNotes: She was found guilty of being 'ane sempill abuser of the pepill as thoct she war ane witche'.  She was to be brought out of the tolbooth on a market day, put on a cart naked from the 'navill' up, to confess her crimes.  Then she was to be progressed around the city making her confession. Then she was to be put in the branks for two market days.  Then she was free, but if she continued in abusing the people she would be executed as a witch.

PostTrialNotes: Treasurer's account of cost of burning - coal £2 16s.; for rope 7s. 8d.; for tar barrel, £1; for a man to attend and execute her £4

Notes: In proceedings against her daughter at the Kirk session of Dundonald she was described as 'ane notit witch'.

PostTrialNotes: A man was paid to do his office upon Bessie Bell and utheris for £4 11s. 4d. (same man from earlier Ayr trials).

PretrialNotes: Not known what happened to her, only that James Lowdoun, officer was paid £7 14s. For warding her in the tolbooth of Ayr.

Notes: Husband was a burgess
PretrialNotes: The Ayr Presbytery ordered a letter to be written to the Privy Council for the purchase a commission to try her.

She was investigated by the Presbytery of Irvine for trilapse fornication and witchcraft.  She was pregnant so the Presbytery decided to delay proceedings against her.
The Presbytery requested a commission from either the Privy Council or the Committee of Estates.
Possibly sought commission from the Committee of Estates.  The Privy Council seems to be the local people's first choice of where to go for a commission of justiciary.

PostTrialNotes: She was executed sometime before 14 November 1650 when her husband tried to do something with his wife's property 'who was executed for the crime of witchcraft'.  The officials were trying to use her property to pay for her imprisonment.

PretrialNotes: Apprehended by the Bailie Depute of Cunninghame.
She was apprehended, and a couple were cited before the Presbytery for writing her a letter saying not to confess.

She was in ward with Jonet Sawer, Jonet Slowan, and Elizabeth Cunningham.  Crawfurd seems to drop out of later action taken against the other three.  There seems to have been a commission granted but unclear from where and whether or not it was acted on.
The Privy Council handed the case over to the Lord Advocate (his majesty's advocate) due to irregularities with how the commission was carried out.

Charnotes: accused of charms, malefices and correspondence with the Devil.
TrialNotes: the verdict was presented to the Privy Council on 26/7/1698
PostTrialNotes: The privy council approved the verdict and set this date as her execution date.

Notes: Mother to John Glass also accused of witchcraft.

PretrialNotes: This case was under a Privy Council commission (see PC1/51 p. 136-9) along with most of the people tried at the same time.  There were other Renfrewshire witchcraft suspects tried at different places and times.  I am keeping this as a mixed/central local because the Privy Council maintained very strict control over the proceedings, even though they granted a commission.  For details of the proceedings of Privy Council in this matter see the no named witches case c/la/3235.  He was not tried with the rest of the group.

Notes: Husband was a miller.  She married her first husband (who she confessed to killing) in England.
Charnotes: This is an unusual case.  She confessed to turning to the Devil to help her kill her first husband, which she did with a drink.  She also procured an abortion for her daughter who died from it.  She had been having an extramarital affair with her second husband while still married to the first.  She tried to kill herself at least three times, by hanging with her curch, cutting her throat while in prison, banging her head on the stocks.
DevilNotes: The devil nipped her check, which people could see on her face.
FolkNotes: She murdered her husband with a drink made of foxtree leaves and tried to give her daughter an abortion (a drink of wine and salt) that backfired when her daughter died.  Her grief and guilt seem to lay behind her confession.  She confessed that the Devil told her how to make both drinks.
DiseaseNotes: she murdered her husband and tried to give her daughter an abortion that backfired in her death.
CaseNotes: She tried to kill herself three times.  The appendix of 'Witchcraft Cases from the Register of Commissions of the Privy Council of Scotland, 1630-42', edited by L. Yeoman has the dates for her commission and trial for 1634.  There is a discrepancy with the dates.  The commission dated 30/12/1634 was clearly was issued before her trial, the date of which is listed as 6/1/1634.  Therefore I have set the trial date at 6/1/1635.
PretrialNotes: She was first arrested for trying to kill herself.  When in prison they asked her why she tried to kill herself.  She said she had murdered her first husband and her daughter and turned to the Devil.  She confessed it all to the ministers and baillies of Haddington.
PostTrialNotes: To be executed at the usual place.

PretrialNotes: The minister and elders of the Dunfermline kirk session made a complaint to the committee of estates regarding a supplication made on Mastertoun's behalf regarding her torture and imprisonment.  The session argued that she should remain in prison and that they be allowed to use lawful means to bring her to confession.  They said that comfort makes it harder to discover witchcraft.  They do not want her released on caution and they want her to pay her own imprisonment  The committee agreed with them and their petition was granted.

Arrangements for witches' trial and execution.  Collection arranged for coal and fordell and 'for ye swesche'.  More details about concerns for contributions for taking, sustaining and execution of witches.  Doesn't specify a number so I applied our standard estimate of three.
Act against persons suspect of witchcraft remaining in the town or that anyone set house to such people.

Commission: commission for execution issued by parliament
CaseNotes: certain persons from Humbie and Keithmarschall to be executed.
execution of certain persons from Tranent.
The wives of magistrates from Inverkeithing were ordered to be arrrested. The town council had refused to act and the church/minister appealed to parliament.
No specific numbers mentioned, only several witches from Carriden parish apprehended and further investigations requested.  Ministers are supposed to make enquiries.

48 unnamed individuals were accused by Janet Coutts (C/EGD/1817) after she was searched by George Cathie. The presbytery of Biggar were sceptical about her testimony and brought her to confront those she had named. They found many inconsistencies in her account and after prayer she confessed that she had only accused innocent people because Cathie had promised to prolong her life if she did so. The 48 individuals were therefore not pursued any further.  The case against them was dropped by the presbytery on 29/12/1649.
1 man and 3 woman from Whittingehame were executed.  The execution was attended by the minister.
note that 10 witches burnt in Dunbar and that they were witnessed by a minister.

Several witches mentioned = 3 un-named. They were mentioned several times as trial process took some months but the presbytery records did not list their names.  They refer to a trial held at Jedburgh at which ministers assisted/attended.  Then they were recorded as executed on 16/1/1650 at Oxnam.

On 12/6/1650 the presbytery minutes recorded that 4 people in Castleton (in the presbytery of Langholm) were suspected of witchcraft and incantation. No names were recorded in the presbytery minutes.  Then on 26/6/1650 ministers were supposed to assist in the execution of the suspects.

'a great many persons' from Musselburgh, Dalkeith, Newbattle, Newton (+ Woomet) and Duddingston but no number or names specified, number calculated as three from each place.  So that is 5 x 3 = 15.  The Privy Council records note that the accused men and women were imprisoned and had already confessed.  A commission of justiciary was issued after petitions from heritors and others from the different parishes.
Nine unnamed executed for witchcraft and ministers were ordered to assist.

Several people in the parish of Caerlaverock suspected of witchcraft. Only one person named in presbytery records - Bessie Heslope, C/JO/2898.  Presbytery told about number of suspected witches in Caerlaverock. Committee investigated, 27/3/1705, but unsure whether witchcraft proven. Details sent to Queen's Advocate who replied that there were no grounds for criminal process. Presbytery drop the matter on 26/7/1705.

Referred to as 'the witches of Douglas'. No number given so averaged as 3 suspects.  Note in the Presbytery minutes that brethren were to be sent to Lanark to apprehend the suspects. No details about what happened.
Un-named witches from Dysart and Fife. Presbytery directed the baillies of Dysart to ensure the suspects were watched and brought to trial.
Unnamed suspects in 2 parishes (Navar and either Strathcathro or Lethnot) in presbytery of Brechin.
Unnamed witches from Tarbat, presbytery of Tain, mentioned in presbytery records - recorded as 3. Minister to write south for advice about the case but no further details in records.
I think these suspects from Thurso are the same as C/EGD/2461, C/EGD/2462, C/EGD/2085, C/EGD/2086, C/EGD/2087 and C/EGD/2088, who all have their own records. I have recorded this total as zero.
Note that Mr James Blair (minister at Portpatrick) and other ministers were to attend to commission for trial of witches the next day. Later reported that this had been delivered.

4 women in Caerlaverock suspected of witchcraft.  Presbytery investigated the suspects and noted that the moderator was to write to the sheriff depute to get commission to secure them 'their due trial'. Mr Paton reported that the sheriff was going to write for the commission but they presbytery felt that they should also write to the Privy Council. No further details.

Un-named witches mentioned by Dumfries presbytery as being in prison. Also named with Janet Wharrie (C/JO/3025).  Presbytery recorded that the group of witches were in prison and Mr Veitch was appointed to send the processes to the King's Advocat. There seems to have been a long delay before Mr Blair reported that the King's advocat said there was nothing so 'momentous as to require a commission to put them to trial'. Ministers appointed to inquire about their imprisonment but no mention if they were released or if the investigation was dropped.

Charnotes: Important note about process, they were involved in watching and warding (i.e. sleep deprivation) to try and get confessions.  Also a pricker was brought in to test for the Devil's mark.
CaseNotes: Investigations by Stow kirk session. No names listed. Group were imprisoned and there was ongoing discussions about watching and warding. Kirk session wrote to presbytery trying to get financial support for the trial process.  On 8/1649 the situation was referred to the local magistrate.
Un-named others accused at the same time as Margaret Coul (C/JO/3105).

Some women in from Brechin were executed.  A particularly graphic description of local justice - the women were tried and convicted (although they denied the charges) and 'wes brunt quick efter sic ane crewell maner that sum of thame deit in dispair, renunceand and blasphemeand, and utheris, half brunt, brak out of the fyre and wes cast in quick in it againe quhill thay war brunt to the deid.'

A commission for trial of witches by Earl Merschell.  The Bishops think that more commissions of this kind should be granted.  They argued that it was too expensive and inconvenient for people to come to Edinburgh for trials.  But they advise the council to take care in deciding about commissions.

The first of two commissions granted for Galloway.  The second was granted in 1615.  The two commissions were for arrest and justiciary.  2nd commission stressed that the bishop was to advice the others in the process.
This is the second of two commission issued for Galloway.  The first was issued in 1614.
Witchcraft was exepted from the benefit of passification.  I think this means that other crimes will be pardoned but not witchcraft. [passed by the Regent Morton]
witchcraft cannot be remitted by the purchasing of a remittance.

Call for criminal cases to be heard by James VI starting 27/11/1587 in Edinburgh then travelling throughout the realm.  Witchcraft is listed (towards the end) as one of the crimes to be tried.  No suspects are listed.

This was a commission for the people listed in the 'people' section to arrest, interrogate, torture and try suspected witches.  It basically says that the use of torture is OK to get people to confess.  It is an open commission, meaning there are no specified suspects.  I have left the number of suspects at zero because this commission is so general and because we already have many people tried during this time in the database.

Commission: for the general assembly to fill in commissioners
CaseNotes: The king ordered that blank (of noblemen, barons, gentlemen and magistrates) commissions should be passed under the signet and by the subscription for the clerk of Privy Council to the General Assembly for them to hand out as they saw fit for maters of witchcraft.    They could issue these blank commissions for arrest, investigation, and trial of witches.  The commissions to expire on 1/11/1592.  This was granted in response to the fallout around allegations of witchcraft and consulting directed at the Earl of Bothwell and associates.

Commission: all requests for commissions to go throughthe Privy Council
CaseNotes: His majesty ordered that requests for commissions of justiciary for the crimes of theft, receiving of stolen property, slaughter, murder, witchcraft and other capital crimes were not to be submitted to him personally.  They were to go to the Kings secretary and then delivered to the Privy Council for deliberations.  'Commissions otherwise passed are to be null.'

Commission: granting of full power of commissions to a commissioner
CaseNotes: Sir William Steward of Houston, commendator of Pittenweem was appointed with the power to grant all commissions for the Highlands and Islands for a specified length of time in order to promote law and order.  He was authorised to hold courts for the crimes of fire-raising, ravishing of women, murder, slaughter, counterfitting, false coinage, theft, receiving of stolen property, witchcraft, sorcery, enchantment, sorning, oppression etc.

A revocation of previously granted commissions for the arrest, investigation and trial of suspects of witchcraft, sorcery, enchantment and devilish practices.  People of high rank could apply for a new commission if they had known witches in their lands.  [seems to be a sort of clearing house for open ended commissions?]

Commission: of Lieutenancy in the West March to Lord Ochiltree
CaseNotes: Commission of Lieutenancy in the West March to Andrew, Lord Ochiltree to ward and hold justice courts on people he saw fit, including witchcraft suspects.

Commission of justiciary and lieutenancy within the bounds of the the South and West Isles to Ludovick, Duke of Lennox.  It includes witchcraft with the usual list of 10-20 different crimes.  A search through his papers may yeild witchcraft prosecutions?
commission granted to apprehend and try 'sundry persons' within the bounds of Galloway.
commission granted to the Steward of Kirkudbright to apprehend and try divers persons for witchcraft in Galloway, he was to consult with the Bishop of Galloway before proceeding with executions.

Commission: Procedural change requiring Bishops to review cases.
CaseNotes: The Privy Council decided that in the future all applications to the Privy Council to grant witchcraft trial commissions, have to pass through the bishops of the diocesses of the suspected persons.
Order to try witches in Duddingston and Libberton

Duns and Chirnside in the Merse.  They requested a commission for the trial of 'diverse both men and weomen' who are suspected of witchcraft.  They had already petitioned for a commission once and were denied.  6 unnamed witches can be estimated - three from each presbetery.

A privicy council decision in the wake of the Geilis Johnston case that the kirk and presbyteries can handle matters of witchcraft when they are simply a mater of idolitry and heresy if the person confesses.  If the suspect denies the charges the case must be handed over to the  'juge ordinar'.  The church can still investigate.  I don't know how this ruling played out in practice?

Ruling that it was not lawful to arrest a person merely on suspicion of witchcraft unless they were caught red-handed doing something like raising dead bodies and taking joints or dancing in the Kirk at midnight.  Suspected witches had to be first summoned and questioned, like any other criminal suspect, before being arrested.  If they are summond and do not appear, they are fugitive and can be arrested when found.

Other: specification of witchcraft under jurisdiction of circuit courts
CaseNotes: The privy council specified that witchcraft, sorcery and necromancy  are under the jurisdiction of the circuit courts.
An open commission for the bailies to search for, arrest and examine suspected witches in his lands.  Required to report back to the Privy Council before trying anybody.
List of crimes that the Privy Council wants the circuit courts to try.  'Charmers and consulters with witches and sorcerers' is the 3th item listed, after making false coin and communing with rebels.

The Moderator and elders request that the Privy Council order local nobles to make space in their jails for witchcraft suspects.  They thank the Earl of Morton for the use of his prison, but he now needs it for delinquents.  The PC ordered that space be made and that the presbytery report back to PC for commissions as per usual.

Commission: Privy Council order to send Haddington witches to the Bishop
CaseNotes: The Privy Council 'prorogatis' the commissions granted to the presbytery of Haddinton for the trial of witches until the next council day, and orders the depositions to be sent to the Bishop of St. Andrews to report back to the PC on their next meeting.

The witch-pricker James Balfour in Corshous was rebuked for abusing ignorant and innocent people with his pretended knowledge of finding witches marks with pins.  His knowlegde was deemed conjectural and unlawful within God's church.

Commission: Justic Court of Jedburgh and Dumfries
CaseNotes: Appointed a justice court to be held in Jedburgh on 1/2/1643 and in Dumfries on 15/2/1643, to try witchcraft among other crimes.  On 3/1/1643 the justic courts were postponed till March 8th and 16th due to shortness of time for preparing.
Just a note in the miscellaneous section, under the roll of business.

Commission: utheris to be dilate and aprrehendit
CaseNotes: Other people suspected of witchcraft, but not yet named were mentioned in a request for a general commission from people in Haddington in 1649.

Complaint: bailies complaint about friends of witches visiting them in ward
CaseNotes: The bailies reprimand a crowd of friends and family who protested to delated witches.  Specifically the 'vindictive, injurious, and opprobrius speaches' uttered at the bailies.  Fines were then imposed for the breach at the ward.

In a letter from Roger Aston to Robert Bowes, he laments the death of the chancelor and reports other news including about the three witches.  'The Earl of Caithness has sent hither three witches out of Caithness that dealt with the Earl Bothwell at his being there'.

Correspondence: many witches are taken and burnt in the Merse
CaseNotes: In a letter from George Nicolson to Robert Bowes.  He narrates many matters including: 'Many witches are taken and burnt in the Merse, some for mean, some for greater matters.'  I estimated three for 'many witches' in accordance with our standard practice.

In a letter from Robert Bowes to Burghley.  He describes that a Duch gentlewoman from Lubeck sought the King of Scots at Elsinore, but not finding him there came to Edinburgh with a prophesy from good witches.  James VI agreed to hear her.
I am counting this as zero witches because it is in reference to the 'North Berwick'.  It says he was occupied with the 'examination' of sundry witches.

Letter from Roger Aston to James Hudson, set at zero witches because it is commentary regarding the investigations into the North Berwick witches.  'We are busy examining witches, who confess many strange things'

Correspondence: Some of the worst sort of witches escaped to England
CaseNotes: A letter from Robert Bowes to Burghley.  'Some of the worst sort of witches - discovered here -  are eschaped and fled into England.'  James VI sent David Seaton of Tranent, gentleman, to find them and bring them back for trial.

A woman was brought back to Scotland from ward in England.  The King was reportedly very pleased.  The woman 'hath accused many others, and if found to have practiced sundry wicked actions by her sorceryes.'  I count the woman as one and the 'many others' as three unnamed witches in accordance with our standard estimating practice.

Correspondence: description of scepticism about 1590-1 withcraft trials
CaseNotes: Letter from Robert Bowes to Burghley in which he says he is sceptical about the truth in the confessions and testimony from the King's examination of witches.  He said they confessed to abusing God's name and yeilding themselves to evil spirits.  He thinks the confessors were 'suborned'.  He objects to himself being described by a witch as 'a little black and fatt man with black haire'.  He said she got his description wrong so the other information she provided may also be wrong.  Also points to John Fean's recanting his testimony at his execution.

A letter from Bowles to Burghley about the 1590-1 witches.  He provides part of Agnes Sampsoune's confession, lists a number of people who were burnt in Haddington, says 'ane in Dalkeith', 'ane in Dumfreish' were also executed so I will count 2 unnamed witches.  Because we know who the Haddington ones were.

Correspondence: instructions from James VI concerning witches
Charnotes: Instructions from James VI as to how to handle some of the North Berwick, treason-cum-witchcraft trials.
CaseNotes: A letter from James VI to Maitland, to examine Barbara Napier to see if she was really pregnant - 'if she be not, to the fyre uith her presentlies, and cause bouell her publicclie.'  'let Effie Makkaillen see the stoup twa or three dayes, and upon the suddain staye her in hope of confession.'  The rest of the witches 'of at the naill uith thaim.'  But Maitland is to make sure that Richie Grahme gets his ordinary allowance.
a letter from Bowes to Burghley saying that James VI has been occupied with the 'fast on Sunday' and the examination of witches.

Letter from Bowes to Burghley describing Ewphame Mackallean's trial and its impact on Bothwell's case.  He says that 'Kennedy the witch of Reydon, lately in England' will be more trouble to Bothwell.  Indicated 0 unnamed witches because both of the people mentioned here have records of their own.

Sundry witches taken some that wished to harm the king.  This is from 'Notes on Scottish Affairs.  Because no specific number, other than 'sundry' was given in this source, I Indicated three unnamed witches in line with our usual estimating practice.
summary of Acts passed in parliament 13/6/1563, with punishment of Death for witches in the list.

Bowes to Burghley, says that the king is in Stirling and that he has been lately troubled by witches, a McKolme Anderson confessed that he and others tried to drown the King as he passed over the water at Dundee at the General Assembly, and that the life of the Prince has also been sought by witches.  Counted 3 unnamed to account for the 'and others'.

Correspondence: King James is interested in a great number of witches
CaseNotes: 'The king has his mind only bent upon the examination and trial fo sorcerers, men and women.  Sut a great number are 'delated' that it is a wonder and those not only of the meanest sort but also of the best.'

Correspondence: From King to the Privy Council
CaseNotes: the first letter is the response for request for protection from Sir George Home so he can resolve the matter of witchcraft trials.  It was granted.  The second was a restatement and an offer of protection to his son Alexander Home.

In this letter from the King to the advocate, he says that he has been informed that Alexander Hammilton confessed to witchcraft and delated others for practices against thelife and estate of Sir George Home .  But that Sir George Home was also accused of suborning witnesses.  The King told the advocate to sort it out and determine which party was lying.  This letter concerned procedures rather than Hammilton's specific case.

This letter from the King to the Lord of Lorne concerns the warrant from the Scottish Privy Council to arrest John Neill who was suspect of witchcraft.  Neill had fled into England.  The King's letter orders justice officials in the Northumberland to find him and send him back to Scotland for trial, to be handed over to Sir William Cockburne of Longtoune, the Sheriff of Berwick.
A commission from the General Assembly,  held in Edinburgh in 1646, requesting that charming be included in the remit of the 1563 witchcraft act.

A note in the Tyninghame Kirk Session minutes said that people who cured their beasts of the 'rowting evill' by making a grave and 'earding' or entering 'ane quick beist' in it could be charged with charming and witchcraft.  They argue that this practices has been used in Wittinghame and some other parishes.

Other: Arrest of C. Cauldwell (alias John Dickson) as a witchpricker
CaseNotes: Christian Cauldwell (sometimes spelled Caddell) alias John Dickson was idicted as a common oppressor for dressing as a man and acting as a witchpricker.  She pretended to be a burgess from Forfar.  She was held in the tolbooth of Edinburgh 30 Aug. 1662 and interrogated by the justice deputes.  She mentioned two unnamed people she accused of witchcraft and many from six counties. (Estimate 2 witches from each county plus 2 for a total of 14 unnamed witches.)  As a man she contracted with officials in Moray to be their witch pricker for one year.  She was paid 6 shillings a day and £6 for every witch who was found guilty.  She travelled and worked with a woman named Issobell Dick.  She claimed she could tell witches by sight, by looking into their eyes and that she learned her skill by watching John Kincaid, a witch pricker active in the Lothians.  She was accused of pricking 'many of his majesties leiges' in the sheriffdoms of Elgin, Forres, Nairn, Inverness, Ross and Sutherland.
It is describing the crimes the court will try.  Specifically it is stated that no one is allowed to conceal acts of witchcraft.  Witchcraft is listed in number 17 'anent the conceilling of sinne'.
It is describing the crimes the court will try.  Specifically it is stated that no one is allowed to conceal acts of witchcraft.  Witchcraft is listed in number 21 'anent the conceilling of sinne'.

Other: Statute forbidding the concealment of witchcraft
CaseNotes: The Lawting Sheriff and Justice Court (much like the Court of the Bishopric later that same year, see c/la/3049) forbade the concealing of witchcraft and other crimes such as theft, murder, oppression, blood wrongs, etc.  This act was in a whole series of justice acts regarding all manner of things, hiring servants, weights and measures, etc.

Other: Shetland law forbidding the concealment of witchcraft
CaseNotes: The Shetland Sheriff Court passed a whole series of laws (much like the Lawting Sheriff and Justice Court of Orkney and the Court of the Bishopric later that same year, see c/la/3051, c/la/3049).  they forbade the concealing of witchcraft and other crimes such as theft, murder, oppression, blood wrongs, etc.  This act was in a whole series of justice acts regarding all manner of things, hiring servants, weights and measures, etc.

Commission: to try witches in the Highlands and Isles.
CaseNotes: This is a report that Marie Nian James Nic Coull escaped the justice of a commission issued by the Privy Council to try witches in the Highlands and Isles.

He was investigated for oppression and interrogated as to how he could identify witches.  He claims to have learned his skill from confessing witches.  He claims to know witches by sight.  He was questioned about specific rituals he used such as walking witches backwards, keeping them away from walls.  He said he could identify the smell of witches because their carnal dealings with the Devil left an odour like a dead corpse.

The General Assembly was not happy that the civil magistrate was refusing to prosecute accused witches and setting some suspects free.  They resolved that Presbyteries should' proceed in all severities with their censures againis all such Magistrats as sall sett at liberties any person convict of witchcraft heirafter.'
A man was paid to do his office upon Bessie Bell and utheris for £4 11s. 4d. (same man from earlier Ayr trials).
Mr. Wm Guthrey and two ministers of Stewarton were appointed to deal with some people who were apprehended for witchcraft in the parish of Dreghorn.  They were supposed to bring them to a confession.

The Privy Council granted a commission of investigation to look into the witchcraft accusations made by Cristian Shaw.  The commission allows for investigation, witness depositions, and giving caution to stand trial.  But they needed permission to arrest suspects.  They were to report back to the Privy Council by 10 March.  That was done on 19/1/1697.  Then the Privy Council issued a commission to try 24 named people in Renfrewshire (their records are updated with this info.), the Privy Counicl agreed to appoint 'such a somme as they shall think fitt' for imprisoning and trying the Refrewshire witches.  That was from 9 March 1697.  This commission gives concrete instructions as to how the commissioners were required to set up court and run the trial.  The the Privy Council agreed to let the commissioners hold courts at Paisley, Glasgow or anywhere else in Renfrewshire this was on 5 April 1697.  By 4 October 1698 the sheriff depute wrote a letter to the Privy Council requesting further funds for the maintanence of people in prison or a commission to try them.  The Privy Council agreed to pass the matter over to the Lord advocate and to reimburse who ever maintained the suspects.  On 12 January 1699 the Privy Council authorised the Sheriff depute to maintain each prison with not more than one groat each per day to be reimbursed by the treasury.
Mr. Robert Ramsay declared from the pulpit, by the authority of the Presbytery, that people who were caught charming or resorting to charming would be prosecuted to the death for witchcraft.

Other: Church of Scotland petition to Parliament
CaseNotes: The Church of Scotland petitioned Parliament to renew the acts about charmers, sorcerers and consulters - and that 'a solid way takin how the same acts may be put to execution.'

The minister of Straiton, Mr. Johne M'Quorne asked the Presbytery's advice as to whether or not he could take a woman in Galloway named Jeane M'Murran around his parish to identify witches.  He had sundry suspected witches as 'Jean took upon her the discoverie of witches throw the cuntrey.'  The answer was no, because the late General Assembly had 'condemed and discharged the foirsaid practice in all tyme coming'.

Other: for tryal and torture of witches
CaseNotes: 'Act and warrant for tryall of the torture of witches.'

Other: Bailie requests ministers to wait upon 12 condemed witches
CaseNotes: The Baillie of Cuninghame told the presybery of Irvine that an assize would be held on 12 people who had confessed to witchcraft and that the execution would take place on the following Friday.  He requested the Presbytery to send ministers to wait upon them before their death, which the Presbytery did.  They sent 13 ministers.
Several parishes in the Presbytery of Irvine had confessing witches, so they recommended that the Presbytery write to the Privy Council for a commission of assize.

Other: Bailie complaint to Presbytery about their improper arresting of suspects
CaseNotes: The Bailie of Cunninhame reported to the Presbytery that sundry people had been arrested within the bounds of the Presbytery without a warrant.  They should refrain from arresting people, and report to the Bailie if they have suspects.

Other: Council remits to magistrates for imprisoning and apprehending
CaseNotes: 'the Counsall remitts to the Magistratis as they think most fitting to give ordor als weill for imprisonning as for the payment of the chargis of these personnis apprehendit and delaitfor withcraft'  I take this to mean the people we already know about for Ayrshire at this time so I have not added any to the count of suspects.

Four witches were to be executed the next Saturday at Irvine, for witchcraft.  They appointed three additional ministers to attend to the execution.  This could be the execution of the four people for whom the Presbytery of Irvine requested a commission on 1 May 1650 (c/la/3205), (c/la/3133), (c/egd/1836), (c/la/3206).

The moderator of the Ayr presbytery 'made report that he had written to the states for a general commission against witches, as also to the baillies of carrik to use the like diligence against witches within there bounds.'

Ayr parish session ordered elders and deacons to make themselves available for 24 hours 'per vices both in the day and in the night, shall oversie the said prisoners to exhort them to confessione and to pray with them to God'.  An example of orders for wathcing and warding.

Ayr Kirk session mentioned that the first witches were burnt in Irvine.  I indicated 0 suspects because we have a many known suspects from Irvine, so these witches will get into the final count as individual witches.  This is to avoid double-counting suspects.

Correspondence: Description of Torture written to the Speaker of the Parliament in Westminster
Charnotes: At least 9 witchcraft suspects were tortured, four of them died.
CaseNotes: A letter from Mr. William Clarke to the Speaker of Parliament in Westminster described how at least seven witchcraft suspects were made to confess (about the time the armies came into Scotland).  They were first brought before the Kirk session and made to confess and then turned over to the civil magistrate.  The court claimed they were forced to confess through 'exceeding torture'.  They tied their 'thumbs behind them' and hanged them by them, they were whipped by two Highlanders, and had lighted candles put to the soles of their feet, between their toes and in their mouths.  Six were accused and four died from the torture.  Another suspect was kept 20 days on bread and water after being stripped naked and laid on a cold stone with only a hair-cloth.  Others had hair-shirts dipped in vinegar to 'fetch off their skin'.

Other: Fast ordered by the Synod because of witches
CaseNotes: The Synod, met at Paisley 'anent the business of witchcraft'.  They ordered 5 May 1697 as a day of humiliation and fasting.

Other: Presbytery sent a representative to Parliament to discuss laws relating to witchcraft
CaseNotes: The Clerk of the Synod wanted each presbytery to send 'some of their number' to Edinburgh to Parliament to have a say in their deliberations against 'poperie, prophanity, schism, and to crave a new and plainer Law against Adultery, Witchcraft, etc.'

The presbytery reported that several people were arrested from Dalry due to delation and 'mala fama'.   'They were apprehended by the Judge Ordinary' and were still impenitent [refusing to confess] therefore it is appointed that Mr. Patrick Colville and Mr. W. S. Russel, shall go to Dalry.'  They got one person to confess.  Because Mr. Robert Bell was unwell, infirm and short of hearing the Presbytery sent Mr. Robert Urie and Mr. James Rowat to exhort the remaining impenitent witches to confess.
Several people in Largs confessed to witchcraft and were recommended to the Committee of Estates for a commission.
